DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF PROFESSOR GORDON STANLEY REID, A.C.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death, on 26 October 1989, of Professor Gordon Stanley Reid, A.C., former Governor of the State of Western Australia from July 1984 till September this year.

INTERJECT.PARA: Professor Reid was an officer in the Department of the House of Representatives for 12 years, for the last three of which he was the Serjeant-at-Arms. He then began a distinguished academic career during which he was well known for his writings on parliament. In 1966 he was appointed Professor of Politics at the University of Western Australia where he continued until his appointment as Professor of Political Science at the Australian National University in 1971. In 1974 he returned to the University of Western Australia as Professor of Politics and in 1978 he was appointed Deputy Vice-Chancellor for a period of four years.

Professor Reid was co-author of the book Australia's Commonwealth Parliament 1901-1988, a major work in the Parliament's Bicentenary publications project. This book was launched by the Governor-General at a ceremony in Parliament House on 31 May this year. Professor Reid leaves a wife, two sons and two daughters.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, it is not the intention to move a formal condolence motion in respect of the death of Professor Reid, but I make the point that from the Government's point of view Professor Reid followed a distinguished career in a variety of capacities-as a servant of this Parliament, as a legal commentator and jurist, and as Governor of Western Australia. I recognise that, and express sympathy to his family and friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I had proposed to say something on the adjournment about the late Professor Reid. Unusually, he combined service to this Parliament as a Clerk with a whole range of other things, including ultimately being the Governor of the State of Western Australia. Professor Reid achieved the support of all Western Australians in his service in that post. He was very warmly and highly regarded. I believe that Mrs Reid also contributed very greatly to the affection with which they were held in Western Australia. I know that Professor Reid put a great deal of effort into the work that he produced as part of the Bicentennial celebration and the celebration of this Parliament. He took the unusual course of accepting the governorship of Western Australia only on condition that he could continue that work which he had already commenced to undertake. It is splendid that in these last years of his life he was able to contribute in a number of different ways.

SPEECH.PARA: My main reason in wishing to speak about the late Professor Reid is simply that he was a particularly fine man and he had a particularly fine family. I wish to express my sympathy to them at this very sad time. I know I speak on behalf of all Opposition senators when I say that. We thank his family for his splendid contribution to Australia as a serviceman-he served in the Royal Australian Air Force-as a servant of this Parliament, as an academic, as an author and, finally, as the representative of Her Majesty in the State of Western Australia. We extend our sincerest sympathy to his family on their very considerable loss.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I will speak only briefly, not out of disrespect to the memory of the previous Governor of Western Australia but because of the way in which this matter has been presented to the Senate for discussion. I knew Professor Reid as a professor of political science. One could not hope to meet a more gentlemanly, quietly spoken and presentable person. In fact, it was probably fairly unusual for a professor of political science to rise to such eminence. He was extremely well regarded by all of his colleagues throughout Australia in terms of the quality of his scholarship and presentation. Those senators who have read the book that he laboured over for so many years until last year will have seen evidence of the quality of his scholarship, combined with the ability to make a readable and presentable piece of work which can also enthral one about the history of this great country.

SPEECH.PARA: Professor Reid had been sick for some time and finally had to resign from his position as Governor because of his illness and the pressures imposed on him by the job. His passing represents an enormous loss for the people of Western Australia, to the world of scholarship and to those of us who had the benefit and the joy of knowing such a fine, outstanding person.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to identify myself with those who have preceded me in noting the death of the former Governor of Western Australia, Gordon Reid. I had the privilege to serve on the Library Committee when we were canvassing the invitation to be offered to write a history of this Parliament and for that to be completed by our bicentennial year. I strongly urged that an invitation should go to Gordon Reid-a very well-established political scientist and historian of Australian politics. His appointments in this Parliament have already been rehearsed by those who have spoken before me.

SPEECH.PARA: Gordon Reid was an excellent appointment as the historian to write the book in collaboration with some other scholars. When the book was completed it was launched in this building and many honourable senators were present at that launch only six months ago. I remember, at the time when the Governor-General launched the book, the glowing smile on Gordon Reid's face. I reflect on our temporary time on this earth by saying that it was with great surprise that we learnt, only weeks after that, that he had a terminal illness. In many ways it was his crowning achievement to have completed a most worthy history of this Parliament whilst he was the Governor of Western Australia.

I had great respect for him as a man. I think he was a fair and wonderful Australian. He had the respect of many academics for his work in universities. He spent a considerable period living in my home State of South Australia and I have got to know the members of his family quite well. I express to his family members, to his wife and children, my very sincere condolences on the death of this fine Australian.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to identify myself with the remarks that have been made by various speakers today on the unfortunate, premature passing of Professor Gordon Reid. I agree with all of the remarks that have been made about his academic standing, his role as Governor of Western Australia and his character and presence as an individual. For my part, I had all too brief a contact with him, but in the discussions I had with him he was certainly an informative figure and a man who brought a great deal of compassion and understanding to his tasks. As Governor of Western Australia I remember him telling me that for him it was a great experience to be Governor because it brought him directly in contact with Australians from all walks of life, enabled him to know and better understand the State in which he was the vice-regal representative and provided him with many warm memories. I wish to record my condolences for his wife and his family.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I would like to say very briefly that I knew Gordon Reid very well indeed, particularly in the context of the role he played in the attempts to get more reason and rationality into constitutional reform in this country over a long period with the successive Constitutional Conventions. I knew him also as a political science scholar and as a man long associated with this parliamentary institution. He was a fine scholar, a fine gentleman, and I wish his family every condolence.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. Would the Minister care to tell the Senate the truth about the carrying capacity of domestic air services? Is it the 60 per cent plus that Senator Button, the Prime Minister and the airlines are claiming? Is it the 51 per cent which Mr Willis says is more accurate if we take account of all services or is it the 35 per cent calculated by the Age newspaper in a survey at Melbourne Airport last Friday? What was the basis of the claim by Mr Willis that by mid-November the airlines would be operating at 80 per cent of normal capacity and why has he now changed that claim to make it relate to early December? Will that prediction turn out to be as nonsensical and as inoperative as the previous claims relating to in excess of 60 per cent? When does the Government believe there will be anything remotely approaching normalcy in the domestic air services-by `normalcy' I mean not having to wait for half an hour just to get through to the reservations clerk, not having to wait hours in airport terminals as hundreds of people did in Sydney on Thursday and then be told that their promised flights had disappeared and had been cancelled? When will people be able to plan and travel with any reasonable degree of certainty?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that during the June quarter of 1989 an average of 34,834 passengers per day flew on aircraft provided by all of the airlines affected by the dispute. The figure of 62 per cent was based on 21,745 seats available on 17 October compared with a demand of 34,834-the figure I have just mentioned. On Sunday Mr Willis, I am advised, was using an average number of seats per day of 40,000 which is an estimate of how many people would normally be flying at this time of the year. It is a difficult calculation to make. The figure of 51 per cent last week represents seats available of around 21,000 provided on average in the previous week compared to that figure of 40,000. Traffic levels fluctuate on a day to day basis. Last Friday capacity averaged 23,000 seats per day which represents 66 per cent of capacity using, again, the base of 34,834.

ANSWER.PARA: Whichever measure we choose to adopt, the simple fact is that the airlines have now restored, as Mr Willis made it very clear, a substantial amount of capacity-much larger than that suggested by so-called independent observers and, of course, by the Australian Federation of Air Pilots. With their moves to acquire additional leased aircraft and to operate more of their own fleet, the airlines are confident that by mid-November they will be catering for over 80 per cent of total demand. Beyond that, I have nothing further to add in response to the question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Four Corners program last week which dealt with the marketing of breast milk substitutes? Does the Government accept that the World Health Organisation international code on marketing these products is effective? If not, what action can the Government take to ensure that the marketing of breast milk substitutes does not adversely affect the health of young children?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Four Corners program last week highlighted concern about the use of certain breast milk substitutes, particularly in Third World countries. Australia has supported the World Health Organisation international code of marketing of breast milk substitutes at the World Health Assembly in May 1981. The Australian Government has accordingly taken significant steps to give effect to the aim and principles of the code. It is certainly true that there is a great deal of concern that the code has been working better in some countries than in others. It is regrettable that some countries have not taken adequate steps to implement the provisions of the code.

ANSWER.PARA: The actions taken by the Australian Government include: the negotiation of an industry code of practice for the marketing of infant formulas; the development, through the Public Health Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council, of guidelines to promote breastfeeding; the incorporation of relevant clauses of the code into the model regulation food standard for infant formulas; and the incorporation, in 1985, of relevant clauses of the World Health Organisation code into dairy orders of the Export Control Act, to ensure that all products leaving Australia are appropriately labelled.

As well, Australia has drawn attention to the importance of promoting breastfeeding in Australia by highlighting the value of human milk in departmental nutrition programs, such as Dietary Guidelines of Australians-Baby's First Food. The Health for All Australians report identified among its goals and targets the need to increase the duration of breastfeeding. At present, the status of the World Health Organisation code in Australia is under further consideration by the Trade Practices Commission, with the object of ascertaining compliance with its regulations and ensuring that market place promotions are not interfering with the decisions of Australian women to breastfeed their infants.

Given that the last admitted payment to help Sir Peter Abeles restructure Ansett Airlines of Australia was for a period ending a month ago, will the Minister update the amount of money that the Government has not collected from both Ansett and Australian Airlines to compensate them for keeping on staff who would otherwise have been stood down? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As implied in the question, there are two components to the Government's compensation to the airlines. The first relates to direct payments, and up until 24 October some $3.8m had actually been paid. I am not sure until which date the contingent liability had been discharged with that $3.8m, nor do I have any actual figure beyond 24 October, although I believe that no payment has in fact been made since 24 October. I will get those completely up to date figures. The $30m figure that the Treasurer referred to, I think last week, includes revenue forgone as well as payments made. The revenue forgone-and I am not sure whether it is an exhaustive list-includes waiving charges for navigation and landing. There may be some others; I am not sure. ANSWER.PARA: On the outlays side of the Budget, I can tell Senator Stone that unless there is a massive deterioration in the level of services now provided, or unless the present level of services does not increase for the next 100 years or so, the payments from the Budget will not be anywhere near the $100m figure that has been thrown around by various propagandists from the Opposition, let alone the $200m figure that even more irresponsible or ill-informed people elsewhere have said. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I thank the Minister for his answer and in particular for his very clear distinction between the two forms of remuneration being made available to Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines, namely, the forgoing of revenue otherwise collectable from those airlines on the one hand and, on the other hand, the actual payments being made to them, I presume by way of some kind of top-up, to make up the total amounts of payments to the staff affected. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps there is something I should add to my previous answer on revenue forgone and that is that, whether landing charges or navigation charges were waived or not, there would be an automatic fall in revenue if the number of flights was to decline as, of course, inevitably happens when there is an industrial dispute. There would have less revenue because there would have been fewer flights. I am not sure what the breakup of that is.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the $700,000 figure that Senator Button mentioned on 5 October, I do not know whether he has been quoted correctly. I think the words `charges waived' were mentioned, but I do not know; I did not have Senator Button's minute; nor did I have a copy of the minute that had been supplied to him by the Department. Having said that, I do not know whether an actual payment was made and recorded as a Budget outlay or a receipt of revenue waived. There is no inconsistency between an actual payment as a Budget outlay of $700,000 on 5 October and the figure I have just given-that is, the actual payment as a Budget outlay up until 24 October of some $4m or, to be precise, $3.8m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the Australian Government's reaction to the dramatic events that are now taking place in Czechoslovakia and, in particular, the weekend's massive demonstration in Prague?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable senators would no doubt have read in press reports, the largest demonstrations since the 1968 uprising took place in Czechoslovakia over the weekend when a crowd estimated at about 10,000 people gathered in the main square of Prague calling for freedom and democracy. The demonstration was violently suppressed by the authorities and approximately 250 people were arrested. The demonstration took place several days after the Government once again arrested the noted author and leading dissident Vaclav Havel. Mr Jiri Hajek, the Foreign Minister in the Dubcek Prague Spring Government, as it is known, was also arrested.

ANSWER.PARA: The events in Czechoslovakia are taking place against the context of a general thawing out in east Europe where very much greater freedom of political expression is being allowed in the Soviet Union, Poland, Hungary and, most recently, the German Democratic Republic. The authorities in Czechoslovakia, by contrast, appear determined to ignore these winds of change and to maintain the repressive tactics of the past 20 years. The Australian Government believes that maintaining obedience through repression is simply untenable. The Australian Government calls on the Czechoslovak authorities, accordingly, to release their political prisoners, to permit the peaceful expression of opinion and to respect internationally recognised standards of human rights. Fundamentally, we and other countries are calling for the Government in Prague simply to take into account the wishes of its own people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories of several media reports over the past few weeks that he may be preparing to take steps to conserve the high conservation areas of the Cape York Peninsula. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had a number of requests to institute some sort of inquiry under section 11 of the legislation. At the time I received those requests, I said that I doubted very much whether the Commonwealth under that section had any effective power to have a proper inquiry. Over the last few weeks, I have had the opportunity to have that checked and I think my initial reaction was correct. Certainly, there is no Commonwealth decision to be made or any action to be taken by a Commonwealth authority on Cape York which would enable me to hold an inquiry into the whole of the area. It is the responsibility of Senator Button and I have advised him that there will need to be a full environmental impact study into that proposal and there certainly will be. But to go further and take in the whole area of Cape York would not meet with the cooperation of the current Queensland Government. Given that the Queensland Government holds most of the information that would be required to make an inquiry under that section, such inquiry would have no meaning and I see no point in even making the attempt. The reality is, though, that the Leader of the Opposition in Queensland-who, I sincerely hope, will be the Premier very shortly-has indicated that his new government will immediately cooperate with the Commonwealth in having a proper land use inquiry into the whole of Cape York. —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Given Senator Hill's inability, or unwillingness, to spell out on television yesterday the implications of the Opposition's foreign aid policy, can the Minister advise what the implications would be for Australia's standing, internationally and in the region, of a cut in next year's aid budget of the order of $100m?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those of us who have some residual capacity for compassion undoubtedly felt for Senator Hill yesterday when one watched his embarrassing attempt-I can only describe it as such-to justify what is a manifestly ill-considered and arbitrary approach by the Opposition to the management of the aid program. Having harangued the Government about declining aid levels, as he and the Opposition have been doing in the last few months, his approach-or that which has been forced upon him, to give him the benefit of the doubt-is simply to hack off another $100m from next year's aid budget. If that were to come off the present forward estimates, which one presumes is the assumption, the aid to gross national product ratio would fall from its present level of 0.33 per cent, which I readily acknowledge is embarrassingly low, to an extraordinary and indefensible level of 0.29 per cent. That is the immediate implication. Australia would slide right down the league table from its present position, which is just about right on the median in terms of international aid effort, to depths of the bottom one-third of international contributors to development assistance. Even worse than all of that, next year the effect on individual aid items would be dramatically greater because, in addition to any overall cut of the kind that is being contemplated, next financial year the aid program will have to bear additional commitments to international financial institutions of some $100m.

—I do not know whether Senator Hill is aware of that; he is certainly not while he is shouting. Those commitments are already in the pipeline. The combined effect of a cut of $100m from the overall program, which has been contemplated, plus the extra $100m of commitments to international financial institutions, which are already in the pipeline, would mean that other areas of the aid program such as support for other multilateral institutions such as the United Nations, support for bilateral programs and support for cross programs such as the equity and merit scholarship scheme, would have to absorb cuts in funding of around $200m. I do not know whether the Opposition is aware of the combined impact of its proposal, but that is what is involved-cuts of around $200m to next year's aid program if it seeks net cuts from the Commonwealth's financial commitment of $100m.

ANSWER.PARA: What would cuts of that kind look like? It depends on how one constructs these things-whether one adopts an approach which cuts out whole programs and leaves others intact or whether one adopts an across-the-board reduction in commitments to existing programs. A realistic package to meet a problem of that order of magnitude would involve something like this: a withdrawal or a very severe reduction of aid programs to southern Africa, for which the Government has a present commitment of $110m over the next three years. It would mean that the new India and Pakistan programs either would not be able to be proceeded with at all or would be under such severe funding pressure as to be barely worth proceeding with. It would mean that commitments that have been made to Thailand and Laos in relation to the Mekong Bridge, which is the most visible single aid project that we have in South East Asia at the moment, would simply not be able to be met. It would mean that commitments to the Philippines aid plan probably would not be able to be met, depending on how their timing is spread out. Certainly it would mean that there would be no capacity for any new Indo-China initiatives, should it become appropriate to initiate them over the next year or two, as we all hope it will be. It would mean dramatic damage to our relationship with Malaysia through a sharp phasing down of the brand new, recently announced bilateral aid program and, in particular, cuts to the equity and merit scholarship scheme, which is particularly focused on Malaysia. It would mean a severe reduction of aid activities in support of our international position on refugees, atomic energy, the environment and the acquired immune deficiency syndrome. In the context of the South Pacific, it would mean that aid to states in the South Pacific could at best probably be maintained only in nominal terms. Our capacity to maintain levels of aid to Papua New Guinea--

TALK.START.PARA: —We will have to ask Papua New Guinea for some of our money back.

—I thank Senator Lewis. As I was saying, our capacity to maintain those levels could come under very severe pressure and certainly make absolutely impossible any increase in aid to Papua New Guinea should its circumstances become more straitened as a result of present developments.

ANSWER.PARA: However, among all the gems in the contribution that has been made to our appreciation of the aid program was that uttered by Senator Hill yesterday when he said, among other things, that he did not want to do anything that might threaten Australia's exports. Yet that part of the aid program which is most clearly and directly tied to exports, the development import finance facility (DIFF) program, is, under the scheme that has been announced so far-and, of course, it might be changed-expected to bear fully one-half of the Opposition's $100m swipe at the aid program. The Opposition is talking about $50m coming off DIFF that could be expected to generate between, of course, around $150m and $200m in Australian exports. With just a little homework, Senator Hill would have discovered that a $50m cut to DIFF would effectively suspend that scheme for a full two years-probably more than that. It would obviously kill new market opportunities and any follow-on business that might have resulted from that initial expenditure. It will cruel jobs and manufacturing capacity right here in Australia. That is not just a matter of reducing expectations about possible levels of support in the future. What Senator Hill is talking about is actual committed programs-investment that is already in the pipeline-being totally thrown away as a result of that kind of arbitrary cut.

I could go on for much longer than this, but I am not prepared to waste any more of the Senate's time in addressing what is such an ill-conceived, ill-thought-out excuse for a policy document. It lacks both compassion and understanding, it lacks commonsense and, certainly it lacks any understanding of the economic impact which Senator Hill and the rest of his team opposite seem most anxious to parade their credentials about. It lacks any sort of capacity to understand the economic impact of the measures that are being proposed.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HUMAN RIGHTS AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Justice give a report on recent activities of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission? In particular, can he give the Senate the number and type of complaints brought under the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 and the Racial Discrimination Act 1975? To what extent is conciliation of complaints successful in combating such discrimination? Are these figures justification for the continuation of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —According to information supplied to me by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission for 1988-89, 221 complaints were lodged under the Racial Discrimination Act and 496 complaints were lodged under the Sex Discrimination Act. That number of complaints indicates that there is a very real role for the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission here in Australia in those two areas alone. Unfortunately, those statistics do not include complaints lodged in Victoria as that data is not yet available. Nevertheless, one can say that there has been an overall increase of 11 per cent in the number of complaints received by the Commission since the previous year. That increasing workload indicates an increased awareness in the community of the fact that discrimination, particularly on the grounds of sex or race, is quite unacceptable in our society. People are emboldened to do something to combat discrimination that they suffer by making complaints to the Commission.

ANSWER.PARA: That change in the attitude of people whereby they are prepared to take on somebody who discriminates against them in that unacceptable way is very largely due to the fact that they have confidence in the public profile that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has developed over the last several years. There have been programs of education and community outreach which have helped change and which respond to the sort of community which we wish to be as a civilised Australian community, living together in tolerant and peaceful harmony.

The conciliation process used by the Commission has been extremely successful with an overall figure of some 97 per cent of complaints being settled without referral for a formal hearing. The speeches read as follows-
HAZARDOUS WASTE (REGULATION OF EXPORTS AND IMPORTS BILL 1989

The purpose of this Bill is to control the export and import of hazardous wastes in order to protect human health and the environment. The Act will enable Australia to take part in international measures to control the movement of hazardous wastes which also have this objective.

With the development of modern industry has come the generation of hazardous industrial and chemical wastes. These are wastes that cannot be disposed of in municipal landfill or to the sewer, but need to be recorded and tracked to special treatment and disposal facilities. In the last two decades it has become recognised in every industrial country that special regulation is needed for these materials.

Consequently, in industrialised countries such special regulation has been put in place, to protect the environment. In Australia, regulation of hazardous wastes is primarily a State and Territory responsibility and they administer appropriate controls.

In this area of regulation, in Australia and overseas, the term hazardous wastes does not include radioactive wastes, which have separate regulatory needs. In this country the import and export of radioactive materials are controlled under the Customs Act.

It became clear as national control systems were developed, that gaps existed at national borders. Well publicised incidents, such as drums of waste being `lost' at European borders, or wastes being dumped in African ports, led to the conclusion that an international control system was necessary, to protect the global environment.

This was recognised by the then House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation, which recommended in its 1982 First Report on the Inquiry into Hazardous Chemicals that Australia should control the export and import of these materials. Subsequently the Australian Environmental Council endorsed Commonwealth control on exports and imports of hazardous wastes.
I should add that there is no evidence that Australia has been involved in unacceptable movement of these materials.

The international body which acted first in this area was the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD). In 1984 it began developing international agreements to control hazardous wastes when moved, to ensure their satisfactory disposal. However, it became clear that a global agreement was necessary, and in 1987 the initiative was taken by the United Nations' Environmental Programme (UNEP). In the light of these developments, the Government decided in March 1988 to control this trade, in order, amongst other things, to take part in international control arrangements.

On 22 March 1989, at a UNEP conference held in Switzerland, `The Basel Convention on the Control of Transboundary Movements of Hazardous Wastes and Their Disposal' was unanimously adopted by all governments represented. Australia was active in drawing up the Convention. Australia can become a Party to the Convention once this legislation has been put into effect. Before becoming a Party the Commonwealth will consult with the States and Territories.
Fundamental features of the Basel Convention include:
the requirement that Parties shall prohibit the export of hazardous wastes from their jurisdictions to States that do not consent to the import;
the requirement that countries treating and disposing of wastes do so in an environmentally sound manner; and
the tracking of wastes to acceptable disposal, when moved across borders.

In essence the Bill before us provides for the issuing of permits to control both the import and export of hazardous wastes to ensure that they are disposed of by an environmentally acceptable method. The legislation has been designed to control the movements of wastes as required by the Convention. However, several of the obligations in the Convention, such as the requirement to minimise waste production and the provision of acceptable disposal facilities, fall within the responsibilities of State and Territory Governments. Therefore the controls introduced by this Bill will be complemented by State and Territory waste management legislation.

At present, a few hundred tonnes of hazardous waste are exported from Australia each year. These wastes fall into the category of intractable wastes for which the only widely acknowledged environmentally acceptable method for disposal is high temperature incineration.

The majority of those wastes that have been exported have been sent to Pontypool in the United Kingdom for destruction in a high temperature incinerator. As far as is known no hazardous wastes have been imported into Australia.

As I mentioned, hazardous wastes are generally defined as those wastes that cannot be disposed of in the usual way such as to municipal landfill or the sewer. They present a potential threat to the environment or human health and therefore require special treatment.

However, in addition to what are usually considered to be hazardous wastes, the Basel Convention also controls the movement and disposal of wastes collected from households and residues arising from the incineration of household wastes. Accordingly, the definition of hazardous wastes in the Bill has been expanded to include these categories of wastes.

The Bill provides that the Minister must only issue a permit for the export of wastes if he or she is satisfied, amongst other things, that the hazardous waste will be permitted to enter the proposed country of import and that any exported waste will be disposed of in the receiving country in a manner that will not be harmful to the environment.

It will be necessary for the applicant for either an import or export permit to demonstrate that he or she has adequate insurance or is able to meet any liability arising in relation to the activity proposed.

Other matters that the Minister may take into account when considering an export application are whether there are facilities for disposal of wastes in Australia which could be used for the disposal of the exports.

This ground could be used to make more viable Australian treatment facilities-it is also consistent with the Basel Convention, which seeks to minimise movements whenever possible. The Minister may also take into account Australia's international relations, when considering issuing permits. Other clauses in the Bill provide for the Minister to vary, extend and revoke permits, with appropriate safeguards for applicants. Particulars of permits are to be published in the Gazette, unless there are national interest reasons not to do so.

Under the Bill, the Minister may make orders to deal with the wastes and recover costs, if the orders are not complied with. This power will include the power to order wastes illegally imported to Australia to be returned to the country of origin. This is consistent with the Basel Convention.

Principal offences under this Bill will be punishable by up to five years imprisonment. Enforcement of the Act will be by inspectors with appropriate powers. The Bill provides for appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, against the Minister's decisions whether such decisions are to grant or not to grant a permit, to vary or not to vary a permit, or other decisions relating to permits. Third parties with an interest may appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The Bill provides for amendment of the Customs Act, to ensure that where hazardous wastes are the subject of illegal movement under the proposed Act, they are not thus forfeit to the Crown. Hazardous wastes have a negative value, that is, ownership of them is a liability. Therefore a person should not be able to get rid of them simply by illegally importing or exporting them and then forfeiting them to the Crown.
There is provision for fees of up to $4000 to be paid by permit applicants. It is intended that these will cover the costs of administering the Act.

The States and Territories have been consulted during the drafting of the Bill. Their cooperation will be needed in the administration of the Act through, for example, informing the Commonwealth authorities of suspected illegal import or export activities. Memoranda of understanding will be developed with them for this purpose.

The Government is committed to ensuring that hazardous wastes in Australia are managed in an environmentally acceptable manner. The introduction of controls on the import and export of hazardous wastes complements the domestic regulation of these materials which the Commonwealth is helping to implement through the Australia and New Zealand Environment Council (formerly the Australian Environment Council to which I referred earlier).

The Commonwealth, in concert with the States and Territories is encouraging industry to minimise its production of hazardous wastes. Many companies are now finding that waste minimisation is in fact cost effective in terms of the valuable materials that can be recovered from the so called `waste' stream.

This Government, together with the New South Wales and Victorian State Governments, is examining the possibility of establishing a facility for the high temperature incineration of intractable wastes in New South Wales. The incinerator is proposed as a national facility but, if established, it will be operated by a New South Wales Government agency. Setting up such a facility would reduce the current need to store or export intractable wastes.

Australia has as its near neighbours many small nations, such as the Pacific countries, which may well have relatively small quantities of hazardous wastes which they wish to dispose of safely. Australia has a responsibility to assist these countries to dispose of their wastes in an environmentally acceptable manner. It is inconceivable that these nations could justify the building of a high temperature incinerator given the small amount of wastes that would need to be incinerated.
Accordingly, if the wastes are to be disposed of safely in our region it may be necessary to import those wastes into Australia for incineration.

Through the adoption of the measures contained in the Bill Australia will be in a position to control the movement of hazardous wastes into and out of Australia and to require that these wastes are only treated and disposed of using methods of the highest standard. In this way we can demonstrate to the rest of the world our commitment to the protection of the global environment.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.
INDUSTRIAL CHEMICALS (NOTIFICATION AND ASSESSMENT) BILL 1989

The purpose of this Bill is to establish a national scheme for the notification and assessment of industrial chemicals to protect people at work, the public and the environment from the harmful effects of industrial chemicals. The scheme will be known as the National Industrial Chemicals Notification and Assessment Scheme-NICNAS.

This scheme will form a vital component in an overall chemicals management strategy for Australia. Notification and assessment of chemicals will improve the efficiency of other elements of this overall strategy such as labelling, provision of material safety data sheets and education and training.

The Bill reflects the continuing priority that the Federal Government gives to ensuring safe Australian workplaces and a cleaner environment. Worksafe Australia and the Australian and New Zealand Environment Council, whose 1984 proposal was the basis for this legislation, have conducted consultations with Commonwealth Departments, State and Territory Authorities, Unions and Industry and other interested groups to ensure that the proposed scheme will take into account and achieve a fair balance between the interests of these parties.

The legislation is to apply to industrial chemicals imported into or manufactured in Australia. It will apply to the individual chemical substances, but not mixtures or formulations. Because it is not possible to determine the hazards of a formulation unless the properties of the ingredients are known, this scheme will also provide the fundamental information with which formulations can be assessed.

This legislation will not place controls on chemicals. This will necessarily be through the existing body of State and Territory legislation. The legislation will, however, promote the development of uniform controls by ensuring that adequate, independently reviewed information is available to State and Territory authorities, and by making recommendations about appropriate controls for national adoption.

Industrial chemicals are used in virtually every commodity, including textiles, paints, plastics, adhesives and cleaners, and are an integral part of modern life. Over the past several decades the number of industrial chemicals introduced by industry has increased dramatically. It has been estimated that worldwide, there are in excess of 100,000 individual industrial chemicals in commercial use. Over 30,000 of these are used in Australia and found in a bewildering number of chemical products.

This legislation is long overdue. Unlike therapeutic drugs and agricultural and veterinary chemicals, industrial chemicals are, and have been, introduced into Australian workplaces and the environment without any national assessment of their hazards. This is in stark contrast to the majority of our trading partners who have had similar legislation in place for a number of years. This legislation will ensure that new industrial chemicals are evaluated before they enter the Australian market, and that selected chemicals already in use are reviewed.

Control over industrial chemicals is currently exercised by the States and Territories through many and various pieces of legislation, covering, for example, the transport and storage of dangerous goods, occupational health and safety, consumer protection and environmental protection.

To date, standards and controls for chemicals have largely been developed on a piecemeal basis by individual States and Territories, often only in response to damage to health or environmental pollution. Differences in approach between States and Territories have led to a lack of uniformity in requirements and controls. This situation results in significant, unnecessary costs for industry, as well as increased hazard to the public and the environment.

Honourable senators will be aware of the enormous cost of rectifying the damage done by chemicals such as mercury, PCBs and asbestos. Hardly a day goes by without an incident being reported involving hazardous chemicals, whether it is a chemical fire in Melbourne or pollution of a historic waterway in Sydney. Such incidents have led to international recognition of the need to anticipate potential hazards of chemicals prior to their entry into commerce.

Based on extrapolation of overseas data, the cost of occupational injury and disease from exposure to chemicals can be expected to be very high. As a consequence, even modest reductions will have major benefits in monetary and human terms. For example the United Kingdom Health and Safety Executive has recently estimated that seven million working days are lost each year in the United Kingdom due to skin problems, at a cost of $A1.3 billion. Occupational dermatitis resulting from chemical exposure makes up the ``large majority'' of these skin problems.
The public is exposed to industrial chemicals directly through use of consumer products and indirectly by the presence of these chemicals in the environment through pollution.

Contamination resulting from release of industrial chemicals to the environment has many negative effects apart from those to human health. Pollution of waterways leads to loss of environmental amenity, for example, swimming or recreational fishing, and also economic loss, for example to commercial fishing industries. Accumulation of chemicals in animals, particularly those at the top of food chains, can threaten individuals and, on occasions, place entire species at risk.

The exaggerated fear of chemicals, has in recent years become a source of considerable cost and delay to both industry and Government. Such fears can result in industrial action against changes in workplace processes using chemicals and adverse community reaction to proposals for new chemical plants, waste disposal and destruction facilities. A persistent complaint of workers, environmental groups and the general public is the lack or inadequacy of chemicals information.

Clearly a mechanism is required in Australia to ensure that sufficient data is provided for new chemicals to permit the adequate assessment of their potential health and environmental hazards. In this way the safeguards recommended will properly reflect both the potential exposure to the chemical and its physical, chemical and toxicological properties. Such a mechanism should not, however, impose unnecessary time or cost burdens on industry.

The establishment of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission, otherwise known as Worksafe Australia, in 1985 was early evidence of the Government's commitment to occupational health and safety. The scheme will be administered by Worksafe Australia.

Turning to the details of the legislation, Part 2 of the Bill refers to the Australian Inventory of Chemical Substances. This central feature of the legislation is currently being compiled by the Department of the Arts, Sports, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. The inventory will list those industrial chemicals which are already in use in Australia and which therefore will not be regarded as ``new'' under this legislation.

Chemicals listed in this inventory, and certain other chemicals, will be exempted from the requirements for new chemicals. These may be reviewed if they give rise to concern. New chemicals which are notified and assessed under the scheme will not be added to the inventory for a period of five years after the assessment has been completed. This will prevent others who wish to introduce the chemical from unfairly profiting from the work of the original applicant in satisfying the requirements of the legislation.

Part 3 of the Bill describes the process of notification and assessment of industrial chemicals. New chemicals will be notified to Worksafe Australia together with a notification statement of the chemical's intended use and properties. The cost of providing this information will be borne by the importer or manufacturer. The information will be assessed to determine the potential hazard to occupational health and safety, public health and the environment. The information required is similar to the O.E.C.D. minimum premarketing set of data, which has been agreed internationally as that necessary for an initial hazard assessment of new industrial chemicals.

There are provisions in the legislation to provide a lesser information package if it is justified on scientific or economic grounds. For example, in the case of polymers, small volume chemicals, research and development chemicals and site limited chemicals it is recognised that parts of the prescribed minimum data set may not be appropriate. These classes of chemicals are therefore subject to special consideration.
For chemicals which have been in use overseas and are on overseas inventories this Bill provides discretion to allow an incomplete notification statement.

On the other hand, in a small minority of cases, data beyond the prescribed minimum level may be required; for example, chemicals for which there is widespread human or environmental exposure or those chemicals for which the basic data package foreshadows a need for further information.

To ensure that occupational health and safety, public health and environmental health hazards are considered, assessments will be undertaken jointly by Worksafe Australia, the Department of Community Services and Health and the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories respectively. For each chemical, the information package, including the material safety data sheet, will be reviewed to determine appropriate recommendations for the safe use of the chemical. A consolidated assessment report will be prepared within prescribed time frames by Worksafe Australia and distributed to responsible Commonwealth, State and Territory authorities.

As it is sometimes necessary to review assessments to ensure that the original one remains valid, the Bill provides a mechanism for secondary notification. For instance, secondary notifications may be required for chemicals if they are used in a wider variety of applications than originally intended or if new information about their properties becomes available.

Several important provisions exist for the estimated 30,000 existing chemicals, which are listed on the Inventory. These provisions allow the Federal Government to tackle, on a priority basis, those chemicals for which there are particular Australian concerns. In some cases, classes of chemicals which are related either by chemical structure or by their use or function may be declared as priority existing chemicals.

In selecting existing chemicals for review, maximum use will be made of international collaborative efforts such as the O.E.C.D. Chemicals Program and the United Nations International Program on Chemical Safety.

There will be no prescribed information requirements for the assessment of existing chemicals. Instead an initial request for information will be made to assist in defining the extent of the problem. Information requirements will generally be directed to the specific concerns which prompted the review. Where only one aspect of a chemical is of concern, for example, environmental damage, information requirements and assessment may be limited to that aspect.

One important outcome of this scheme is the information on chemicals that will become available to the public. A summary of each assessment report will be published in a special issue of the Commonwealth Gazette and the full public assessment report will be available on request.

Confidentiality of information will be maintained when this is necessary to safeguard commercial interests. However, there will be a prescribed set of basic information, including summaries of health and environmental effects, which cannot be confidential.

The appeal provisions in the Bill are drawn widely. Industry and third parties will be able to appeal decisions made under the legislation to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. For example, appeals may be made against the content and recommendations of an assessment report on the selection of priority existing chemicals.
The openness of the scheme, as evidenced by availability of information and by the wide appeal provisions, is unique, and is to be commended.

The Bill includes a number of offences. It also sets out the levels of fines to apply to a natural person and to a corporation. Consistent with standard practice, the maximum fine for a corporation is five times that for a natural person.

The detailed implementation of controls and their enforcement will be the subject of memoranda of understanding to be developed between the Commonwealth and the States and Territories. Proposals for regulating hazardous substances at the State and Territory level are being developed to be consistent with this legislation. For this reason there are provisions in the Bill to declare equivalent State and Territory schemes.
Financial Impact Statement

The costs of implementing this legislation are estimated to be $1.25 million after 50% cost recovery. Cost recovery is consistent with the practice established in August 1987 for the review of agricultural chemicals and veterinary drugs. Fees will be specified by regulation.

The legislation has been developed to achieve its objectives at the minimum possible cost and includes significant provisions to allow flexibility in application to minimise impact on industry. Information required for both new and existing chemicals is limited to that necessary to perform an adequate hazard assessment of the chemical. The inclusion of statutory time-frames for assessment will ensure that hazards will be promptly reviewed and delays and uncertainties for industry minimised.

Harmonisation of the scheme with those in operation in most O.E.C.D. countries, and adoption of agreements on such matters as chemical test methods, good laboratory practice and mutual acceptance of data, allows a system of notification of new chemicals which does not duplicate equivalent testing and assessment processes carried out by other countries.

The provisions of the Bill specifically make maximum use of overseas assessments resulting in reduction of costs. Where the chemical has been notified and assessed under a recognised equivalent scheme of another country, that notification and assessment will suffice providing it is accessible and relevant to Australia. On the other hand, there may be occasions where additional tests are required because of unique Australian circumstances. The Bill allows for such occasions.

It is not suggested that the proposed legislation will, in itself, solve all the problems associated with hazardous chemicals and the considerable costs that flow from these. However, even small percentage reductions in the damage caused by chemicals represent very substantial benefits to Australia. The Bill, operating in conjunction with other mechanisms such as requirements for material safety data sheets will maximise these benefits.

It is the Government's intention that the commitment of industry and trade unions to the scheme be maintained and their involvement continued. To this end, an advisory committee will be established within the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission.

In addition, a co-ordinating committee will be established external to the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission to deal with issues of common concern to interested departments, and to provide advice to the Government on the development and operation of the scheme after its inception.

Major effects of the scheme will be evident in the areas of, occupational health and safety and protection of the environment. Overall, we believe that real benefits will follow because the legislation will:
encourage uniformity of regulation by the States and Territories;
require those introducing chemicals to `know their products', to be aware of the chemical's identity and properties; and
increase rational debate in the community on chemicals issues.

Honourable Senators, this Bill provides another strong indication, of the Government's desire to ensure that significant occupational health and environmental issues confronting society are managed effectively and safely. Chemicals are an essential part of our society and require responsible management by manufacturers and importers, workers and consumers as well as by Government. The provisions of this Bill show that the Government is addressing this important area. I believe this Bill represents an important step in the management of an extremely complex issue.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Tambling) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: JUDICIAL AND STATUTORY OFFICERS REMUNERATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Button) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The purpose of this Bill is to implement increases in remuneration for members of the Federal judiciary and certain statutory office holders.

The Remuneration Tribunal in its 1988 review recommended increases in judges' salaries of up to 80 per cent. Whilst these proposals discharged the Tribunal's statutory obligations, the Government was unable to accept that level of increase at a time when continued community-wide restraint in wage fixation was necessary.

The Government considered that a balance should be found between the need for restraint and the interests of the administration of justice through the maintenance of a proper standard of judicial appointments.

The Minister for Industrial Relations therefore asked the members of the Remuneration Tribunal to provide further advice on appropriate remuneration for the Federal judiciary in the current wage fixing context.

The members of the Tribunal presented their special report to the Minister on 30 June. In that report, the Tribunal members found that within the terms of the national wage principles at that time, there was an inequity between Federal and State court judges.

They concluded that the duties and responsibilities of the Federal Court warranted remuneration no less than that of the members of the Supreme Court of Queensland, who at the time of their report were the highest paid of the State Supreme Courts receiving a level of remuneration 16 per cent greater than that of their Federal Court colleagues.

The report also proposed that expenses of office allowance be absorbed into salaries and that judicial remuneration be adjusted in accordance with the August 1988 national wage case decision which granted increases of 3 per cent and $10 per week.

The Bill implements these recommendations by amending the Judicial and Statutory Officers' (Remuneration and Allowances) Act 1984. The Government has also decided to legislate to equate the remuneration of members of the Family Court with that of the judiciary of the Federal Court. There is no longer any justification for members of the Family Court to be paid less than their Federal Court colleagues, especially as the Federal Court is now able to refer certain matters to the Family Court.

Consistent with the report's recommendations, these changes in remuneration will operate from 1 March 1989. Travelling allowances are also to be adjusted from 1 March 1989 in accordance with the rates recommended in the Tribunal's 1988 review.
The Minister for Industrial Relations has foreshadowed that a further examination of judicial remuneration will be undertaken in the light of the recent decision from the national wage case bench.

The appropriateness of the relativities of remuneration between Federal Court judges and a number of statutory officer-holders will also be assessed. The linkage of two of these offices is to be removed pending the review of the relativities. These are the offices of Master of the Supreme Court and Judicial Registrar of the Family Court. However, the current levels of remuneration will be adjusted in accordance with the increases arising from the August 1988 National Wage decision.
The removal of these direct linkages at this time, should not be seen to prejudice in any way, the future re-establishment of linkages for these offices, should it be considered appropriate to do so.

The Bill also empowers the Tribunal in the future to make determinations, rather than recommendations, in respect of the office of judge and offices of judicial status. The Tribunal currently has this power in relation to virtually all other offices within its jurisdiction. As is the case for these other offices, determinations will be subject to disallowance by either House of the Parliament.
The cost of implementing the Bill will be of the order of $3.7m in 1989-90.
Further information on the Bill is contained in the explanatory memorandum, which I now present and which has been circulated to honourable senators. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Button) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the revised explanatory memorandum and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill would amend social security and veterans' affairs legislation to implement some of the measures announced in the Budget this year and several other program refinements of a mainly administrative nature. It also contains measures to enhance the effectiveness of the child support scheme.
Over the last six years the Government has rebuilt the integrity of Australia's social security system. We have substantially amended legislation to support an overhaul of administrative systems.

This Bill would amend the Social Security Act to continue this reform. Compensation recovery mechanisms will be made much more effective, family allowance and family allowance supplement procedures will be refined, assessment of domestic circumstances of sole parent pensioners will be overhauled, deferment periods for education leavers applying for benefits will be adjusted and unemployment and sickness benefits will not be payable to people who refuse to provide or apply for a tax file number.

Three amendments in the area of compensation recovery promote the administrative integrity of the social security system and help to ensure that the funds made available by the Australian public for social security go to those who most need them.

Under present arrangements which apply where compensation payments and social security benefits overlap, the Department of Social Security tries to recover any money from the employer or the insurer. However, some employers and insurers pay out compensation before recovery is made even though they may have been alerted by the Department. This Bill makes it possible for the Department to take recovery action against employers or insurers to redress this situation.
The Bill tightens the Department's recovery powers to ensure that State compensation bodies participate in proper recovery arrangements.
This Bill also provides that any outstanding money still owed to the Department once a client has been paid compensation may be recovered from his or her continuing social security entitlement.
Sole parent pensions are payable to people caring for children who are not married nor living in a de facto relationship and to people caring for children whose spouse is in prison.
It is paid because of the very special hardships and disadvantages caused by bringing up children alone.

The administration of sole parent pension requires assessment of the domestic circumstances of some claimants and pensioners-to determine whether they are unmarried and not living in a de facto relationship.

That aspect of administration has been most unsatisfactory-for clients and staff of the Department. Without any clear legislative provisions, staff have been left to administer a program without clear rules and with no clear procedures. The results have necessarily been intensive investigations and arbitrary decision making.

This Bill would specify clearly the process for decision making in these cases. It would enable the Department to require sole parent pensioners and claimants for pension who are living in a de facto or marriage relationship to fully disclose their domestic circumstances to the Department.

It would provide that, where this is done, the Department must weigh the evidence with a clear list of relevant indicia set out in the legislation and make a decision whether the person is, or is not, entitled to pension. The legislation would provide that, in the rare case when a decision maker is unable to come to a clear conclusion one way or the other, pension should cease-subject to continuation of pension pending resolution of any appeal to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal.

The legislation would also provide that, when a pensioner or claimant has fully and honestly disclosed his or her domestic circumstances to the Department and it has been decided that he or she is entitled to pension, there should be no further investigation of the domestic circumstances of that person for 12 weeks-unless there is a significant change of circumstances. In this way, the Bill would guarantee a decision making process which recognises the complexity of many cases in this area: and protects clients and staff from the indignity and arbitrariness of current arrangements.

The legislation would also specify-for the first time-matters which decision makers must take into account in determining marital status issues for all purposes under the Social Security Act. This would lead to more structured, more consistent interviewing and decision making on these issues across all pensions, benefits and allowances.

The Bill refines provisions relating to family allowance supplement (FAS) when family income has fallen. These amendments flow from practical experience with the FAS program. Under current arrangements, families may qualify for FAS if their taxable income for the financial year ending in the previous calendar year is below certain levels. If the family's previous taxable income was higher than these levels, but their income has dropped so that taxable income in the current financial year will be at least 25 per cent less, the family can qualify for FAS on the basis of their current financial year's income.
From December 1989, FAS will be payable even if the drop in income is less than 25 per cent as long as total income is expected to be below the FAS income threshold.

To preserve the effect of this amendment into the next entitlement year, families will retain their new, higher entitlement if this would make them better off than under a normal assessment based on their income for the previous financial year.

The Bill would provide for reassessments of FAS following amended assessments by the Australian Taxation Office of taxable income for the year which is the basis of a FAS entitlement. Under the provisions in the Bill, a downwards reassessment of taxable income would trigger FAS arrears for the client. With an upwards reassessment, an overpayment and reduction in FAS rate would occur only if the reassessment was more than 25 per cent higher.

Another amendment ensures that low income parents who are full-time students receiving Austudy or a similar payment will not be excluded from entitlement to FAS through the operation of the income test. FAS will now be payable to these people at the maximum rate subject to the assets test.

From January 1990, the family allowance provisions will be changed to require recipients to inform the Department of certain notifiable events which occur during the calendar year. Events such as the allowee starting a new job or getting married are likely to generate an increase in income and, therefore, might affect the family allowance rate payable. Prescribing notifiable events in this way puts the family allowance system on a similar footing to FAS.

A refinement is also being made to the FAS notifiable events arrangements. Currently, FAS can be reassessed where a family's income increases following a notifiable event but only if the event occurred after FAS had been granted. It will now be possible to take into account a notifiable event occurring before grant to arrive at a fair and accurate entitlement.

This Bill includes a number of refinements to the unemployment benefit system to strengthen its principles of providing support to people when they need it, providing opportunities and incentives to unemployed people to get back to work and, in return for the community's support, requiring recipients to utilise the opportunities available to them.

In order to encourage school leavers who become unemployed to commence job search immediately, the four-week period of grace for education leavers to register with the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) after leaving study will be abolished from October 1989. This means that the standard 13 week deferment period which applies to all education leavers would run from the date of CES registration as long as a claim for benefit was lodged within two weeks of that date. The Bill stresses the importance of job search by providing that, when a young person registers with the CES before finishing school, that registration would date from the last day of school for benefit purposes.

The requirements for payment of unemployment benefit and job search allowance include the need for the client to be actively seeking suitable work. It is often difficult to assess this when that person moves to an area where there are low employment prospects. At present, once a person has moved to such an area, it is usually sufficient for benefit purposes if he or she can demonstrate satisfactory attempts to find work in that area. The Bill turns this situation around in cases where there are no good reasons for making such a move.

In future, a recipient of unemployment benefit or job search allowance who moves address and reduces his or her employment prospects as a result will have his or her benefit cancelled and, on reapplication, will have to serve a waiting period of 12 weeks. This rule will not apply when the move is to live with or near a family member of the beneficiary.

The Bill would provide for unemployment and sickness benefit to not be payable when the beneficiary does not provide, and will not apply for, a tax file number. At present, unemployment and sickness beneficiaries who fail to supply their tax file number are taxed at the top marginal rate of 50.25 per cent including the Medicare levy. As from November 1989, benefit will not be payable if claimants do not either supply a tax file number or agree to request one from the Australian Taxation Office. Any current beneficiaries who have not supplied a number by the date of effect or who are not prepared to request a tax file number will forfeit their benefit.

Lastly, this Bill incorporates minor amendments to strengthen the child support scheme. The special maintenance income concession for pensioners and beneficiaries who are eligible to apply for administratively assessed child support under stage 2 would only be available if an application is made to maximise recurrent cash entitlements under child support assessment legislation. The Child Support (Assessment) Act would ensure that child support agreements, instruments and orders are exempt from State and Territory stamp duties.

The Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act would be amended to ensure automatic withholding from salary or wages can be effectively and speedily applied in every case when a non-custodial parent defaults-regardless of the date of the order giving rise to the liability. It would also be made clear that automatic withholding can be used by the Child Support Agency to collect arrears of maintenance owing to it.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
