Again, welfare rights groups around Australia-the Women's Electoral Lobby, the Council for Single Mothers and their Children Inc, the Rural Low Income Network-Victoria, the Social Security Advice Service in Geelong, the Good Shepherd Youth Family Service and the Australian Financial Counselling and Credit Reform Association-have reflected their concerns about this particular proposal, which appears to be ignoring the needs of sole parents in seeking out shared accommodation and the ways in which the needs of sole parents in our community have not been taken into consideration.

Similar concerns have been expressed by the Federation of Community Legal Centres, Parents without Partners, the National Union of Sole Parents and, as I said, councils of social service around Australia, and also the Women's Refuge Movement, which is concerned that many women's choices may be limited by this proposal as it stands and even as amended in the House of Representatives and that, for financial reasons and for personal support reasons, women may in fact be less able to move out of potentially violent domestic circumstances. Even the Melbourne Age of Saturday, 14 October, supported a call for this whole very delicate question to be seriously looked at by a committee.

Indeed, the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has expressed some concerns. Although that Committee often expresses concerns about legislation, and those concerns are addressed by Ministers and accepted or not accepted by the Senate, I would like to point to what those concerns are because, if we are going to believe that it is significantly important to suspend Standing Orders in order to make this reference, I think we should have some idea of the concerns outside the community sector and in our own Scrutiny of Bills Committee. In Alert Digest No. 14 of 1989, which was published last week, the powers of the secretary are queried in that the legislation allows the representatives of the secretary, that is, the Department of Social Security officials in departmental offices around the country, `wide-ranging enquiries into the private lives of pensioners or beneficiaries who reside under the same roof but claim to be living separately'. The Committee notes provisions under certain paragraphs of the legislation, which we believe should be sent to a standing committee for perusal, that place a requirement on the relevant secretary-that is, a representative of the secretary in the Department office. It is stated:

when forming an opinion that two people are living together in a marriage-like relationship, or for the purpose of defining `de factor spouse' or `married person' to have regard to all the circumstances of the relationship including any sexual relationship between them.
The Committee goes on to say that it is concerned that the provisions may excessively intrude into personal privacy, and that the Minister's opinion has been sought on this point as well.

Subclause 28 (6) of the legislation is causing a great deal of concern, not least to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. It is a subclause that I do commend to all members of the Senate and, indeed, to any member of the general public who can get hold of it as perhaps the most difficult piece of gobbledegook that I have seen in a long time, from a government which, in the past, has committed itself to framing legislation in a way which makes it accessible to people in the community. I remind the Senate that this is social security legislation. Therefore, surely our goal should be to make it accessible and understandable to social security recipients, among them some of the most disadvantaged people in our community.

Subclause 28 (6) has three negatives. I hesitate to read it to the Senate but, if nothing else, it will move this chamber to believe that this is an urgent matter: it really should be persuaded by this subclause. It is not worth the time of the Senate to be debating the substance of something which is so difficult to understand. A number of legally trained people, with whom I have been in communication in the last few weeks, are still having trouble. I find no instruction in reading the explanatory memorandum, the second reading speech of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) or indeed the Hansard record of the House of Representatives debate, which did not mention this at all. Subclause 28 (6) of the Bill reads:

``(6) The Secretary must not form the opinion that the pensioner or claimant is not living with the other person in a marriage-like relationship unless, having regard to all of the matters specified in the paragraphs of section 3a, the weight of evidence supports the formation of an opinion that the pensioner or claimant is not living in a marriage-like relationship with the other person.

The Scrutiny of Bills Committee has expressed concern about this clause. It has said that in its opinion it is difficult to comprehend and the Minister has been asked to comment on that. Finally on this clause, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has expressed concern that it appears that there is some question about the rights of review for claimants because within these provisions it is possible for a claimant to be deemed not to have made a claim. Clarification has been sought on that. As I said, I know that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee often expresses concern, often writes to Ministers asking questions, and then waits for the answers, as does the Senate, but these are among the very concerns expressed out in the community and now being felt by at least one committee of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Powell, I know your problem of trying to illustrate why Standing Orders should be suspended so that you can discuss these matters but, rather than making a brief reference to what would have to be discussed, you are now developing a fairly long argument, which will be relevant to your motion if the one before us is passed, rather than to the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. All that remains for me to say, as I have done publicly in the past, is that, when there is a range of genuine concerns, the Senate needs to move for investigation, discussion and consultation before passage of the legislation rather than afterwards.

SPEECH.PARA: I happen to be a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. At the moment we have before us a reference on the debt recovery and information gathering powers of the Department of Social Security. The reason that we have that reference now and that the Committee is spending time on it, after legislation has been passed and after pain has been caused in the community, is that we legislated before we investigated. Sections 162 and 164 of this legislation were amended to give powers which raised concern in the community in 1987 and in 1988, and in May this year the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee was asked to investigate those provisions. It seems that the credibility of the Government-and indeed of the Parliament-is at risk if it continues down this track of ignoring the people in the community who are working at the coalface; passing legislation regardless of those expressions of concern; and refusing to have that legislation properly investigated, to have a vital and sensitive issue, which this one is, properly discussed. It seems to me a bit like the case of Little Red Riding Hood's grandmother: `Everything will be all right but maybe down the track, if enough pain is caused, we will send it off to a Senate committee'. As I say, that committee already has a reference which probably it would never have had if we had seriously addressed earlier the issues of debt recovery and information gathering. The Australian Democrats are putting to the Senate that we should not go ahead with that part of the legislation dealing with the sensitive matter of determination of de facto relationships before there has been adequate consultation-and there has not been in this instance-and before the very difficult areas are investigated. The list that is being inserted in this legislation is not exhaustive, nor should it be because it is a very sensitive, very personal and very individual area.

We do not see how the Government is advancing what is a difficult area which is not being terribly well handled at the moment. We subscribe to the view that there are other ways of tackling this-that better administrative guidelines, better resourcing and better training of people who have to make the decision in spite of this legislation would be a better way to go about it. We submit that this Senate should at this point in the debate remove certain parts of the legislation so that we can then open up for consultation the serious issue that is before us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question before the Chair is that Standing Orders be suspended. Senator Powell elaborated to a considerable extent on what matters would be discussed if Standing Orders were suspended. I ask the following speakers to concentrate merely on the direct issue of whether Standing Orders should or should not be suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are confronted with a motion to suspend Standing Orders on the basis of the urgency to clarify and defer a matter for further and wider consultation. The Government needs to make three points in response to this. Those points are based very much on questioning the urgency of the need for deferral. I acknowledge that Senator Powell's concern may be honestly based, but we must respond to that concern by ensuring that the urgency and the reasons put forward for it are clarified in the minds of many people.

SPEECH.PARA: The first point is that the Government's intention in this area was announced some 6 1/2 months ago. At that particular time the Australian Democrats made their position very clear. Senator Powell indicated that she would oppose the legislation. In a press release of 7 August, Senator Powell said:
The Australian Democrats will oppose Government legislation on de facto relationships when it comes before the Senate.

The Democrats have a clear position. There is no reason why that position could not have been expressed in the normal course of events when the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1989 came before the Parliament. But we have an expression of urgency this afternoon which, I must say, is not all that well founded.

In terms of the urgency of the consultation, Senator Powell, in the same statement of 7 August, indicated that she had written to all women Federal parliamentarians urging them to oppose the move in their party meetings and in the Parliament. It should be placed on record that consultation does not start and end with the Australian Democrats. The Australia Labor Party Caucus, as well as a number of Caucus committees, has considered the issues very closely. The status of women committee is one group that Senator Powell has targeted. The community service and welfare committee and the sole parents working group have considered the matter over some length of time. I am pleased to say that they have consulted, and are consulting, outside organisations and that they do not express the same degree of concern that Senator Powell expressed this afternoon. They are satisfied with the Government's intention.

Senator Powell has had plenty of time to make up her mind. She had made up her mind some months ago. To defer this matter to a committee at this stage is just to stagnate the process of decision making. The case for urgency is based on a number of premises about how people's lives would be affected once this Parliament passes the legislation. In order to resolve that uncertainty, that case for urgency, it is important to go to some of the points raised by Senator Powell about which she was quite agitated. The legislation, in part, under clause 25, inserts a list of indicators to be considered and taken into account by the Department of Social Security in each case when deciding whether a marriage-like relationship exists. This list is contained in proposed section 3a. The list essentially codifies the law as it is laid down by the Federal Court in Tang's case, which has been in operation for some time. The law laid down by the courts implements a policy that people who live as if they are married should not be advantaged as against people who are married. It therefore requires decision makers to consider all the practical elements of a relationship to decide whether a person is single or not.

Some concern has been expressed-and, as a result, some urgency-that the legislation is rigid in its application of the principles of Tang. As I said, the legislation essentially codifies existing law, because the Government does see a need for the legislation to provide a clearer decision-making process than the current law. Essentially, that is because some of the interpretations of the current law really need to be taken account of at this stage by the Senate. For example, proposed subsection 3a (a) (ii) refers to:
any significant pooling of financial resources especially in relation to major financial commitments;

That compares with the case law, which would look to any pooling of financial resources; not limited to `significant' pooling nor to emphasis on `major' financial commitments. So if Senator Powell is concerned about the urgency of the legislation, her concern may be coming from the wrong direction. The legislation, at proposed subsection 3a (a) (iv), looks at the basis of sharing day-to-day expenses, not merely whether there is any sharing of expenses, as the existing case law dictates.

Some concern has also been expressed that some of the paragraphs of proposed section 3a are of no assistance in the decision making. Taken on their own, that may well be right as regards any particular case coming before a decision maker. Proposed section 3a provides for objective, thorough decision making, taking all relevant facts into account. So in some cases some of those criteria will be relevant and in other cases they may not. The proposed legislation will improve the primary decision making by the Department. The urgency that Senator Powell expresses about what it does is not well-founded.

I go on to other parts of the provisions about which there is said to be urgency. Currently, the legislation requires an officer merely to determine whether a de facto relationship exists, with nothing more. Decision making is often arbitrary and can be inconsistent. On the other hand, if officers are expressly required to make their decision by looking at the indicators listed in the proposed Act, then by turning their minds to each indicator we will get more consistency and less arbitrariness in decision making. That covers the first part of Senator Powell's urgency motion.

As regards the second part of the motion, clause 28 seeks to insert a new section 43a into the Act. That section will deal with three matters. First, it deals with the obligation of pensioners and claimants to provide information. Secondly, it specifies a clear decision-making process. Third, it repeals the arbitrary disqualification of some pensioners. It also limits investigations into domestic circumstances. All this concern and agitation about more intrusiveness by the legislation is really not well-founded.

The provisions relating to obligations to provide information change the existing law, contained in section 163 of the Social Security Act, in three respects. First, the existing law overrides common law privileges. One of those privileges is the privilege against self-incrimination. It would have been urgent and subject to grave consideration by the Parliament if that sort of situation were allowed to continue. But the Bill we are talking about, which is said to be so urgent, does not allow that situation to continue. In recognition of the sensitivity of this area, proposed section 43a does not override privilege.

Secondly, the existing law provides no procedural protections. It limits the imposing of obligations to notify `any matter that might affect the payment of a pension'. In contrast, one of the concerns that Senator Powell has with proposed section 43a is that it is limited to operating when specific objective facts exist and that there is not such a broad provision under it. In fact, individuals will be protected under proposed section 43a more than they are under the existing law.

Thirdly, section 163 (2) of the existing law provides for pensioners to be obliged to notify matters by a written form. We are saying that that is a bit too rigid: a pensioner can comply with the requirement in the future through an interview rather than by filling out a form. That is the first part of this area of urgency and concern. I am sure that Senator Powell would agree that that is not as real as she might have thought it to be.

The second feature of proposed section 43a is the prescription of a decision-making process, which is vital and important. As to whether it provides certainty to people out there who, Senator Powell claims, might be concerned about further intrusiveness, a prescribed decision-making process can only assist against intrusiveness. That is what the second part of this particular section does. By imparting these more rigid and visible decision-making processes, we can be sure that decisions that are made on the evidence and in accordance with the criteria will be able to stand up to scrutiny. Let us acknowledge that intrusiveness is not going to be a real problem there. Basically, the legislation lays the groundwork for much more objective, less arbitrary and less intrusive decision making. When this new legislation becomes law, interviews in the home about the details of domestic circumstances will not occur. Instead, decisions can be based upon office based interviews and reviews. Further, we can be sure that decision making will be much more careful and consistent with regard to the detailed facts of each case and to set-down criteria.

I conclude by going to the third feature of the legislation which is said to be urgent. Clause 24 (g) relates to the repeal or arbitrary disqualification from sole parent pension of people separated under the one roof after six or 12 months. The Government is providing a tight but fair decision-making process, which enables the repeal of this particular rule. Once again, far from urgent intrusiveness, we are striking a very good balance between fairness, equity and responsibility of government to ensure that government resources are spent appropriately. We also recognise by the legislation that domestic circumstances of sole parent pensioners can change over time. Proposed subsections 43a (13) and (14) would limit further investigations in certain circumstances and would ensure that reviews can take place after 12 weeks rather than at any particular time, unless there has been a substantial change of circumstances.

I can go on. Other protections in the Bill will protect against intrusiveness and give more certainty to people. In summary, we have not had presented to us any case for this matter to be considered as urgent. The issues canvassed this afternoon can be canvassed when the Bill comes up in Parliament at the appropriate time. I am sure that that will not be more than a few weeks away. In the meantime, it probably would be appropriate for people who get representations to spell out some of the provisions as they would operate and not to approach this legislation as if we were approaching something new, something in a vacuum, but to acknowledge, firstly, that there is currently operating case law that dictates how departments work and how governments operate and interpret the legislation and, secondly, that this legislation gives certainty, clarity and a fair degree of definition to the criteria on which decisions have to be based, as well as to the decision-making processes. There is no case for urgency. I am sure we will have this debate again when the Bill is considered by the Senate, perhaps next week. In closing, I say that I can quite understand that Senator Powell's concerns in this area may be honestly based, but it probably behoves a lot of people in the community to approach this legislation with a calm mind rather than becoming hysterical about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on the question of urgency of the matter, and opposing the suspension of Standing Orders, the Opposition is of the view that this area of law is one which has been perpetually complex and confused. The legislation which is proposed to be introduced amounts to a statutory code which will make the definition question of de facto relationship-now referred to as a marriage-like relationship-more certain. The question of urgency concerns the fact that if a committee had been established, it would have held up the operation of the legislation, which is due to come into effect on 1 January 1990.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite clearly the relevant sections of the Bill are clauses 24, 25 and 28. Clause 24 of the Bill provides a new definition of a de facto relationship. Clause 25 embodies new sections of the principal Act which will require certain aspects to be taken into consideration; namely, financial aspects of the relationship; the nature of the household task and arrangements; social aspects; sexual relationship and the nature of the commitment to each other. Clause 28, which proposes a further amendment to the Act, sets out quite clearly three absolute criteria which must be established on the facts, plus one of several others, which would mean that four criteria had to be established before the Secretary was required to ask for information.

The questions that have been raised in deputations that have resulted from the proposed legislation do have some real basis in what one might describe as a worst case scenario. It is for exactly that reason that the shadow Minister has sought from, and been given by, the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) an assurance that the review procedures would be applied fairly and that the person seeking review of a previous decision would be entitled to receive benefits until the outcome of the review. Further, the shadow Minister in the other place has said that we give a commitment that, if necessary, we will review the legislation upon coming to government and ensure that it is applied with fairness. Accordingly, if the motion moved by Senator Powell were to be agreed to, it would simply delay the introduction of the legislation and really serve no good purpose.

Senator Powell drew particular attention to the requirement that the Secretary is obliged to make a determination that a relationship is not in fact a de facto relationship only if the information supplied sustains that decision. It is further provided in the proposed legislation that it is prohibited to provide fraudulent or misleading information upon which the Secretary would make that decision.

There is general concern in the community that the existing system has been subject to abuse. Indeed, there has been growth in the number of people who are in receipt of the benefit. I think the projected figure is for an increase of 4.9 per cent for the current financial year. There is a good deal of concern that there is a need to tighten up the criteria upon which the benefit is paid. It is important to point out that it is a benefit conferred; it is not a right which is sought to be exercised. I think that that decision is important, particularly in light of some comments which are being made that somehow the onus of proof is being reversed, when in fact the onus of proof is something which belongs in criminal law. When we are dealing with civil law we are concerned with the balance of probabilities. I think it is important to remember that it is a benefit conferred to those who are in genuine need and not a right which people seek to exercise. Accordingly, I do not feel that Senator Powell has been able to establish urgency. It would in no way serve to benefit people who need to have access to the benefit, because the legislation makes the law more certain.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Powell's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1989-90[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 1) 1989-90APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 2) 1989-90]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 October, on motion by Senator Walsh:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has decided to debate together Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1989-90, Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1989-90 and Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1989-90 which make up the Government's Budget for this financial year. No-one can enter this debate without feeling concern for the situation in which we are considering the Budget: a nation deeply in debt and going further into debt each month under a Labor Government that promises so much and then which does not deliver ever, at all; a nation burdened with record bankruptcies, where people cannot start or succeed with businesses; a nation facing interest rates above 20 per cent-interest rates which mean that the dream of owning a home recedes for many, including many Australians already in a home which they would like to own. We have the spectacle of people losing their homes and of a generation of young Australians despairing of ever owning one. We have the unsavoury spectacle of a government either unable or unwilling to fix the damage it has caused and created.

SPEECH.PARA: We hear a lot about the technicalities of the economic malaise and disaster that surround us today. Most of us do not really follow the jargon, the language, the arcane reasoning of economists. Too often it is just so much complicated nonsense. We understand simpler things. We know that we are not doing well as a nation. We know that more of our pay is now going into enormous mortgages. We know that our rents get higher and that our taxes increase. Every time we look around there is another Labor Government grab or another Labor Government withdrawal of benefit. Our children are having more trouble with enormous interest rates payable on their car loans. Their Bankcards cost them the earth to service. They are being laid off from their jobs as a result of a disastrous and unresolved pilots strike.

Yes, we know what it is like in real life even if we do not understand the jargon of the economists. Through it all this Labor Government seems either not to know what to do or to do things which just do not work. Then it tells us crazy things and it expects us to believe them. It expects that we should not be worried that two reputable rating agencies say that Australia under Labor is less creditworthy than it was. Why should we not worry? The Government tells us that high interest rates, which are part of its economic program, which are driving us to the wall, are good for us. Why should we believe that? The Government tells us that record international debt obligations do not matter. Why should we believe that? We know that the Government is wrong. A friend of mine who is a leading toy retailer in Australia-I would say the leading toy retailer-tells me that sales at this moment are down 30 per cent on last year. They are down because people have less money, people are less prosperous and they just do not believe that they are well enough off to be buying luxuries like toys for their children.

This Budget, which forms the basis for this debate, sets out how the Government thinks it will approach things this financial year, and a threadbare and sorry effort it is, too. It is already clear that it is not working. Here it is October and we are almost four months into the financial year. Tomorrow is the end of the month, and that will be one-third of the financial year gone. We already know that the Budget program will not work. We already know that our debt is becoming greater and greater-not less.

We already know that inflation is worse. The figures given last week show that it is back above 8 per cent. We already know that we have lower creditworthiness. We already know that we have higher interest rates, and God knows where they are going to end. We already know that there is more misery around the country, that there is less certainty and more failure. Through it all, the Government says that it is a wonderful Budget.

It is a pleasure to support the amendment moved by my colleague Senator Stone, which makes these matters explicit, in elegant economists' language. It is a pleasure to go further and remind Australians that we have an alternative government, that we have an alternative program and that there is another way to go. We have an Opposition which is now invigorated and renewed-and whole, particularly after the weekend-which stands ready to redress wrongs, to offer hope and succour, which stands ready to reward enterprise, to reward opportunity, to increase opportunity and to promise those who wish to strive that they will be allowed to succeed.

The Opposition has now released its blueprint, a document which the Government has not dented or damaged. It is a document of hope which points the way to a better future. We know that the Labor Government in its desperation might steal some of the elements of our package. Well, the Government is welcome. Should it do so, people will see that as one more piece of evidence of the intellectual sterility and administrative incompetence of this Labor Administration. It has the smell of death about it, it is on the way out, and we cannot get an election quickly enough.

I use the opportunity that this debate presents to turn to some more detailed and specialised matters. I do not intend to use my time in this second reading debate to reconsider all the matters dealt with in the Estimates committees. I might mention one or two of them later in committee. For example, I might well wish to discuss further the case of Mr Young, the homosexual man who was so badly, inappropriately and callously treated in the Royal Canberra Hospital. However, that will be a matter for the committee debate. I trust that some of my colleagues will want to take up his case with me.

I now want to develop some matters related to my specialist interests and background in medical service delivery. I will discuss first some of the ways in which we conceptualise hospital services and why there is such disarray today. We all know that Labor's Medicare has produced quite perverse results. Public hospital beds are less available for the less advantaged now than they were before we had Medicare. That is one of the perverse results that Medicare has produced. Generally, public hospital beds are not readily available for those people seeking to redeem Labor's promise, made when Medicare first appeared, that we could all have access to public hospital beds if we wished. We cannot have access-that is the truth of the matter. This is one more promise by Labor that has been and is being dishonoured every day in every part of Australia. There are not enough beds for admissions of people with non-urgent illness, especially once the hospitals have been filled up with trauma victims, the victims of accidents that come in each weekend.

It has never been easy to find a bed in a public hospital in Australia. Once, many years ago, I was for a period the admitting officer of a large teaching hospital. Actually, I was the non-admitting officer-my job was to keep people out of the hospital. My job was to fit admissions to the number of beds that we had empty, not to fit admissions to the needs of the community.

Labor's promise was that things would improve with Medicare, that all that would change, that people by paying their levy could look to the availability of a public hospital bed if they needed it. People have tried to redeem that promise, but they cannot. Things have actually become worse. They have become worse for a number of reasons. The Labor governments previously in power in New South Wales and Labor governments here in Canberra forced a quite unnecessary confrontation with members of the medical profession and drove nurses by the thousands out of the hospital system. Yes, things are much worse now. My old hospital, once the pride of that part of Sydney where it is located, now has beds closed and empty, in true Sir Humphrey style, and has queues at the door. Sir Humphrey Appleby would like it because, after all, empty beds require less maintenance and less administrative support and do not require nurses or resident medical officers. Empty beds mean that fewer meals are required, that big drug bills are not required and that investigations are not required. As Sir Humphrey Appleby said, `Keep the hospital empty and you will keep the costs down'. However, that is not very good for the community. Things are worse and we have all been cheated by the undelivered promises of Medicare.

This leads me to the question of what can be done. We know this is the situation, but what can we do? This is not just a theoretical matter to be solved by armchair experts. It becomes a crisis if I am ill or if one of my loved ones is ill, if we cannot then find a bed when one is needed. One obvious answer might be to look for a bed in a private hospital, and that is what used to happen. But even there the scene is one of chaos. It is a scene of betrayed hopes and broken dreams. The Labor Government has moved relentlessly on several fronts to make it less and less possible for private hospitals in Australia to survive, much less to prosper.

It has done this in a number of ways. It has taken away the $40 per day bed subsidy to private hospitals, it has reduced the reinsurance fund, which helps share costs for certain chronically ill people, from $125m five years ago to $1m last year, and it has reduced the rebate on Medicare that can be claimed for services in hospitals from 85 per cent of the schedule fee to 75 per cent of the schedule fee.

Why is it that it is only the helping professions that are being asked by the Labor Government to take cuts in their income at the present time-only doctors and pharmacists? What has the Government got against doctors and pharmacists? Can it not understand why they are so angry about these moves? Labor's promise might have been acceptable. It might have been acceptable action had we understood that we have a socialist government and a Minister who identifies himself as a socialist health Minister. It might have been acceptable had there been a surfeit of public hospital beds, because in that case the promise could have been redeemed. It might have been acceptable had there been unused public bed capacity-and I mean in the large cities, as that is what I know best. It might have been acceptable had there been a sufficiency of public hospital beds, or had there been the possibility of meeting the urgent and legitimate needs of citizens as those arose.

However, such is not the case. There is not a sufficiency of beds. It is not possible to meet the needs of citizens as they arise. The public hospital systems do not deliver accommodation for all who need it. Private hospitals are therefore, of necessity, one of the main locations of alternative care. Yet, as I say, this Government has moved in several ways to make it less and less possible for private hospitals to survive at all. Altered tax and levy arrangements have meant that fewer and fewer Australians carry insurance cover for the cost of private hospital accommodation. In the last few years the percentage of Australians carrying that extra insurance cover has dropped from something above 70 per cent to something under 50 per cent. So 20 per cent of the Australian population have opted out of private health insurance. Twenty per cent more people now rely on that smaller number of public hospital beds. The 20 per cent who dropped out were the young and healthy. I will mention them again in a moment.

Altered co-payment systems have further reduced the viability of some public hospitals. The submissions that have been presented to the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance, on which I serve, have not been made public and, therefore, they have not been released. However, one of the submissions consists of a paper which was presented in September at a conference of Australian health economists and is, therefore, a public document. The submission was written by Dr R. B. Scotton from Monash University who is well known as one of the architects of Labor's health policies in the 1970s. In respect of the present system, Dr Scotton says:

The major problem of Medicare is the difficulty faced by many patients in gaining access to free public hospital care, as evidenced by long waiting lists for certain types of treatment in most capital cities. There is some evidence that waiting lists are again tending to grow, despite attempts by state and federal governments to contain them. It is an ironic feature of the Medicare program-and a potential source of long-term weakness-that its capacity to deliver its most important promised benefit depends on a substantial proportion of the population opting not to avail itself of it.
Dr Scotton is saying that for Medicare to succeed we need substantial numbers of Australians able and willing to use the private hospital sector. He goes on to say:

Excess demand for public treatment is associated with a decline in private insurance coverage, which is down from 49.1% of the population in December 1985 to 46.2% in December 1988. The slide does not appear to be slowing, which indicates that the system is not in stable equilibrium.
The word `not' is underlined by Dr Scotton. He continues:

The trend away from private insurance has been exacerbated by several factors which have combined to an increase in the price of private health insurance premiums which has far outstripped general price rises.

He then goes on to talk in economic terms. The situation has been exacerbated further by some new arrangements for day care arrangements which are sensible in concept but still imperfect in detail and which have added further problems for the private hospital sector. The viability of our private hospitals-which is essential, as Dr Scotton said, if the whole system is to work-depends on and is related to questions of payment, of cash and subsidy. This seems to be where much, but not all, of the problem lies. If the cash is not going to be available, another set of questions arise. Those questions are: can we do more and can we do better with the same funds? First, we have dealt and continue to deal too much with inputs, with the result that we end up with incremental budgeting on an historical basis. This is no way to reform a system. It is no way to get better outcomes. It is no way to do better with the same money.

Without developing this complex subject in too much detail, let me suggest that it is now time for us to move to hospital funding based on outputs or outcomes, to provide more money for better or more complex provision of care and to provide less money for simpler, less complicated provision of care. There are some mechanisms by which this approach is being developed, but it needs more development. If carried through, there could be an alteration in activity undertaken, in funding for private hospitals and in the possibilities for new vigour and new development. Let me suggest further that while the levels of insurance cover and cash payments are important, they are not the most critical factors in the viability and future of private hospitals. They are important but they are not the only factors. The most critically important factor is the quality of the care and the facilities which are available.

We have in Sydney at least three outstandingly good private hospitals. Other capital cities have a corresponding number of good facilities, too. But in Sydney, if one is ill and one wants private care, one thinks immediately of St Vincent's Private Hospital, the Sydney Adventist Hospital and Baulkham Hills Private Hospital. Each of them is different from the other two in some or several major ways. But each shares a reputation for quality of facilities and quality of services. I put it to honourable senators that at a time of need this is what will influence people. I will go where quality care is available. If I were suffering a common or garden problem, I would certainly look for high quality care in a high quality institution, whether it be public or private. If I had a rare or complicated condition, at present I would seek care in a teaching hospital. But that does not mean that for the usual run of conditions I would be unhappy in seeking care from a private hospital. I would not be unhappy.

I raise this matter because the debate in Australia is not about quality, it is not about outcomes but, like so much of the medical services debate, it is mostly about inputs of money. I think we can do better. I want a better debate and, consistent with my long-time advocacy of program budgeting, I believe that the quality and relevance of that debate is linked closely with an increasing concentration on outcomes. That in turn means that I look closely at the range and quality of services and that I am concerned about the range and quality of data on which decision making must be based.

That leads me for a few moments to think a little about health insurance. I am, with five other senators, a member of the select committee which is presently looking at this matter. I have to say that I have some difficulties with some of the basic concepts underlying voluntary health insurance in Australia. These difficulties are added to the question of double payment. Most people say, `We have to pay our levy; why should we then, in addition, pay voluntary health insurance?'. People get the idea that they are paying double. Such health insurance as we have is based on the concept of community rating. This, of course, is a form of taxation of the young and healthy to pay for the medical costs of the elderly and the ill.

I said a few moments ago that it was the young and healthy who have dropped out of health insurance. They are the very people who are needed to make the system viable. The trade-off, of course, is that the young will become elderly in time and will then, in theory, benefit in their turn from community rating. But there are several flaws on community rating. It requires a very high rate of coverage across the community. Further, it requires what is euphemistically called `insurance'-one might wonder whether health insurance is insurance-to be taken out by many people whose need for services is predictable and inevitable.

Let me give an example. My secretary and personal assistant of 20 years now receives the invalid pension because she is looking after and caring for her husband who has severe, crippling and destructive rheumatoid arthritis. He is not, and has not been for years, an insurance proposition in the sense that we use that term. He has been a dead cert high cost drawer on the health insurance pool. We all know that. Yet, under the community rating rules and assuming that he has been insured, it is required that he and many like him with equivalent disabling illnesses have access to community rating at the same rates and with almost the same rights of access and portability as young healthy people. This is one of the reasons young people I know-people who are already required to pay their levy-will not pay what they consider to be excessive premiums for extra private health insurance cover. You know and I know, Mr Acting Deputy President, that they may well need it because the public hospital system cannot deliver them the beds on which they depend.

Of course the matter is not simple. Any course one takes in trying to set down rules for private health insurance will have costs and benefits. For example, some people-not me-might propose a simple move from community rating to risk rating. I am not one of those people. The price of moving to risk rating is too high-that is, the cost in fairness and equity would be too high, so we cannot go down the road of risk rating. If it were applied with cold purity, it would mean that the insurance costs for the elderly increased severalfold. This is too much and market forces would then see the elderly abandoning health insurance in droves and see them left with no cover and getting no access to care as the public hospitals would be even less able to give them the access they needed.

Until our Committee hears detailed argument from witnesses, I favour some variance of the old `special account' rule which operated when I was in medical practice. That rule allowed the Commonwealth to pick up and subsidise the costs of certain high cost patients who were not insurance propositions, particularly some of the elderly with chronic illnesses. Under that system we identified people who were chronically ill and who were not then candidates for community rating and removed them from the pool. We bore their expenses as a community. That then seemed to me to be a fair, efficient and reasonable way to go and it still seems a fair way to go. It was certainly a better system then than we now have. The present system passes the costs of these people back to the general body of insurees, with little public assistance. For that reason it is in favour with and has the approval of the Department of Finance and the Department of the Treasury. They are delighted to see costs pass back to the public and to minimise the amount of public underwriting that has to be done by the Commonwealth. It may also be in favour with those who would like to see the costs of health insurance kept beyond the reach of many but it is not in keeping with those who are concerned about equity and fairness.

The second thing I would like to see is more lateral thinking around the possibilities offered by the concept of capitation as a form of payment-as one choice. I do not favour some of the capitation schemes I know or in which I have worked, but I am impressed by some others. I am thinking of the health maintenance organisations that I have seen in North America. The advantages of these could include fewer visits, more emphasis on health promotion, lower drug bills, and less use of hospital services-all desirable things if the quality and the level of care remains. In addition, it would sit well in a mixed system alongside fee-for-service medicine, so offering even greater choice for consumers like me and my family.

We will have to take some policy decisions about those aged 65 or more who decide at that age that they wish to take out private health insurance. Medibank Private already has exclusion clauses related to new enrollees aged 65 or more, but we will have to go about it in a very logical way. These people can claim rights under Medicare if they have not contributed to the insurance pool up to the age of 65, but then a real question arises as to whether they should be able to enrol for all the benefits only at the age when they are likely to represent a call upon the funds and we know that most of the calls are from the elderly. We need to decide whether to subsidise their access and by how much.

Questions about pre-existing illness also need careful attention. Perhaps there should be exclusions for pre-existing illness, perhaps for several years, on those who come in with pre-existing conditions. These things will be necessary if we really wish to make health insurance viable, attractive and successful. We then have to devise better strategies for encouraging the young to join and for convincing the middle-aged to join and contribute before they are old. Getting the insurance formula wrong has high costs. It discourages further doctors already under seige and dispirited with low morale and feeling the assault of a Labor Government in Canberra and a former Labor Government in New South Wales. Getting it wrong would lead to even more inadequate hospitals, with wards closed, a distorted range of illness represented, no places left for those who depend on the Medicare levy alone and a staff with a low and dropping morale. It would lead to unfairness, not just the perception of unfairness, but its reality. It would lead to a poorer range of offerings and to lower quality services and facilities in private hospitals. If we get it wrong it will lead to fewer private hospitals for a community in which elective illness is too often just not treated properly. As a principle, surely we would all agree that delay in treating the routine things-cataracts, enlarged prostates, hernias, heart failure, delays in offering palliative care-is immoral. Such delays are a denial of what the Labor Party has been pleased to refer to as rights to care. That is what is happening today. There is that denial of care for those conditions. It is a shame and it is not good enough. We can do better.

The Liberal Party's economic statement has shown as a first instalment how we would go about it. Our health insurance policy is yet to appear, but it will carry the promise of relief, the message of hope, one stage further. We in the Liberal Party stand ready to resume the tasks and responsibilities of national government. We cannot have it happen soon enough and Australia will be a better country if we do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate on the Appropriation Bills gives one a chance to talk about general economic issues and the opportunity to raise issues of concern with regard to specific appropriations. Therefore, I will refer to some matters of macro-economic policy. Within that context, I will also comment on the issue of the adequacy and timeliness of the statistics which serve as the basis for official economic decision-making. I will also make some comments about the overseas aid budget-its quantity, quality, and the priorities within it-and proposals to cut further the already meagre budget.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to questions of macro-economic policy, there is a significant contrast between the policies of the Government and the Opposition. The contrast is not as it has been publicly presented and I would like to comment on some of those contrasts. With regard to fiscal policy, the prevailing analysis is essentially correct. There will be no significant tightening of fiscal policy under the declared policies of the Opposition. The macro-economic implications of the increases in the deficit are nil. It is possible to argue that there is a hidden agenda, that Messrs Hewson and Stone in a second Budget would be given their head to cut much more savagely. Certain indicators of their underlying attitude would indicate that that may be so. However, if we take their comments at face value, as also the policies they espouse, we can see that the fiscal policy differences are minor.

With regard to wages policy, the difference is much more significant. The Government has an established, working wages policy which has delivered wage restraint for seven years while delivering increased household disposable income because that wage restraint has been the basis on which more jobs have been able to be created. This is where one of the areas of dramatic contrast arises. Under the proposed Liberal-National Party policy the preconditions for a wage blow-out for some workers-those in strong bargaining positions-would be enhanced, but workers in the less advantageous market position might get no increases at all or possibly even cuts in their wages. If the policy was to deliver an increase in wages, it would lead to increasing unemployment and consequent falling household disposable income. This would also create graver inequities and divide Australia in a way that a similar policy has divided Britain.

As a matter of interest, once unemployment went up, taxation revenue would start to fall, government outlays would start to rise and the Budget surplus so painstakingly built up would continue to be eroded. Of course, the policy might have some magical method of achieving its declared aim of making wage increases occur only at the same rate as productivity. The process by which this is to be delivered is not apparent and it has not been discovered anywhere in the world. Even if there is such a magic wand, one thing is certain: There is no element of the magic wand which could make rapid increases in productivity per employee. Mr Howard on the weekend confirmed that quite correctly. The only exception to that rule is unemployment. Unemployment could increase the productivity of those workers still in employment as capital labour ratios change. But unless unemployment increases, wage increases would be substantially less than inflation if the exclusively productivity-based wage increases espoused by the Opposition were to be achieved. By whatever method, household disposable income would fall. I believe that the real outcome would be a wage blow-out for the strong and a wage cut for the weak, increasing unemployment, falling household disposable income, social division and inequity, and a consequential slackening of fiscal policy, which is quite the opposite of what is predicted at the moment.

In commenting on the so-called third arm of economic reform, namely, micro-economic reform, I should like to quote from a book entitled Making Economic Policy in Australia 1983-88 by Michael Keating and Geoff Dixon. At page IX of that book the authors say:

This book examines the Labor Government's response to the economic challenges in the period 1983-1988. The centrepiece of that response has been, in effect, a package of measures involving reductions in real wages, although not household disposable incomes, a Commonwealth budget surplus for the first time in 35 years for which comparable records have been kept and the floating of the exchange rate.

Taken individually each of these developments was of historic significance. As a package they represented a quite major redirection of economic policy, even by international standards. The package was moreover accompanied by a number of other significant changes in microeconomic policy: reductions in tariff and quota protection; major tax reforms; moves to put government enterprises on a more commercial basis, together with encouragement of improved work practices, pay systems and training, which is potentially of great long term significance.

Together with the proposed deregulation of the airline industry, the reviews of the primary industries, and the reports and recommendations on coastal shipping and waterfront reform, this constitutes the most comprehensive package of micro-economic reform ever achieved in Australia. This is not to say that the process is over; it is simply to say that the process described by Keating and Dixon as `bargained consensus', that is, negotiated agreement between affected interest groups to achieve agreed processes of change, provides the only real basis for lasting micro-economic reform. If time permits, I hope to return later to other micro-economic reform issues.

The other arm of domestic macro-economic policy is monetary policy, which I have deliberately left until last. A lot of attention has been focused on this subject. In fact, the allegation has been made by the Opposition that this is the only weapon which the Government is using to restrain demand. Quite clearly, the evidence of a tight fiscal policy and wage restraint points to the contrary. However, it is true that monetary policy has been what I would describe as the swing variable-the mechanism which is capable of being adjusted once fiscal and wages policies are as tight as can reasonably be achieved. The Opposition implicitly endorses this by a fiscal policy no tighter than that of the Government and a wages policy that will probably in effect be much slacker.

In these circumstances monetary policy does not have the capacity to be varied independently of the parameters of fiscal and wages policy. Certainly in the short term no micro-economic reform changes will have any impact on the level of monetary policy. There is no micro-economic reform initiative which could affect monetary policy in any way within any reasonable timetable that would, for example, affect the legitimate concerns of Australians who are aspiring to buy or maintain payments on their homes. For this reason the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has said correctly that the so-called economic statement of the Liberal and National parties is a recipe for higher interest rates.

A second and disturbing element exists within the area of monetary policy. The language of the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), bears an awful similarity to that of the pre-1979 Thatcher Conservative Party. The shadow Treasurer's reference to medium term monetary targets is the language of Thatcherism and monetarism-a policy which has failed around the world and which will fail in Australia. The only problem with it is that the price of its failure tends to be paid not by its advocates but by the weakest in the community.

My outlining the manner in which I believe the Government's economic strategy is superior to that of the Opposition is not sufficient to establish the view-and I do not wish to pretend otherwise-that there is no more to be done. A large number of issues need to be addressed. For example, obviously any country with significant problems of debt and balance of payments and with an inflation rate that is higher than that of its trading partners must continue to focus primarily on economic management, which I believe will be the key policy issue in the next election.

I turn now to one key variable to which attention needs to be given and which for the first time is beginning to be addressed, namely, savings. There is some evidence that the savings ratio in Australia has been rising. The Budget Papers appear to support that view. Nevertheless, it is obvious from the need for capital inflow to finance Australian investment that Australian savings are too low. We do not want to achieve a balance between savings and investment by a dramatic reduction in the level of investment. Therefore, we must concentrate on increasing the level of savings within the country.

The Budget appears to indicate that the principal source of increase in the national savings effort has come from public sector savings, that is, from the Government's outstanding performance in restraining expenditure and turning a large deficit into a record surplus. This makes the Opposition's policy on capital gains tax very hard to understand. For no apparent economic reason other than a pathological opposition to requiring its major contributors to pay tax, the Opposition is proposing to abolish capital gains tax and to hand back $450m a year of money that is legitimately paid by those people who earn their income as capital gains. In effect, that covers the top one per cent of income earners in Australia.

What is more, the Opposition is advocating or pretending that this policy is being adopted to provide an incentive to people to change their savings and investment habits. I believe that the policy would be ineffective in that regard. If that is the real and underlying reason for the decision, it is very hard to understand why the Opposition is introducing this policy with retrospective effect, on all capital purchases dating from 1985. It is impossible to believe that even the Liberal Party would expect its rorted tax changes to have a retrospective effect on people's attitudes, that is, to affect purchasing and investment decisions made by people in 1985. It is no more than a handout to the wealthy at the expense of ordinary Australians who pay their taxes.

A key element of a proper savings strategy must be continued emphasis on superannuation. The Government has given proper and continuing emphasis to this both as a necessary element of its retirement incomes policy and as a process of generating savings by Australians. The example of what has occurred in Singapore and in other countries demonstrates the tremendous potential of widespread superannuation to generate substantial savings. Of course, not all money flowing into superannuation will be a net gain to savings. Some of the money flowing into superannuation would have been saved elsewhere by the individuals concerned, and another portion would have been driven by taxation incentives, which reduce public sector savings. Nevertheless, it appears that superannuation has the potential to generate an enormous increase in domestic savings in Australia and, therefore, to provide a substantially enhanced savings pool to fund Australian investment.

The increase and extension of the coverage of superannuation has substantial equity and social justice implications. I do not have time to consider those here, but they are outlined comprehensively in the retirement incomes policy statement of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), which was released at the same time as the Budget.

In addition to superannuation, other countries have taken radical steps to increase savings. A wide range of measures have been adopted in a number of countries. For example, the Swedish Government has for many years pursued a voluntary savings scheme in association with its taxation collections. A Bill that was introduced into the Swedish Parliament in May 1989 contained a proposal to extend that voluntary savings scheme to a compulsory or obligatory savings scheme that required individuals and companies to deposit the equivalent of 4 per cent of income tax payable for the period September 1989 to 31 December 1990 into an interest bearing account for repayment in 1992 and 1993. If that legislation was passed, it was expected that obligatory savings would total about $2.7 billion.

This is a very controversial proposal and far beyond anything that I would suggest needs to be undertaken in Australia. However, it is an indication that a wider array of measures than those that are used in Australia to date is available and that we should examine the activities of other Western countries to determine possible measures to enhance savings and the likely impact of those measures if introduced into Australia.

I turn now to consumption tax. It is asserted continually that a consumption tax is a key measure to increase savings. The theoretical economic argument for that proposition is easy to comprehend. Nevertheless, the evidence is not yet available.

In Japan, where the controversial debate about the introduction of consumption tax has caused great damage to the LDP Government, notwithstanding the absence of this tax, Japan has a savings ratio that almost all countries which have some sort of value added tax or other consumption tax would love to achieve. What is needed is a comprehensive analysis of the correlation between consumption taxes and savings ratios, both across countries and through time. Do countries with a consumption tax tend to have a higher savings ratio than those without and, in countries which have recently introduced new or substantially increased consumption taxes, have savings ratios responded, as economic theory would predict, to those changes? Anecdotal evidence would tend to indicate that they have not, but it is a necessary part of our information base on which future decisions should be based.

Now I would like to turn to that question of the adequacy of our information base and our statistical base. The inadequacy of the statistical base on which contemporary economic decisions are made is highlighted by the savings issue. In contemporary measurement of economic statistics, savings is essentially a residual measurement, that is, it is essentially what is left over after everything else has been measured; and that clearly seems to me to be a methodological problem. But the problem in the measurement of savings is merely a microcosm of a broader problem. We need statistics that are better and that are more quickly provided. I do not pretend this is easy, and I certainly do not intend to reflect on the diligent and competent activities of the Australian Bureau of Statistics which discharges, in an exemplary manner, the brief it has been given by legislative charter and by various governments over the years. I am referring to the general issue. Economic decision-making is essentially a very difficult task. On the basis of statistical evidence, one is required to apply a theoretical analysis to lead to a prediction of what might or is most likely to happen in the future, and on that basis required to determine the measures that are appropriate to achieve desired social and economic outcomes. However, the information on which decisions are being based can never be up to date or supplied instantaneously. If that is the case the level of estimation or perhaps guesswork becomes much greater. If at the end of October we are dealing with figures in some areas from, say, May, June or July, then a great deal of very important consumer or investment behaviour and a great deal of evidence are unavailable. That has been particularly evident in previous circumstances when governments were making decisions about the appropriate time at which to ease monetary policy.

What is frustrating about the level of this information is that in many areas industry has the contemporaneous information which government desires. The nature of modern computer-based information systems means that in such areas as housing, motor vehicles and retail sales information is immediately available in great detail to the people in the relevant industries. We need to look at ways in which this information can be made more readily and immediately available to government. It seems to me also possible to provide that sort of up to date information in the savings area as well. My purpose today in raising this matter is, I reiterate, not to criticise the Australian Bureau of Statistics or to reflect on the adequacy of current decisions. In the main, I support the view that they have been the best decisions available in the circumstances with which we have been confronted. However, I want to put on notice my concern that in future years governments, of whichever persuasion, will have to pay attention to the adequacy of the statistical base.

In the remaining time available to me I would like to turn my attention to one particular appropriation, that is, the aid budget. This has always been an area of special interest to me and I suppose I should declare that special interest before proceeding to participate in the debate. I think it is a matter which should be of special interest to all Australians and certainly to all involved in the process of government because, properly conducted, the provision of overseas development assistance by Australia to other countries is a question of the transfer of resources to the poorest of the poor and there can be no worthier cause than the alleviation of the cruel poverty in which many people in the world find themselves.

It is important to say at the outset that we are getting better at managing our aid. In this post-Jackson report period there seems to be a widespread view, with which I concur, that the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau is a more efficient, better managed organisation, conducting the aid program more efficiently. In addition, the Government, through the decisions made by Mr Hayden, towards the end of his period as Foreign Minister, and substantially endorsed and in fact reinforced by the current Foreign Minister (Senator Gareth Evans), has moved towards a sharp poverty focus in our own aid program; and I support that strongly. There is also, as a consequence of their decisions following the Jackson report, a greater regional focus on our aid. On the face of it, this may seem to be a contradiction as the poorest countries in the world are not be found in our region; they are to be found in Africa. But we must not ignore the enormous numbers of people in poverty in our region. There are more poor people in Asia than in Africa, although the plight of some of the countries in question is not as desperate as those of the poorest people in the poorest countries, such as the central African countries like Mali, or the besieged southern African states like Mozambique.

Notwithstanding the fact that the quality and focus of our aid is improving, I want to put on record, without equivocation, my regret at the extent of the cuts to the aid program made by this Government. In the economic circumstances with which the Government has been confronted, some cuts were inevitable: not desirable, they would never have been my first choice, but I recognise that all areas of government expenditure had to face restraint and in the absence of widespread community support for aid, and in a context in which aid expenditure, because so much of it contributes to the outflow of money from Australia, was particularly vulnerable for cuts. It was a soft option and all of us concerned with the aid issue-and I include myself-must share the blame for leaving it so vulnerable.

My concern is that aid has taken more than its fair share of the cuts. If the aid budget had been cut proportionately to the reduction in government expenditure as a percentage of gross domestic product (GDP), the aid budget would be substantially greater than it is today. As I said in a speech to a seminar at Deakin University recently, that aid budget would be approximately $150m more than it is today, or about 0.39 per cent of GDP, if those objectives had been met that is, if the cut had been only the equivalent of the reduction in government expenditure overall. It is possible, in fact, to argue that the correct figure is closer to $180m but, for the sake of not appearing too rash, I will use the more conservative figure of $150m.

I acknowledge that in these periods all governments will have to make hard choices, as ours has had to do, but I must say at this stage that I deplore, in the strongest terms, the proposals put forward by the coalition to cut a further $100m from the already meagre aid budget. As Senator Evans said in answer to a question today, it would cut the already meagre aid budget to 0.29 per cent of GDP. What is more, this callous and ignorant decision was probably designed, as were some of the other cuts, such as those to Aboriginal Affairs, to provoke a community response from unpopular groups in an attempt to reinforce the cynical proposition being put to middle-class Australians that somehow or other money was being taken away from those areas in which it might have been wasted and paid to those whose votes the Liberals were hoping to win.

Unfortunately, the decision is also ignorant. It ignores the fact that it is highly likely-and it was confirmed by the Minister in his answer to my question today-that the Australian Government will have to meet $100m of extra multilateral commitments to the international finance institutions next year and that therefore any proposal to cut aid spending by $100m will have double its normal impact on the programs because of the need to fund multilateral commitments. In a $1 billion budget, effectively some parts of it will have to be cut by 20 per cent to absorb this specific $100m cut while increased funding to the international finance institutions goes ahead. When the area of fixed costs in the aid budget is looked at, it will be seen that the impact of these cuts in the other areas of aid to the poorest countries, the effective programs that are being developed to assist the poorest of the poor, is particularly sad and an inappropriate response by any party aspiring to govern Australia.

While I have been critical of this Government's cuts, I must say that there have recently been some substantial pluses in the aid program. I refer, particularly, to the decision to restore funding to the International Fund for Agricultural Development, IFAD. I believe that this is consistent with the poverty focus of the Government's strategy and an appropriate decision for which Minister Evans should take substantial credit. There is also the equity and merit scholarship scheme, devised under Mr Hayden and implemented under Senator Evans. Again, this is assistance in an area in which Australia has a particular capacity to contribute to the development of our region, in a way which is consistent with our objectives of equity and redistribution.

I also want to refer to the increased environmental focus in our aid. It is often too easy to choose the soft option and ignore the fact that sometimes priority objectives may be in conflict. But in many areas of the Third World the problem of poverty is reinforcing the problem of environmental degradation. As the vicious circle continues, the problem of environmental degradation is reinforcing the problem of poverty.

There is also the well targeted and so far currently successful WATCH program; that is, the women and their children's health program. The health of women and children is a proper priority for a poverty focused program. It is one which I wish the Australian media would give more attention to. It is successful and it would give a dramatic focus to the positive achievements of Australia's aid program. The final plus in recent changes to the aid program to which I wish to refer is the question of increased assistance to non-government organisations (NGOs). The NGOs make an outstanding contribution to the Australian aid effort overseas and to the education of Australians about overseas development and poverty issues. This Budget reflects a substantial increase of 10 per cent in real terms in the level of assistance to NGOs. I believe that this is appropriate and I hope it can be sustained.

In conclusion, I turn to some suggestions for the next three years in this area. I hope, and I will be arguing, for a commitment by the Government which would see the lost $150m restored. Some people would regard this as too modest an objective. It is not as ambitious as the very worthwhile recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, which sought 0.5 per cent by 1992. However, a real increase of $150m, or a target of 0.39 per cent or hopefully 0.4 per cent, which the Minister has set as his target over the next three years, would be a very ambitious and appropriate target. Within those financial parameters, I would support a maintenance of the poverty focus, the regional focus and the development of the new initiatives which I have recently outlined. This should be possible, as a greater proportion of aid will be available for such programs as the percentage of our aid going in Budget support to Papua New Guinea declines, as both the Australian and the PNG governments agree that it should.

There is no quick fix in this area. Australia is a small player in a game in which the international community is struggling to come to grips with an enormous problem. But we must act primarily for humanitarian reasons. I acknowledge that there are trade and foreign affairs benefits in a successful aid program. These should be recognised, but they must remain secondary to the primary humanitarian motivation. If we act in this way, we can further enhance Australia's proud place in the international community and make a contribution which is more appropriate to a country such as ours and which is within the realistic limits set by our current economic capacity. With those remarks, I support the Appropriation Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are discussing the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1989-90, Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1989-90 and Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1989-90. This package substantially gives effect to the Government's economic policies. One cannot help but note that in recent days a significant criticism of the Government's present economic policy has come from both the traditional left and traditional right of politics. For instance, I note that Mr Chris White, the Assistant Secretary of the United Trades and Labour Council in South Australia, has just recently called for a change in government policy. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: The need to develop an alternative economic strategy to that of financial deregulation is pressing.
It is ironic that the Labor Party, which once rejected financial deregulation as undemocratic and irrational, began a program of financial deregulation.
He goes on to say:
A further rise in mortgage interest rates would be a disaster for low and middle income earners.
Private and public housing sectors and local manufacturing would be forced into serious decline by the high cost of borrowing money.
Foreign debt will be fuelled by high interest rates, by restricting the capacity for growth of Australian manufacturing exports.
The failure of financial deregulation is increasingly evident with foreign debt increasing by over 300 per cent since public controls were lifted on investment flows in 1983.
The private sector now counts for over 70 per cent of this debt-evidence of the need for introducing new forms of financial regulation.
A clear change of economic direction is required.
At the same time, Australia's major employer groups have attacked the Federal Government for making policy on the run and destroying investor confidence. Nine industry organisations warned that:
. . . business could not confidently invest in the existing environment.
Recent Government decisions on resource development have sent clear messages to Australian business.
That message is: Resource development and business investment are subject to short-term political expediency.
The joint statement-
that is, by the nine industry groups-

follows a Cabinet decision earlier this month which effectively defers a decision on mining of Coronation Hill in the Kakadu conservation zone in the Northern Territory until after the next Federal election.

This, on top of an earlier decision to block moves for the Wesley Vale Pulp Mill in Tasmania, brought to a head simmering industry unrest over the Government's approach to projects with environmental sensitivity.
The joint statement said the greatest threat to investment was uncertainty . . .

The Australian Democrats agree with both the industry leaders and Chris White from the United Trades and Labour Council: there is indeed considerable uncertainty in government direction. But the same is absolutely true of the Opposition's economic policies. Both the Government and the Opposition have failed to recognise that we live in an age of rapid and necessary transition. This transition is brought about by the need to adopt a different attitude to the environment. Both Government and Opposition live in the past. Both act as though the economic patterns of the 1950s and 1960s can be reinstated with a bit of environmental tidying up. Neither the Government nor the Opposition has understood that a new and totally different economic model with a number of exciting technologies is required and that Australia could lead the world in the application and development of those technologies and social adaptations.
