Until this is understood and a new direction is firmly announced and embarked upon by Government, as a society we will remain uncertain.

The Australian Democrats is the only party proposing an alternative economic strategy. Neither major political grouping has grasped the need, and indeed the inevitability, of the eventual replacement of the present growth oriented polices of the major parties with a sustainable steady state economy. Contrary to the views of most economists and, dare I say, most politicians, economics cannot remain based on the arbitrary assumptions about people, society and nature. A new economics must be built on the real world and on the laws of nature.

What do we know of humanity's place in nature? For 99.9 per cent of our existence we have lived in intimate association with the natural world. This natural world is rapidly disappearing and may have passed from the experience of most people in less than another two generations. Yet this is the world to which evolution has adapted us. We have demonstrated our ability to survive in such a world. It is conjectural whether, as a species, we can survive in a world increasingly dominated by industrialisation and directed towards forever increasing the consumption and destruction of that natural world. Enough has been said on numerous occasions about population growth, resource depletion, species lost, greenhouse gas accumulation, ozone depletion, et cetera. I do not want to recite the list in more detail here but merely accept that the evidence is overwhelming that the industrial economic processes of the last few centuries cannot continue.

For over 20 years attempts to find other technically advanced life forms in our corner of the universe have been fairly vigorously pursued, so far without success. Bearing in mind the size and age of the universe, it seems almost certain that conditions suitable for life must exist in many places, and in some there should be life forms as technically advanced or more advanced than our own. The absence of any signal so far, together with limitations on space travel imposed by Einstein's relativity, suggest that planet earth is not only our origin but also our destiny.

What is our destiny? Cosmologists forecast that the conditions suitable for our type of life are likely to persist for at least another 500 million years. By evolutionary standards we are still a very young animal. Indeed, most of our life still lies before us. We have co-evolved with millions of other species over vast periods and now share this exceptional planet, with its unusual life sustaining properties rare in this cosmic precinct, with about 30 million other species. This animal Homo sapiens is at the very threshold of its life on the planet but already has exhibited some technical sophistication. But at the same time-and very recently-we have shown a strong tendency to apply this sophistication in ways damaging to the life support system on which we and all other living creatures depend. We could, if we chose, render the earth lifeless. The acquisition of this power places upon us the awful responsibility of so managing our own affairs-and that refers specifically to our economic affairs-that the slow and ponderous processes of evolution can continue to work themselves out without increasingly disruptive and intrusive human impact.

This is the context in which we must try to build our economic and other systems. These are the factors it is necessary for us to observe if we are to be free to properly fulfil our destiny. The biosphere reveals a system based on closed cycles and a tendency towards stability. In the last two centuries Homo sapiens has attempted to run increasingly open-ended systems which have moved the biosphere toward instability. We have adopted an open-ended economic model and an open-ended pattern of resource exploitation. Our longer view of history points us to the urgent need to re-establish closed, stable systems close to equilibrium. We must again become part of a dynamic steady state. We must recognise an economic model consistent with nature if we want freedom for ourselves and our children.

Where-and in some detail-are the flaws in the present growth oriented economic model? There are at least five quite fundamental flaws in a model which takes growth in gross national product (GNP) or gross domestic product (GDP) as its principal objective and as a surrogate measure of the welfare of a nation. GDP is the dollar value of all goods and services made in a country in a year. It roughly parallels consumption. Making GDP grow means making the dollar value of all goods and services consumed each year more than the dollar value consumed in the previous year after allowing for inflation. As growth is measured as a percentage year on year, the growth being attempted is exponential.

Firstly, there is no a priori reason, nor any basis for one in nature-and that should be our guide-why growth of GDP should be accepted as a guiding principle. This notion of growth hangs in an intellectual vacuum unconnected with anything but its own corollaries. Arguments about growth conducted within the paradigm of growth economics are tautological. Secondly, as an article of unproven and unprovable faith, the growth paradigm assumes infinite wants and infinite technological innovation to produce more and more goods and people world without end. It assumes that this is not only possible but desirable. Both assumptions can be shown to be false. Many scientifically illiterate economists pin their faith on the infinite capacity of science and technology forever to roll back the impediments to continued growth. Before getting carried away with the idea that the human mind is an ultimate resource that can generate endless growth, let us remember that, while certainly not reducible to physical or mechanical terms, the mind is not independent of the physical body. Frederick Soddy said:
No phosphorus, no thought.
Loren Eisley reminds us:
The human mind, so frail, so perishable, so full of inexhaustible dreams and hungers, burns by the power of a leaf.

Minds capable of such insight ought to be capable of showing more restraint towards leaves and phosphorus than is usually exhibited by our growth-bound economists. The restriction point in the entry of knowledge into the physical economy is through the availability of low-entropy resources. If there are no low-entropy resources there is no capital, regardless of knowledge, unless the second law of thermodynamics is abolished. Moreover, if endless consumption is so desirable, why do we spend over $10 billion each year on promotional advertising?

Thirdly, the peculiar accounting system used to calculate GDP counts costs as benefits. Recently it was said that some $32m would be spent on sand replenishment on the Gold Coast because New South Wales had interfered with longshore drift. That $32m to be spent in that way enters the national accounts as an addition to gross domestic product. The American economist Herman Daly puts it in a perceptive essay on this subject:

We take the real costs of increasing GDP as measured by the defensive expenditures incurred to protect ourselves from the unwanted side effects of production and add these expenditures to GDP rather than subtract them. We count the real costs as benefits-this is hypergrowthmania. Since the net benefit of growth can never be negative in this Alice-in-Wonderland accounting system, the rule becomes `grow forever', or at least until it kills you-and then count your funeral expenses as further growth. This is terminal hypergrowthmania. Is the water table falling? Dig deeper wells, build bigger pumps and up goes GDP! Mines depleted? Build more expensive refineries to process lower grade ores, and up goes GDP!

Beaches eroded? Cart sand to replenish them and up goes GDP. As we press against the carrying capacity of our physical environment, these extra effort and defensive expenditures-which are really costs masquerading as benefits-loom larger and larger. This creates the illusion of becoming better off when in actuality we are becoming worse off. We may already have passed the point at which the marginal cost of growth exceeds the marginal benefit. In that we might find an answer to the perception of most people in Australia today, who believe that they are worse off even though the economy continues to grow. This is not merely a matter of increasing inequity in the distribution of goods that are created; we may have a real reduction in those things ordinary people count toward the quality of their lives. Costs masquerading as benefits suggest one change that needs to be made to the growth model. Take the costs out and the adjusted accounts themselves should guide us into making more rational decisions. Such a course will produce productive shocks along the way.

Since coming to the Senate I have asked the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, a number of questions around this theme. For example, I asked where the $6 billion annual cost of motor vehicle accidents appeared in the national accounts. Senator Walsh told the Senate that these costs are indeed added to GDP. He went on to elaborate on the removal of some of these costs and said:

. . . to exclude medical costs borne by households would require more fundamental changes to the accounts-indeed, to the extent where it could touch off a spiral in which all of the gross domestic product gradually disappeared.

He could not have made more clear the point I am making here. It is true that it is difficult to decide precisely what is a benefit and what is a cost. An element of arbitrariness is impossible to avoid. However, note that the present system is extremely arbitrary, implicitly claiming that everything on which money is spent is a benefit. Wider public understanding of this arbitrariness would itself go a long way to dismantling the obsession with growth. Eighty per cent of population growth in Australia accrues to the capital cities. The increased costs of water, sewerage, electricity, telephones, roads, schools, police, air and noise pollution, loss of civil freedom, et cetera, made necessary by this growth-all these things that ordinary people correctly count as costs-are added to the gross domestic product. The public might view these things very differently if it understood that these same costs are used by treasurers and others as an index of improved quality of life.

Fourthly, the growth model measures throughput rather than stock. This contrasts markedly with how we order our personal lives. There we do not measure our well-being by how quickly we can spend our assets; nor do we equate it with the size of the effort required to maintain our physical lifestyle. Indeed, we quite sensibly seek to minimise the rate at which assets are consumed and effort expended. Why should we adopt the exact opposite view when we contemplate the welfare of a nation? Consider for a moment a stock of physical goods-houses, cars, refrigerators, et cetera-being maintained in a steady state; that is, a constant number by a maintenance throughput. Herman Daly said:

That this maintenance throughput as a cost is clearly seen by looking at each end of the pipeline. Inputs necessitate depletion, outputs necessitate pollution. Furthermore, the maintenance of the stock requires human labour, the sacrifice of leisure to production. To increase throughput for its own sake makes no sense . . .
Seen in this light, GDP becomes a largely irrelevant number, something to be minimised for a given stock not maximised.

Every company keeps a capital account as well as a cash flow account. GDP equates with a cash flow account. This nation-indeed, most nations-keeps no national capital account to keep track of the state of our natural resources. It follows that, as no value is put on iron ore in the ground or forest trees, we can believe or be made to believe that we become richer when these things are exploited. What really happens when iron ore or woodchips are exported unprocessed is that wealth is shifted from the capital account to the cash flow account, but because we keep no capital account wealth appears, as if by magic, in the cash flow account and we can believe that we have become richer. Amory Lovins said: `Whoever heard of developing a bank account by drawing money from it?'. Yet this is precisely what a lot of development entails.

A related corollary concerns those services which nature provides free-clean air and water and space. They are not, of course, counted in GDP. However, once these services are destroyed or removed and we must pay dollars for their replenishment, these dollars are counted as an addition to GDP. As I have indicated, recently $32m was set aside for the replenishment of sand on the Gold Coast. This had become necessary because New South Wales had interfered with the south-north longshore drift. The national accounts only became aware of this longshore sand drift service provided by nature after it had been destroyed. Money had to be spent to artificially restore it. The money went into the national accounts as a benefit. Certainly it may be difficult to put appropriate values on natural assets, but it is even more ludicrous to put no value on them at all and assume that nature will continue to provide them at no cost. I am not here suggesting that the best way to assess value is always in dollar terms. I merely point out that that is the way it is now done, but done very poorly so that the result is very misleading.

There are a number of ways it could be done better. For example, Mr Hawke, in his 28 July statement, which has been described as the greatest environment statement in the world, said that he would plant trees at a cost of $1 per tree. The Opposition countered this statement saying that it would cost between $12 and $17 to plant and nurture a tree up to the stage its continued growth is reasonably assured. We could start by putting this value on trees and showing in our capital account each year how much poorer we were by reason of the number of trees that we had lost.

Fifthly, a number of factors are allied with the growth model which serve to further buttress it. Both the Government and Opposition daily extol the terms: market forces, market determinism, the economy as an entity which must be served for its own sake, increasing competitiveness as a goal and deregulation. These, together with growth, form the foundation on which the Government and Opposition both build their economic model. Each of these notions is based on assumptions which are rarely, if ever, questioned. Government and Opposition believe with fundamentalist religious fervour in the sanctity of the market. This belief contains an a priori assumption that the operation of competitive greed will somehow serve the common good. Of course, that takes us right back to Adam Smith. Mathematics tells us that it is impossible to maximise two independent variables simultaneously. It follows that unless the variables, competitive greed and common good, are dependent, then the invisible hand supposed by generations of economists to guide greed toward good must be a figment of the same economists' imaginations.

Moreover, the market assumed by economists is one near equilibrium and one in which there are a large number of more or less equal players: one in which supply and demand by these players causes the market to see-saw about this hypothetical equilibrium. I use `hypothetical' in a pejorative sense, because a moment's reflection will cause everyone to realise that in that state the market is at its most unstable. Positive feedback determines that as one player gets a slight advantage, that advantage will be magnified and the market will hunt toward monopoly. Some years ago, John Blatt, professor of applied mathematics at the University of New South Wales, wrote a book called Dynamic Economic Systems in which he mathematically modelled the economists' market and showed that this instability was indeed a real fact of that market system. Needless to say, his work was not accepted by most economists. But apart from intuition and mathematical modelling, we have the observation of what happens in practice; markets do hunt towards monopolies or cooperative oligopolies with big players expending enormous efforts to close markets against competition.

The market model extolled by Government and Opposition is unreal; it does not exist. The attempt to apply its dictates produces social inequity and environmental despoliation. This is the model that Government and Opposition are coercing citizens, scientists, educational institutions and industry to serve. The most sinister and most destructive aspect of the market system is that it necessarily assumes that the value of something is the value which the market puts upon it. As we have already seen, this market system evaluation has a countercurrent relationship with the real world. The market places no initial value on clean water, clean air and space to live, which nature provides free. As these natural services are destroyed, they obtain value in the market system. The more rare and less accessible they become, the greater the value which the market places on them.

A recent advertisement in the Australian Financial Review made the point with sickening clarity. It explained the likely impact of greenhouse on world agriculture and encouraged investors to take advantage of greenhouse induced food shortages on the futures market. I believe this could be described as making a killing. The market system allows the rich to maintain access as the price escalates. This is the market system that Government and Opposition coerce the people and institutions of this country to serve.

Two further points need to be made about the market driven, growth oriented economic model. It is frequently asserted that we need a growing economy so that we can afford to look after the environment. A growing economy is one that is getting richer and can therefore afford to spend more to look after the environment. The flaw is that a growing economy is not necessarily a richer economy or one that can afford to spend more. For example, if a wife and mother stays at home and looks after her husband and children, her work is not counted towards GDP because it is unpaid. If she pays someone to carry out precisely the same duties, then that enters the national accounts as an addition to gross domestic product. But, quite clearly, that does not make society richer and more able to spend on environmental clean-up. If instead of eating at home we all ate in restaurants, GDP would rise by the difference in the cost. But that again does not make us any richer. The flaw is that, because GDP does not distinguish costs from benefits, there is no clear connection between growth of GDP and more money for discretionary spending-for instance, looking after the environment.

The point can perhaps be made most clearly by observing that what is spent on environmental clean-up is an addition to GDP. Therefore, it should follow that the more we spend on the environment, the more we can spend on the environment-that is, we could spend the same amount over and over again and obtain infinite environmental benefits.

The pressure for economic growth is inconsistent with environmental sustainability. The press for continuing economic growth necessarily leads to environmental despoliation and increasing global and local inequity. Traditional economics considers the inputs to production as land, capital and labour. Land today must be generalised to material resource. Capital, as we have seen, is stored low entropy and is composed of material resources and labour. Of course, labour refers to human labour. Thus there are really only two inputs to GDP-material resources and labour. Growth in GDP therefore means a growth in the consumption of one or both of these inputs. There are clearly limits to growth in consumption of both of these inputs and therefore there are limits to growth in GDP.

Exponential growth in material consumption has clear limits. Energy consumption is a direct cause of greenhouse gas emissions and escalating changes in the composition of the global atmosphere. Energy use is closely linked with the extraction and use of all other material resources. Continued growth in the consumption of material resources is incompatible with ecological sustainability. I refer to my opening remarks regarding the mixed messages which this Government is giving to industry. On the one hand, it is talking about continuing economic growth, continuing resource exploitation, and, on the other hand, it is talking about further protection of the environment and cutbacks in the emission of greenhouse gases of between 20 and 40 per cent by the turn of the century-clearly, incompatible goals.

Because we live in a society which is so heavily predicated on economic considerations, I believe the tools we must use to change direction must be, at least in the first instance, economic. The first task is to explode the myths of the present market growth system. Once fully apprised of the flaws, the stupidity and the inappropriateness of the present growth directed market system, sensible people will look for saner, less damaging and more sustainable alternatives. I believe that we need to establish a national capital account in which is recorded the value of minerals in the ground, forests and those services which nature now provides at no cost. As these resources are turned to cash flow, we would then see that we have not become richer except to the extent that we have added value to them from human input. We would see that the export of raw timber or woodchips adds very little, if anything, to the nation's wealth. We need also to redefine wealth as capital and not merely as cash flow. We need to disaggregate the costs and the benefits which currently are lumped together in GDP. We need to recognise that the market system is not an appropriate mechanism by which to make many decisions, that we need to make other decisions, put value on some resources, in ways which are not purely monetary.

Finally, the sustainable steady state economy which must replace the present growth model will seek to maintain some agreed stock of goods-that is, capital-with a throughput of resources which is minimised and sustainable indefinitely into the future. The steady state is not a static state. As technology advances, resources can be used more conservatively. Choice would determine whether to use a little more resource or to decrease further human impact on the planetary environment. (Extension of time granted) I find this a far more exciting prospect than living in a world hell bent on forever frenetically increasing material consumption and equating that increase with progress.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon the Senate is debating the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1989-90 and cognate Bills. I take the opportunity to say that I believe that Australians today should be questioning how much longer they are prepared to live with a Federal government that is increasingly putting Australia deeper and deeper into debt.
—`About three months' is the answer to that question.

—I hope that Senator Boswell's answer is correct. I am sure that everybody on this side of the chamber is working very hard to ensure that that is so. This Government's policies are putting Australia deeper and deeper into debt and that is something which affects every man, woman and child in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Since last year's Budget there has been a dramatic change in Australia's fortunes-not that it was not expected, but many commentators Australia-wide failed to note what the average Australian could have told them. It is getting increasingly hard to make ends meet in middle Australia and there is no let-up in sight. We have an inflation rate of 8 per cent and eternal price rises. As I do my shopping in the supermarket every weekend-and I feel sure that Senator Reynolds who is present has to do likewise, unless she gets her husband to do her shopping for her-I find that the prices of groceries are going up and up. To me, it is like a dog chasing its tail. As the prices go up, inflation also increases and we never seem to be able to get to the end of it.

This Government has indeed deserted middle Australia. It has deserted the men and women it relies on to produce the goods, and who keep paying tax so that this Government can continue with its many high spending policies and useless programs. Millions of average Australians have known for the last two or three years that this Government has been a failure as a manager of the economic affairs of this country. I say to honourable senators that millions of Australian families know more about the realities of economic life in Australia than do members of the Government and the Government's advisers. Indeed, they have proof of that.

In its six years in office the Hawke Labor Government has failed totally to live up to its commitment to the Australian family. In fact, I believe it has done quite the reverse. I refer to its high taxing policies, its continued support for high inflation-which, as I mentioned earlier, is now at 8 per cent-and high interest rates. I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that an inflation rate of 8 per cent is twice as high as that of our major competitors, and that is very damaging to industry as a whole.

This Government has also attacked traditional values. Through that attack the Government has actively jeopardised the continuous viability and stability of many families. A prime responsibility of any national government must be to ensure that the family and the institution of marriage remain the cornerstone of Australian society. The Hawke Labor Government is seriously undermining that priority. Income distribution is now less equitable than it was when Labor took office in March 1983. The top 10 per cent of income earners now receive 28.4 per cent of all income in Australia, while low and middle income earners have gone backwards. Real disposable income fell by 1.2 per cent in 1986-87, the first time in 30 years that this figure has gone backwards.

After six years of Labor government, 2.6 million people, one in every eight households, live in poverty. Seven hundred thousand Australians have fallen below the poverty line, and 440,000 children are living below the poverty line. What did the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promise regarding children living in poverty? He said that no Australian child would be living in poverty by 1990, yet there are up to 70,000 young Australians living on the streets.
Family values and living standards have been destroyed. The Government's record can only make a tragic myth of the many Hawke promises and commitments to Australian families. Just listen to this:
What concerns the ordinary Australian family is:
-that there should be jobs available now for parents and in the future for their children
-that they can purchase their own home at a reasonable cost and not have to face crippling rates
-that their children can receive an education which equips them in the best possible way for their lives ahead
-and above all that every Australian family has the opportunity to maintain and improve this standard of living-
high ideals certainly-
and that's where our efforts have been directed and continue to be directed.

Honourable senators will never believe it: these are the words of the Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, during his election policy speech in November 1984. They were words and nothing more. Indeed, the rhetoric does not match the action. Mr Hawke said:
This Government sets the welfare of the Australian family as its top priority.
As I said earlier, he also went on to say:
By 1990 no Australian child will be living in poverty.

We should note that Mr Hawke altered that statement recently to say that by 1990 no Australian child ought to be living in poverty. There is some difference between those statements. The members of the Australian public could be forgiven for being reduced to total cynicism about the promises of the Prime Minister and this Government because every Australian knows these commitments are not being met. No real attempt is being made to meet them. In fact the other day in the Courier-Mail I read an article which stated:
The poverty rate among Australian children was more than one in seven, a seminar was told yesterday.

The 15 per cent child poverty level was despite a promise by the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, that by 1990 no child would be in such a situation. NSW Council of Social Service officer Graham Jackson was speaking at the launch of a campaign to make Australians aware of the nature and extent of poverty and encourage them to take community and government action to eliminate it.

Families have living proof that the Government's commitments are not being met. They know that the $9.1 billion surplus announced in the Budget will once again be achieved mainly through a massive tax impost on working Australians. Let us remember that the total taxation on individuals has more than doubled under Labor from $23 billion in 1982-83 to $51 billion in 1989-90. Here, just let me say that when I was home over this weekend I had to do the wages for the men who work for us. One of our workmen gave me a bill for 171 hours-I think it was-worked over four weeks. When I worked out his wages I found that, although he had worked ever so many more hours during that four-week period than he had during the previous four weeks, he hardly got any more money because of the higher rate of tax that applied. That is exactly what is happening all the time.

In 1983 a person on the average wage paid a marginal tax rate of 30c in every extra dollar that he earned. Today this is 40 1/4c in the dollar, including the Medicare levy. I know too of a similar situation applying to some of the Commonwealth car drivers who often work over weekends. They say that they earn double time pay if they drive on a Sunday but they sometimes find that it is hardly worthwhile because they have to pay so much of the additional earnings in taxes. If the tax rate is 40 1/4c in the dollar that is understandable. A single income family on average earnings in March 1983 paid $84.65 tax each week. That is nearly 23 per cent of its income. In July 1990 that same family will be paying $156.74 tax each week- almost 26 per cent of its income. By July 1990 this family will be $56 a week worse off compared to the situation in March 1983. If we include higher home mortgage repayments that family will be $100 a week worse off. Let us face it: most families these days are paying very much higher home mortgage repayments. People are very fortunate if they have managed to be on the 13 1/2 per cent home interest repayment as a fixed level because I am afraid that every time the interest rates go up so too do the payments for homes.

Those statistics that I have just mentioned are not only an economic disgrace, they are a social disgrace. Families know about the Government's housing policies, policies which mean that the Government will be able to tell the Australian people that it so loves the Australian dream of home ownership that it has put it beyond the reach of ordinary Australians-a very sad state of affairs. Families know that under current Government policies the prices of virtually all groceries have risen dramatically in the past few years. I mentioned that a little earlier. Families know that there has been a 90 per cent increase in the taxation bite for single income families on average earnings. They know that our foreign debt has quadrupled over the last five years, that home ownership is now getting steadily beyond the reach of all but the relatively affluent people who are entering the home market for the first time. The Government then turns around and asks the Australian people to save. I ask: How can they save to get ahead? Labor's tax system discourages and penalises hard work, penalises savings and penalises investment.
For the sixth consecutive year this Government has retained its title as Australia's highest taxing government. Adam Smith said:
There is no art which one government sooner learns of another than that of draining money from the pockets of the people. They are themselves-
that is, governments-

already and without any exception the greatest spendthrifts in society. Let them look well after their own expenses and they may safely trust private people with theirs. If their own extravagance does not ruin the State that of their subjects never will.

This present Labor Government is working hard to make sure that these words Adam Smith said in 1776 are true today. The family is the building block of society. It is a nursery, a school, a hospital, a leisure centre, a place of refuge and a place of rest. It encompasses the whole of society. It fashions our belief. It is the preparation for the rest of our life. It is for these reasons that governments should ensure that their policies should serve to nurture the family and its structure and not to undermine it.

Unfortunately, today we see that many women are unable to care for their children because of the tremendous financial pressure placed upon single income families. In a society that is becoming ever more sensitive to women's rights, what is to be said of the rights of women who want to be full time wives and mothers? Is it fair that they fall victim to a taxation system that discriminates against women who choose not to leave home in order to earn a separate income? Without wishing to impinge on the freedom of women seeking fulfilment in employment and activities outside the home, adequate measures should be taken to recognise and financially assist the role of mothers who choose to stay at home. I believe that such measures should be taken now.

Unfortunately, apart from the economic hardship that has been imposed on families, this Government has directly undermined traditional family values, further threatening the stability of marriage and family life. It has provided for equal status for de facto partners, compared to married partners, for government benefits and allowances. It has supported programs that encourage homosexuality. It has introduced a homeless allowance for 16- and 17-year-olds. This can directly encourage the splitting up of families for economic reasons, particularly in the case of low income families. The Government has discriminated against single income families in the tax system, forcing both parents of an increasing number of families into the work force, and therefore jeopardising the home environment, particularly affecting young people. It has supported the pornographic video industry, by refusing to support legislation banning the sale of pornographic videos from the Australian Capital Territory.

The Budget, of course, reflects the way that this nation has changed, both socially and economically. Government members place great store on the small and delayed increases in welfare payments to our needy, the aged, the handicapped and the homeless. Increased welfare payments simply point to the failure of government. Increased welfare is a sad reflection of a sick economy and the need to support increasing numbers of desperate people. Under current government policies, traditional services are struggling to survive. Public and private hospitals are under pressure. Aged persons' facilities, many of them established through the voluntary effort of communities and the generosity of individuals, are under threat of closure.

Finally, I refer briefly to a matter of great concern to me. I have mentioned this in the Senate on a number of occasions. Our road system is in a deplorable state. I remind honourable senators that families, whether living in the city or in the country, use the road system regularly for work and for leisure. The road system is being used heavily at the moment as Australia suffers the crippling effects of the current pilots strike. All senators would know as well as I do that a tremendous number of fatalities have occurred just recently on roads that are not of a good standard.

I suppose that one cannot attribute all these accidents to the state of the roads, but certainly many problems are caused by roads that are too narrow, for example. When large transports and buses are travelling towards one another some horrific accidents can result, such as those that we have read about recently in the papers. We have seen reports of these on television, and one's heart is nearly turned over. This is especially so when one sees someone like the gentleman on television-Colin Ormesher, I think his name was-who had lost nearly all his family. His relatives had come out from England. It just about made me cry while I was watching him on television, it was so sad.

Labor has cut road funding by over 30 per cent in real terms since it came to office. The increase in this year's Budget represents only 9.5 per cent over the miserly 1988-89 allocation. I suppose this is one of the reasons why the roads are deteriorating. The most recently indexed increases in fuel excise alone netted the Government an estimated additional $200m, none of which, I regret to say, has been earmarked for road funding. In 1989-90, total revenue from fuel excise will increase by 9.3 per cent, to $5,645m. So the apparent increase of 9 per cent in road expenditure is not a just return on the increased amount that the motorist will be paying at the petrol pump. In fact, I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that this Government will still be taking extra as the motorist fills his tank.

I refer to an advertisement that appeared in Queensland papers. At the beginning of the advertisement, the first words `This is how Federal road funding has been going for six years' are printed back to front-and at first I wondered what it was all about. The next part of the advertisement states, `Two cents would turn it around'. The advertisement was placed by the Royal Automobile Club of Queensland, and it is very sad that it has to keep on advertising to tell people of the need that exists for more money for roads. The advertisement states:
If you're a motorist you'd be well aware that Federal road funding is going in the wrong direction.
But don't worry. We're not asking you-
that is, the people of Queensland-
for any more money.
You're already paying about 30 cents to the Federal Government in petrol tax for every litre you're pouring into your car. And that's enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is more than half.

—Yes, it is more than half. It is a sorry state of affairs, and we must keep drawing people's attention to this so that they will realise that we need a change of government badly in Queensland-in Australia, I beg your pardon!
—You are right, Senator!
—The article continues:

SPEECH.PARA: What you should be worried about though is that the Federal Government is trickling only about five and a half cents of this back into road improvements.
The Federal Minister for Land Transport will tell you that his Government has increased the level of road funding this year to keep up with inflation. That's true.

What he's not telling you is that, because of inflation and previous funding cuts, we're still $500 million short of the amount spent on roads in 1983/84. That was the last time that there was any worthwhile increase in Federal funding for roads.
In real terms this means we are now about 30 per cent worse off.

All they are asking for is 2c out of the 30c that motorists are already paying in order to improve our roads. The Labor Government will be taking extra as the motorist fills his tank, and we must realise that that is the case. I must certainly emphasise here that it is the Federal Government that we are concerned about when it comes to the matter of bad roads. As far as I am concerned, the Queensland Government is doing a very good job indeed. The worst thing that the people in Queensland could do would be to vote in a Labor government in Queensland, because people would find that the same things would happen in Queensland as are happening federally now.

As Labor's willingness to tax the motorist has increased, its willingness to spend on roads has decreased. The Government's failure to produce a proper return of the fuel excise collections to road funding is particularly culpable, since 70 per cent of domestic trade is carried by road. It is expected that by the turn of the century that figure will have doubled and that the number of vehicles will have increased by 60 per cent.

An increase of 9.5 per cent is simply not enough to provide the essential road infrastructure to sustain the growth in our road traffic safely and efficiently. For primary industry, the one sector which has the capacity to improve our trade balance and which, of course, offers the greatest potential for diversity, value adding and general productivity increases, these cuts only increase the burden in its attempt to make ends meet. In fact, the burden is becoming too hard for all Australian families. In short, six years of the Federal Labor Government have been a total disaster for the nation, especially for the security and future of Australian families. The record and the facts are indisputable. The tragedy is that there is no sign that the Government has any intention of making serious and urgently needed changes in policy to help ordinary Australians and their families.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1989-90, Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1989-90 and Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1989-90. As Senator McMullan said earlier, this debate gives honourable senators the opportunity to range across the sphere of economic decision making of this Government and to elaborate on other matters of importance within the community. I acknowledge the contribution that the previous speaker, Senator Bjelke-Petersen, made to the debate. She acknowledged that there was a real need to change the Government in Queensland. We heartily endorse that view.
—Hear, hear!

—I thank Senator Reynolds. I am sure that in five weeks time Wayne Goss will ensure that this comes about. To get back to the debate before the Senate, the 1989-90 Budget is the continuation of seven years of sound economic policy under the Hawke Government. Those seven years have not been easy. In fact, they have been very difficult years in which the Government has fought to reduce the levels of inflation and unemployment. We have succeeded magnificently in both spheres. We have done it because of the social justice policy of the Australian Labor Party, the Cabinet and the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: During the last seven years Australia has experienced the highest level economic growth among the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development member nations. It has also achieved record Budget surpluses into the bargain. We have also seen a major restructuring of Australian industry in the last seven years, preparing Australia to stand on her own feet in the face of international trade competition. I will refer to a few remarkable facts a little later in my speech in order to give a backdrop to the long awaited coalition's taxation and spending policies which were outlined some three weeks ago. I will focus on those policies tonight.

On the one hand, we have seen remarkable achievements under Labor. They are even more remarkable, given the appalling legacy left to the people of Australia by the Fraser Government. On the other hand, we have the terrifying prospect of a Peacock-Hewson government actually implementing the coalition's Economic Action Plan-a plan which no doubt strikes fear into the hearts of all fair-minded Australians and even, no doubt, the more self-interested Australian, for ultimately it means economic ruin for the nation. To be poor, black or chronically ill, or to contemplate life should the coalition win the next election, can only mean despair-a real horror story.

It is my intention tonight to look at the implications and ramifications of such policies for ordinary Australians should they ever be implemented. The best way to do this is to look at what happened the last time the conservatives were given the opportunity to govern and to compare that with the sound economic alternative and salvation offered and delivered under Labor for the last seven years. The Budget, which we are speaking about tonight, is the culmination of that. Australians will then be in a good position to assess the coalition's Economic Action Plan for what it really is-inequitable, illogical, politically naive, vote grabbing, greedy and self-indulgent.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: we are debating the Appropriation Bills. This is a debate on the Government's monetary policy. The good senator is debating the coalition's policy, which is in complete contradiction to the debate that is listed on the program tonight. SPEECH.PARA: In order to get a real picture of the contribution that Labor has made to Australia and to the economics of Australia, we have to go back some time. We have to go back to the last time the Opposition was in government. We do not have to go back too far-only to 1983. For the purposes of this debate, I will outline some of the statistics relating to that time. I know that Senator Boswell and Opposition senators will not want to be reminded that in 1983 unemployment was 11 per cent and on the increase-on the up and up. Factory doors were closing, particularly in the manufacturing sector. Investment was negligible. There was only a little Japanese investment and that was in the coal industry. In the last year of the Fraser Government, 80,000 young people's jobs disappeared. The future of Australia was tossed on to the scrap heap. In the entire life of the conservative Fraser- National Party Government, payments to families for children were increased on only one occasion. That is disgraceful, considering that it was in government for seven years. The government deficit was more than $9 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, again I raise a point of order. I draw attention to the honourable senator's speech. You pointed out in respect of my last point of order that he was making comparisons between the Government's policy and the Opposition's policy. I ask you again to rule on the point of order as Senator McKiernan has not made one remark regarding the debate that is listed on the paper.
—Second reading debates can be fairly wide ranging. There is no point of order.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. Only one child in three finished high school; 270,000 children were dependent on adults who were receiving the unemployment benefit; 147,500 people aged between 20 and 24 were unemployed; two million Australians did not have access to adequate medical cover; and the inflation rate was 11.5 per cent and showing no signs of easing. At that time, all the economic signals-the inflation rate, levels of growth and investment, the number of apprenticeships and the number of new housing starts-indicated that Australia was in a rotten shape.

SPEECH.PARA: I will move to the present. In the last seven years there has been a dramatic transformation in Australia. This has come about because of the good sense of the Australian people. That good sense was shown in 1983 when they elected Labor into office. Since then we have built a solid basis for society by providing opportunity, fairness, equality and security for all people regardless of their origins or circumstances. To realise this vision of a just society, especially given the massive numbers of people who had been marginalised by the policies of the Fraser Government, Labor had to provide solid, sustainable economic growth. Labor has encouraged productive investment and has dramatically reduced the massive unemployment inherited from the previous conservative Government. Unlike the conservatives the Labor Government would not tolerate massive levels of unemployment. The previous conservative government used recessionary tactics in a vain attempt to keep the inflation rate low. The Peacock-Hewson duo-now joined by Mr Howard-will repeat the exercise, given half a chance.

The basic rationale for the Hawke Labor Government's policy and the Budget as a continuation of that economic policy has been the driving force behind the reform of the taxation system, the introduction of the family allowance supplement, the child support scheme, award restructuring and Medicare. These are but a few of the initiatives implemented by the Federal Labor Government since 1983. All the initiatives have been based on the premise that only through a growing economy can effective assistance be provided to the needy in a community. That is not to say that the Opposition is not aware of social justice. Indeed, it paid lip service to it in the document released last year by the then Leader of the Opposition, John Howard, known as `Futile Diversions', or something of that ilk. There is no mention of social justice in the current Economic Action Plan. Perhaps we should applaud and recognise that honesty.

Despite all the dead lead in the saddle bags, even the Opposition realises that a policy which aims to open divisions in Australian society, a policy which attacks the poorest, the most marginalised in the community, that calls them bludgers, that condemns the poor and disadvantaged merely for being poor and disadvantaged, is an insult to the idea of social justice. The notions of a fair distribution of economic resources, equal access to essential services such as housing, health care and education, equal rights in civil, legal and industrial affairs and the opportunity for all to participate in personal development, community life and decision-making are alien to those who sit opposite. Under a coalition Government those who are most disadvantaged in our midst-the unemployed, families, invalids, the disabled, Aborigines-will be made to pay for the government privileges delivered to high income earners. That is the conservatives' understanding of the principle of social justice: take from the needy and give to the greedy.

Let us look at the record of Labor over the last seven years. In the area of employment, education and training we have created 1.6 million jobs, a 24.7 per cent increase since 1983. Ninety per cent of those jobs have been created in the private sector; 55 per cent have been created for women. Unemployment has fallen by 30.2 per cent over the same period. Teenage unemployment has been halved. The median duration of unemployment has been almost halved: 26.1 weeks in 1984 and 15 weeks in July 1989. It is still too high. We will not rest on our laurels and the Budget will ensure that we do not. The number of people receiving unemployment benefit has fallen from its peak of 670,000 in 1984 to 463,000 in October this year. The number of apprenticeships has risen by over 50 per cent to 54,000 annually. Thirty-two thousand young Australians have now taken advantage of the Australian traineeship system. Award restructuring offers unprecedented numbers of workers for the first time in their working lives the opportunity to participate in new and more rewarding employment opportunities.

As I mentioned at the start of this speech, school retention rates have risen from a disgraceful aggregate of one in three young people finishing secondary school in 1983 to two-thirds of young people finishing secondary school in 1989. Since 1983, Labor has created an additional 43,000 places in higher education. By the end of the 1989-1991 triennium, an additional 110,000 places in tertiary institutions will have been created-a massive 43 per cent increase over the 1983 levels. They are but a few of the achievements and they relate to only one portfolio.

In the Social Security portfolio we really see what a commitment to social justice principles can mean for the more disadvantaged members of our community. I believe that Brian Howe will be remembered for many years to come for his leadership and the achievements of his Department in this area. The policies that have been introduced have been singularly successful because, as I said earlier, Labor knows that social security payments alone will not solve the problems faced by many low income families. Since 1983 we have seen the introduction of the family allowance supplement and the establishment, for the first time, of standards of adequacy for child payments, benchmarks, to 15 per cent of the combined married rate of pension for children aged less than 13 years and 20 per cent of the combined married rate of pension for children aged 13 to 15 years of age. In recognition of the importance of ensuring that these increases are not eroded over time, the Government-also for the first time-will index annually both the family allowance and the family allowance supplement. This will ensure that the child poverty benchmarks are met permanently so that low income families with children need not slip back into poverty. The coalition has been unable to give a commitment that the indexation arrangements would continue under a conservative government.

Another initiative of the Hawke Government is the introduction of the child support scheme, a scheme that ensures that non-custodial parents meet their responsibilities to support their children. We have eased social security income tests to address poverty traps. Social security recipients have been encouraged to supplement their payments through part-time work. The Hawke Government also introduced new programs-jobs, education and training (JET) and Newstart-to increase the access to training programs by sole parents and long term unemployed, enabling them to overcome barriers to employment and develop a springboard for more active, satisfying lives. Another Hawke Government initiative is the extension of occupational superannuation across the work force so that it is not just the prerogative of a privileged few. Labor has also met its longstanding commitment to raise the age pension to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings.

Under Labor the taxation system has also undergone unheard of reform, despite the noisy, self-interested objections of a previously privileged majority. The reforms mean that the taxation system now provides greater equity and efficiency by broadening the tax base; taxing capital gains; effectively pursuing tax avoidance and evasion which, incidentally, previously was the only growth area under the former conservative Government; and by reducing marginal tax rates. Labor's tax reform package has restored incentive and neutrality to the tax system, establishing an improved economic future for the nation.

I give a few more examples, if more are needed, of Labor's achievements since it took office in 1983. We have introduced the home and community care program for the aged and the disabled, providing these people with real alternatives to institutionalised care. We have introduced Medicare and facilitated the building of a million new homes. We have increased funding for Aboriginal programs by 47 per cent in real terms. We have increased the number of child-care places from a measly 46,000 in 1983 to 114,000 this year, with another 30,000 places to be available by 1992-a 200 per cent increase since 1983. Commonwealth assistance for public housing has more than doubled, as has funding for disability services. The expenditure on the children's services program has increased from $62m in 1982-83 to $232m this financial year.

These initiatives are remarkable in themselves, but they are even more remarkable, given that they have been introduced at a time when we have seen a huge decline in Government spending as a proportion of the gross domestic product. While Government spending as a proportion of gross domestic product has dropped to its lowest point in 16 years, the percentage of the Budget devoted to social justice programs has actually increased. An inherited $9 billion deficit in 1983 has been turned into a $9 billion surplus in 1989, the third consecutive year in which a surplus has been realised. I could continue to list many equally noteworthy achievements by the Government in a variety of portfolios from Transport and Communications to Veterans' Affairs, from the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to Consumer Affairs.

I turn now to the alternatives in the Opposition's Economic Action Plan, which aims to mangle and make mincemeat of the achievements to which I have just referred. The most needy in the community no longer will be targeted for efficient assistance. The cycle of poverty and welfare dependency will spin again as positive policies are ejected. The Opposition is hell-bent in a blatant and undisguised manner on winning votes by making the underprivileged the target of its wrath and callous proposals. In order to pay for their promises to the Elliotts, the Hewsons and their New Right mates, the conservatives intend to crush those who are already the most vulnerable. To those people who are allowing themselves a hope for the future as a consequence of programs such as jobs, education and training and Newstart, which are designed specifically for sole parents and the long term unemployed, the conservatives are saying, `You are good for nothing; you are only bludgers'. They are saying also, `Only those who can afford it have the right to be chronically ill.' The conservatives believe mistakenly that they can win government by playing on the bigotry of a small number of swinging voters.

Unfortunately, bigotry exists in our society. To prove that, one has only to ask a former Country-Liberal Party candidate for the Northern Territory about the rednecks and the white supremacists. Everybody hopes that the conservatives will not win the next election. They cannot win because, even if the conservatives do not understand concepts such as equity, justice and a fair go for all, the Australian electorate does. It will not take a giant leap back into the economic dark ages of unemployment, inflation and tax avoidance and evasion of the late 1970s and early 1980s. The Australian electorate cannot be fooled into believing that politics is an acceptable substitute for policies.

The Opposition's Economic Action Plan will be exposed for what it is: bigoted, shortsighted, inequitable and racist. What does it offer? The alternative government offers: the abolition of Jobstart; the abolition of the industry training support schemes; the abolition of Skillshare; and the abolition of a number of other employment, education and training programs that are designed specifically to meet the needs of rural areas, including the innovative rural education and training program; the rural education access program; the rural community-based education program; and the marketing skills program. If they were implemented, those proposals would be devastating for people in country areas, where unemployment is generally felt harder and where training opportunities are less numerous. It is further evidence of how out of touch the tories are with the needs and expectations of rural Australia. Those proposals, combined with the plan to privatise the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) operations, would have no other consequence for the rural unemployed than total disaster. Very few of the services that are presently provided by the CES in rural areas could be provided by private enterprise. Ultimately, rural communities would be left without any appropriate employment and training services.

The conservatives propose also to move all of those who have been unemployed for nine months or more off unemployment benefits and onto special benefits. However, no definition of the eligibility criteria has been provided for those people who would achieve and receive those special benefits. The tests that exist at the moment under the Labor Government are very rigorous. Under a conservative government, one could anticipate that those people who are unfortunate enough to be rendered unemployed and who are unable to gain employment within nine months may have to dispose of a number of assets before they can obtain those special benefits.

The conservatives intend to abolish the Occupational Health and Safety Commission. They want to massively reduce the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio, particularly in relation to employment, education and training, which are the only hopes that most Aboriginal people have of ever lifting themselves out of a desperate cycle of poverty. Despite the fact that, in 1989, 11 per cent of Aborigines who are aged 15 years or more have never attended school, the coalition plans to massively slash assistance in that area. Although some achievements have been made under the Labor Government, there have not been enough. Under the Hawke Administration the retention rate for Aboriginal and Islander students in secondary schools has doubled and the number of tertiary graduates has trebled. However, more needs to be done because the figures are fairly appalling. I fear that the gains that have been achieved would be short-lived if the coalition were to win office at the next election, especially when they are combined with the severe reductions that are planned for sewerage, water and housing programs for Aboriginal people. Those programs aim to guarantee basic quality of life standards for all Australians.

The Opposition's Economic Action Plan contains good news for the wealthy. It proposes to abolish the capital gains tax, with a windfall going pretty well straight into the pockets of those people who have largely escaped from the wage restraint that has been experienced by the average Australian. It would go also into the pockets of those who have benefited greatly from the recent property and share boom or those who have already received the biggest cuts in their marginal tax rates. For example, John Elliott would be $17m richer under the proposal, whereas the effect on at least 95 per cent of the Australian population inevitably would be far less money being made available for the education of their children, the maintenance of roads and the care of their elderly. However, they would still be responsible for funding Elliott's child-care rebate. No mention has been made in the Economic Action Plan of the sums that would be allocated to road funding.

The plan also proposes to replace the higher education contribution system with a yearly $1,200 upfront charge for tertiary study, which would effectively mean that only the children of the wealthy could afford to undertake a degree. Under a conservative government, sole parents, Aborigines and people from disadvantaged working class and even middle-class backgrounds would be unable to afford to undertake tertiary study. The plan also proposes to scrap 30,000 new child-care places, thereby forcing thousands of families out of government funded child-care centres, out of jobs and onto welfare. Without affordable child-care, many in the community have no choice but to stay at home and to care for their children, despite their wish to enter or remain in the paid work force.

Another bright idea of the conservatives entails subjecting those who are on sickness benefits to monthly medical examinations. Any savings that may be made in that respect probably would be far outweighed by the cost of those examinations, assuming that enough medical practitioners were available to undertake them. Perhaps that is just a result of a reciprocal deal that has been worked out between doctors and those in opposition to provide some funding for the next election.

The Opposition's plan also proposes to deny migrants access to unemployment benefits, sickness benefits and invalid pensions for the first 12 months after arrival in Australia. That is proof of the Opposition's callous disregard for the different circumstances in which people may find themselves through no fault of their own. I suppose that we should be grateful that we have seen only one policy instead of two-one policy for Asian migrants and another for non-Asian migrants. Heaven forbid if, not long after arriving in Australia, a family of migrants were involved in a serious car accident or if the breadwinner were the victim of a terminal illness.

The coalition proposes to reduce payments to the States by $300m, which would once again hit the disadvantaged the hardest because they are the most likely to be dependent upon the State government services that are financed from those payments. Although it is not specifically mentioned in the Economic Action Plan, funding to local government is linked to funding to the States. Local authorities are virtually guaranteed their share of cuts in allocations.

Perhaps one commendable aspect of the entire policy is the decision not to repeal the Hawke Government's decision to tax the profits in the goldmining industry, thereby making that industry subject to the same taxation arrangements as apply to all other Australian industries. We are told that the big emphasis is on families, but no definition of a family has been supplied. Two weeks ago, on 16 October, during the Australian Broadcasting Commission's AM radio program, Brian Howe said:

It's very much a question of which families, isn't it? There's nothing there for families with people unemployed. There's nothing there for black families. Migrant families are very much the subject of attack, as are poor and low income families. I don't see that as a families' package.
