SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are considering the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill and related Bills. In any consideration of the Budget proposals of the Hawke Labor Government, I cannot think of anything more typical of the situation in which the nation finds itself at the moment than Darwin Airport. We have in the Darwin Airport a totally inadequate facility that for years and years has been the subject of procrastination by a Federal Government about the dedication and the commitment that it will give in any funding to the north of Australia. We are well aware that the Hawke Labor Government has made major announcements about the Darwin Airport: that its construction timetable is to be kick-started in the near future and that it is to be given an injection of capital works that will enable it to be the provider of a major facility for the future of northern Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: But just where is that future at the moment? The current airline pilots dispute would have us all in an absolute quandary about whether there is a future use to which a terminal such as Darwin Airport could properly be put. Later in my remarks I will make particular reference to the important tourist industry of northern Australia. It is the very impotency, or the symbolism, of Darwin Airport at the moment that makes me turn my attention to the Budget and ask: What is its purpose? What is its direction? Where is it going? What will it provide? What facilities will be carried forward into the future? I am afraid that, when it comes to this project, all of the hype, the promises and the commitments of the Hawke Labor Government fall on very shallow fields. As I said, I believe that the impotency of the Government becomes paramount when we consider the 1989 Federal Budget.

There are so many areas that we would like to take the time to address and on which to consider where we are going. Many people in the electorate are making competing demands not only on government but also on many of the facilities of State governments and local governments. They are looking to the Federal Administration for some degree of leadership, some degree of commitment, some degree of hope, and all of that is totally failing.

Darwin Airport is merely one example. Let me move several hundred kilometres south-east from the Darwin Airport and take honourable senators to the Kakadu National Park. Again we need to look very carefully at the policies and proposals of the Hawke Labor Government. In the Budget proposals we see estimates of income that will be received by a rise in the fees received by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service (ANPWS) for tourist visitation to Kakadu. But that cannot and will not be achieved because, as I have said, the commitment to solving the current pilots dispute, which rests squarely on the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), will result in disastrous consequences for the Kakadu area. The Budget figures that we saw with regard to fees for the Kakadu National Park just cannot be anticipated.

What about the Government's commitments to so many other areas in that great park? Many years ago, a cattle station called Munmarlary was amalgamated into the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service administration. That property has been allowed to fall into extensive disrepair by the ANPWS, so much so that, where it could be providing major facilities for the Aboriginal traditional owners of the area and providing business opportunities for the Aborigines and for the Territory generally across the tourism industry, we have seen the Government completely walk away from any responsibility in that area.

If we look at service agencies of government such as those in the Department of Administrative Services (DAA), in particular the Australian Construction Services, we see that there is a commitment to commercialise or normalise many of the operations of that Department. For example, I refer to the commitment to architectural and engineering facilities that are to be provided in the various regions of DAA throughout Australia. What is happening with the changes in this area? Recently, in the Senate Estimates hearings I was able to ascertain that the Department has been told, `Get out there into the field and compete with private industry'. But compete on what basis? For example, where the Government is making commitments to major civil works projects throughout Australia and is inviting commercial and competitive tenders, it is then saying to the various wings of the Australian Construction Services, `Yes, your various branches can also be involved in those tenders in cooperation with the large building contractors or construction firms'. So what do we see? We see projects in which two or three State divisions enter into partnerships with competing tenderers. What is the end result of that? It is that Government funds are being squandered; Government funds are being wasted by branches of the same Department putting up similar facilities in different consortiums around Australia.

Take the firefighting protection services for Commonwealth assets such as those at airports or Army facilities. Again I use the example of Darwin, where the Department of Administrative Services has decided that it would rather move its staff resources into firefighting protection of Commonwealth assets than use the traditional form of contractors and consultants that it has been able to engage at very competitive rates. The Department says that it is trying to rationalise, save money and enter into facilities of that nature, but instead what does it do? It rips the contracts away from those contractors and brings in a bureaucracy to run that type of venture.

Several days ago, the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) made an announcement about the satisfactory negotiations between the Australian Government and the Indonesian Government on the Timor Gap treaty, which will open up oil and gas exploration fields to the north of Darwin. Yes, the facilities to be put in place are well worth the type of announcement that was made. I am pleased to welcome that sort of announcement. But at the same time, if we look at the policies of the Hawke Labor Government in its commitment to mining in northern Australia, we have to ask: Why, then, the deferment of uranium mining in the north of Australia? Why a dedication and commitment to a three-mine policy that will in effect thwart the economic development of northern Australia, which development can be carried out in all consciousness of the environmental and safety factors that have to be taken into account? There are jobs to be had by the development of the uranium industry, but the Hawke Government says no, it cannot face up to these important onshore facilities. Because of the international treaties and arrangements, the Government can enter into negotiations and treaties that are very worthwhile offshore. But try to break the three-mine uranium policy of the Australian Labor Party: No way. This has to be deferred until after the next Labor conference.

In recent weeks in this chamber and in the House of Representatives we have seen the debates with regard to the development of Coronation Hill. Under a very obvious threat from the Australian Conservation Foundation and a number of other groups with very particular and vested interests, the Government has walked away from the proper, managed, proven, economically and environmentally sound projects that would provide jobs, that would provide an economic stability for northern Australia and, in fact, for all people throughout Australia.

It is interesting to weigh up the differences in the economic approaches of the Hawke Labor Government and the Opposition. In recent weeks we have had announcements of new economic and tax policies that would be implemented by a Federal Liberal- National Party. These policies give a commitment and a promise that an extra $2,000m will be put into the pockets of families each year. Gains for families would include child rebate of at least $200 per child, a new rebate for child-care worth between $10 and $20 a week, and an opportunity for a spouse to earn more and still get the dependent spouse rebate. Under such a policy, gains for taxpayers would include a commitment to give back extra tax paid by those pushed up the tax scale because of inflation and a commitment to reduce tax scales in our first term of office.

The Liberal and National parties would give a far greater degree of commitment to the important area of small business-an area sadly neglected by the Hawke Labor Government-by scrapping Labor's capital gains tax and replacing it with a fairer speculative gains tax which would phase out after five years. As a commitment to the elderly, probably one of the areas that we are all very mindful of as we all get older year by year--

TALK.START.PARA: —Speak for yourself.

—I am not just speaking for myself; I am speaking for many people in the community in saying that there is a need for a much fairer application of the assets test and a deferred pension plan for those who wish to continue working beyond retirement age and ultimately receive a higher pension. The Liberal and National parties' policies, by comparison with those of the Hawke Labor Government, aim to ease the pressure on families, to protect the elderly, to give small businesses a fair go and to stop people rorting the system. Indeed, no-one in genuine need would suffer. The announced Liberal and National parties' policies are not, as described by my political colleague in the Northern Territory, Labor member Warren Snowdon, a cynical political stunt. I can assure Mr Snowdon that my colleagues and I make no apologies for promising to help millions of hardworking people who are bearing the brunt of six years of a Labor government. We certainly have a commitment to those people of middle Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Many comments have been made on the Budget but we have to ask: Are these measures aimed at reducing government inefficiency across the board by cutting out unnecessary spending, wastage and red tape? It seems to be endemic that after six years of Labor we have forgotten that the important principle is to look after people in the suburbs. Community reaction was probably best summed up in an editorial in the Centralian Advocate newspaper about a week ago. It stated:

It is high time to give middle Australia a fair go. This forgotten class has been milked for all it is worth by pressure groups and minority lobbies. This so-called silent majority are not prepared to remain silent for much longer.

That is where a very strong and deliberate comparison can be easily drawn between the Hawke Labor Government's budgetary commitments and those that the Liberal and National parties would implement in government.

We also need to ask: What areas of portfolio adjustment would have to be made? Andrew Peacock, the Leader of the Opposition, and so many shadow ministry members have gone into considerable detail to isolate and work out how the Liberal and National parties' commitment to a new tax package could be achieved-so successfully, as I am sure all honourable senators would be aware, that in the last week or so the polls have shown very dramatic turns away from the stalemate and the position that the Labor Government has got us into towards the promise and commitment of the Liberal and National parties and the faith that the community can have in the policies of a Liberal-National government.

An area of personal interest to me, which I have pursued in this Senate for the past two years because of the pressures and commitments in my electorate, the Northern Territory, is the portfolio of Aboriginal Affairs. The Liberal and National parties quite openly admitted that they could see the opportunity to save about $100m or, I remind the Senate, 10 per cent of a total Budget worth nearly $1,000m of current commitment to Aboriginal affairs. Some commentators and some politicians have come out crying on that issue. The Senate should bear in mind that this saving of $100m is actually less than the increase announced in the last Labor Budget for this portfolio. Our plan is to save money by reducing government inefficiency, cutting unnecessary spending, wastage and red tape, and coordinating State and Commonwealth programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you really believe that?

—Yes, I do; I would not be here with this sort of commitment if I did not. As Senator Aulich, as a former Chairman of Estimates Committee E, would be well aware, successive inquiries in the past 12 months into the administration of the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio have proven-as my experience certainly has-and have squashed any doubts, that that sort of target can be achieved.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate Estimates hearings of several weeks ago gave very important consideration to this portfolio. I invite honourable senators to pay particular regard to the report that will be handed down in the near future as a result of the deliberations of the October 1989 Estimates. I make no apology for putting some 600 questions on notice concerning the portfolio this year. The range of answers that were given need very careful academic but, more importantly, political study by Ministers of the Crown because they highlight time and again the areas where policy direction has been misguided and where there has been very considerable waste and duplication of expenditure. As I said earlier, the Hawke Labor Government has demonstrated a very deliberate different emphasis across this portfolio from the commitment that the Liberal and National parties would make. There are many particular and individual instances that would be very easy to highlight across that portfolio. I draw honourable senators' attention in particular to the Hansard record of Estimates Committee E of 10 October 1989, when we spent an entire day, from 10 a.m. to 11 p.m., thoroughly scrutinising and deliberating on the portfolio of Aboriginal Affairs. That was in addition to the information so widely available through all the questions put on notice.

Certainly, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission can take credit for having improved their game in the past 12 months. But frankly it is still not good enough. The performance indicators applied to such important and necessary areas of service delivery show that they have failed time and again in being of real benefit to Aboriginal people throughout Australia. Whether they live in urban communities on the eastern seaboard, whether they live in traditional and ceremonial types of Aboriginal communities-the areas I am familiar with in the Northern Territory-or whether they live among the pressures of different groups throughout Australia, there are so many examples of where the Government has got it wrong. The Government and its agency, the Aboriginal Development Commission, have failed the Aboriginal constituencies, that they so piously claim they are serving, with this expenditure of over $900m per annum.

There are 230,000 Aborigines in Australia. This Parliament has for many years been giving a commitment of funds of that order. The test of the expenditure in that area should be whether we end up with programs that are helping people in terms of health, education, welfare, business improvement and community relations. Instead, well in excess of $100m that the Liberal and National parties have identified as matters of waste and duplication need to be particularly addressed.

There are so many matters in the Aboriginal area that need to be pursued and I am sure we will do so in the committee stage. I am sure that the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), who has taken a very close interest in this area-he has been forced to do so for the last 18 months-will be mindful of the changes that are so necessary in the portfolio, particularly as the Government has steamrolled ahead with its determination to set up an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) early next year. I believe that the Government has not been honest with Australian people or with Aborigines throughout Australia, in terms of the political agenda that has driven the formation of ATSIC as opposed to the appropriate spending of taxpayers' money. Mr Acting Deputy President, as you would be so well aware from the personal interest that you took in the debate and the deliberations on the ATSIC legislation, there is no proper way that ATSIC should be kick-started on 1 February, as the Government seems hell-bent on doing, to force the agenda that will quickly aggravate the many problems that have been created.

I would like to spend the remainder of the time available to me addressing the differences in approach and commitment to the tourist industry between the Hawke Labor Government and an alternative Liberal- National Party Government. I would also like to say something about the opportunities that would be given under a coalition government. We have all become familiar with the problems of the pilots dispute. We are months into it and there is no hope of resolution because the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is not prepared to make any commitment whatsoever to getting one. We need to be reminded time and again of how long it is going to take for the consequences of this unresolved dispute to actually have an effect.

Some constituents of mine in the Northern Territory who have obviously been giving this a lot of consideration are operators in the tourist industry. I would like to draw on some comments that were made today by some of these operators. One operator, Mr Kevin McDonald, the manager of Darwin's Atrium Hotel, has said:
It may take seven or eight years to overcome something like this. It may be that the hotel industry will never recover.
John Parsche, who manages another of Darwin's biggest hotels, the Beaufort, said that Australians will be left with nothing to sell overseas.

Mrs Penny Tastula, the President of the Darwin Tourist Promotion Association, speaks for many of her members when she says that officials estimate that the Northern Territory tourist industry has lost about $45m through the dispute and that, with only a couple of exceptions, hotels say their occupancy figures have remained at least 50 per cent down on last year. She says that Darwin's Beaufort and Diamond Beach hotels have each cancelled more than 20 conferences and conventions while most Northern Territory hotels report cancellations of room bookings well into next year. She says that almost all of the Top End's 40 tour operators are in debt as a result of the pilots dispute and that at least three of the major operators may not be able to re-open business next year. My office has run a very open and public hot line canvassing the problems and the issues that have affected this industry. There have been hundreds of phone calls, contacts and letters from industry representatives and individual people who have been vitally affected.

I had a phone call today from an Alice Springs constituent, a Mr David Baldwin, who has invested some $200,000-odd in a specialised red carpet service to a particular upmarket clientele in the tourist industry. Of course, the rug has now been pulled totally from under him. What resort does he have? He has certainly got large debts and large commitments. He has not had a single booking since the end of August. What does this do to such a personal business? Here is a territorian of some 40 years standing who has pioneered taxi services and radio controlled freight delivery services and who has made a commitment to the tourist industry. He has had the rug totally pulled from under him. Because he has some assets he cannot get any assistance from Social Security. Nothing is available to him there. If he walked into the Department of Social Security he would be told, `Sell your assets; sell your business'. That is the sort of commitment that Hawke wants to give.

I am well aware that the Northern Territory Government has done everything possible to help the small tour operators and the families that have been affected but there is no easy solution. Certainly, the Northern Territory has lost the advantage of the peak tourist season. The Northern Territory Government has been able to stimulate a united effort in the small business and family business area. But the price hikes in air fares that will be the inevitable consequence of this pilots dispute will cause even further major heartache. I am very surprised that my Senate colleague from the Northern Territory, Senator Collins, has had a preoccupation with attacking the Australian Federation of Air Pilots. I have no truck with the pilots or the Pilots Federation and their stance in this dispute. They should have been at the negotiating table far sooner and they should have had an invitation by the Prime Minister to be there. He should have locked the door behind them and held them in the room until there was a resolution. Bob Hawke has walked away--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! That is the second time. Could you refer to the Prime Minister in appropriate terms.

—The Prime Minister has a lot to answer for. The diversionary tactics of the Australian Labor Party throughout this entire dispute have major implications on the Budget for this year, whether it be in the tourist portfolio, the social security portfolio, the health portfolio or the promotion of Australia in the future. We are going down the gurgler fast because the issue is back squarely with the Prime Minister. I could cite many examples from throughout the Northern Territory of the hurt that is being felt because of the efforts of this Government. Everyone is well aware of the major tourist promotion of the last few years with regard to Australia and, in particular, the Northern Territory. Every Australian can now identify with places such as Kakadu, Mataranka, Daly River, Litchfield Park and Uluru. But where will we go? As I said earlier, cumulative losses for the Northern Territory alone are $45m.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the greatest economic crisis to confront the nation since the Great Depression. There is certainly no light in relation to a solution. The Prime Minister and his Ministers do not appear to believe that an economic crisis exists. They are all running away when the nation is bleeding to death. Certainly, the Northern Territory's second largest industry is a major casualty. Whether one is talking about the family or industry, it appears that the Government must bear the responsibility for what it has done in trying to coordinate the economic climate in Australia. We are in the worst economic situation since the Great Depression. It is totally the responsibility of the Hawke Labor Government, which is absolutely and crucially defenceless--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating this evening cognately the Government's Appropriation Bills. It is in fact the Government's Budget. My belief is that what this centralist socialist Hawke Government has done to this great country of ours over a relatively short period of time can be described as nothing more nor less than a damn shame and a disgrace. We are a large country with a relatively small population, blessed with a very broad range of rich mineral resources, a great primary industry and great plains-for example, the brigalow country in my own State where we produce wheat, beef, wool and so on. Of course, we have the additional benefit of having places of great beauty that people wish to come and see; hence, the recent growth of our tourist industry. In addition, our terms of trade, the money we get for our exports, are at their highest for 10 years. Over the past year they have been at that level. So as a country we have everything going for us.

SPEECH.PARA: Notwithstanding all these factors, after just over six years of this Hawke Labor Government, our economic position, by whatever measure one takes, is frighteningly precarious. I get no pleasure in making those remarks; I get great displeasure. Julie McIntosh, the 20-year-old president of the apolitical Association of Students in Economics and Commerce, said recently:

We are getting left behind and if we don't do something about it soon we will end up as a nobody country at the bottom of the world whose economy will work around trying to service its overseas debts.

What great perception from a 20-year-old. It comes not from a scaremonger with political motive but from a young lady who was reflecting the views of not only the young but every rational thinker who is genuinely concerned about the future of our country. Instead of being the envy of the world, a downturn in our commodity prices would plunge us into recession. Instead of reaping the rewards of record terms of trade, we are besieged by welfare groups pointing to the level of poverty in Australia, the plight of single income families and so on. The National Media Liaison Service even quotes at great length the Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, in the publication it has put out with the headline `Welfare Record', saying that 1.2 million children in families benefit under welfare. It also says at great length that the Government's policy is directed forwards those families who are poor or near poverty. This Government is saying that, because of its economic policies, 1.2 million children in this country are in or near poverty.

TALK.START.PARA: —So much for Bob Hawke's promises.

—He should be ashamed of it, not bragging about the headline `Welfare Record'. But neither he nor the Government seems to recognise that the higher the level of people receiving welfare payments, the greater the indictment of its failed economic policies. They are directly proportional. I am not referring to those people with physical or mental disabilities; I am talking about people described by this Government itself as being in or near poverty. That comes about only because of economic policies.

SPEECH.PARA: Instead of reaping the rewards of what should be good times, firstly, we have a net foreign debt which, in the term of the Hawke socialist Labor Government, has risen from $23 billion to $108 billion; and, secondly, for the second time since this Government has come to power, two recent significant downgradings have occurred of our international credit rating by the two international credit rating agencies, Moody's Investors Service and Standard and Poor's Inc. I cannot help observing that the name of one of the agencies is Standard and Poor's. Regrettably, it is not a bad description of the state to which Labor has brought Australia.

Thirdly, the inflation rate is now 8.3 per cent and rising. For almost the whole period of the Hawke Government, our inflation rate has consistently been about twice the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development average. Senator McKiernan, who usually speaks fairly wisely about these things, said during his speech in this debate that the Hawke Government had to be proud of what it had done about the inflation rate. Senator McKiernan said that when the Hawke Government came into power the inflation rate was 6.9 per cent and that a year later, in 1984-85, it was 4.3 per cent. The reason that it came down to 4.3 per cent was as a direct result of the Fraser Government's wages freeze. Year in and year out it has gone up steadily. Currently, it is running at about 8.3 per cent, notwithstanding that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his last Budget Speech said that he expected the inflation rate to fall below 7.5 per cent. Pigs might fly! Fourthly, home mortgage rates are not only at a record high but also by far the highest in the industrialised world. I do not have to go into that; numerous articles have been written on that subject and the affordability of homes in Australia as a result of those high interest rates.

We are in drastic times. The blame can only be laid squarely at the feet of this Government, which lacks foresight and which has persisted with antiquated centralised solutions instead of stimulating the initiative of individual Australians. That is what the coalition parties are on about. Yesterday's solutions are clearly not solving today's problems. Monetary policy, with resultant high interest rates, is the only lever being pulled by the Government. That may have worked 20 years ago, but not today. The reasons are really quite simple: a deregulated financial system means that financial institutions are able to offer domestic borrowers far greater flexibility, which was not available 20 years ago. There is not much difference to home buyers between cheaper houses with higher interest rates and dearer houses with lower interest rates. What high interest rates do, however, is depress new housing starts.

The other major problem is that our inflation rate and high level of marginal taxation rates are an inbuilt disincentive to save. While attempting to dampen domestic consumption with high interest rates, what is totally ignored, or seemingly not even recognised, is that high interest rates are a major cause of our continuing current account deficit and increasing debt. It should be noted that the net incomes component of the current account deficit-that is, the difference between interest and dividends paid overseas and interest and dividends received from Australia-is locked in at around $1,100m a month. That has been going on for the last 12 to 18 months.

Because of our high interest rates, manufacturers cannot compete with imports from countries where bank lending rates are as much as one-third of Australian rates. Current overdraft rates in Australia are around 21 per cent compared with 6 per cent in, say, Japan. This not only precludes our manufacturers from holding their own domestic markets, but our inflexible centralised wage fixing system and grossly inefficient waterfront practices preclude any consideration of exporting those manufactured goods if they do make them.

It is possible to borrow from overseas banks at interest rates of about 9 per cent, compared to the 21 per cent charged by Australian banks, particularly if one is exporting commodities in United States dollars. This applies to all areas, whether it be the resources, primary industry or tourism area. An exporter would be a fool not to take advantage of those lower rates. By exporting in United States dollars there is really no exchange risk. That is why it is happening. I believe the Australian Democrats should take this point on board when they call for the abolition of foreign borrowings by the private sector. Having regard to a 50 : 50 debt ratio, there are export projects which will go ahead if the money is borrowed at 9 per cent interest rate which would not go ahead at a 21 per cent interest rate.

What one would hope would eventually sink in is the fact that our domestic interest rates are contributing to the level of private sector foreign debt. It is no good blaming the person in the business sector; he is making a proper entrepreneurial decision to borrow so that his project will be viable. I note that Senator Sanders is looking at me. I say to him that if one is in the export trade, selling in United States dollars, there is no exchange risk; hence the reason for borrowing at those rates. No business person who gains satisfaction from building an enterprise wants to hand it over to someone else. People starting a small business must borrow if they wish to continue to control their own enterprise. Of course, this country started in that way. People set up a business with few resources and try to hang on to it. I suppose it could be argued that they have an opportunity to sell out to one of the big guys, but they may not want to do that, they may want to hang on. The only option they have is to borrow, and they have to borrow at a rate which makes the project viable.

Notwithstanding our inherent wealth, with 80 per cent of our exports in the mining and primary industries, we cannot make the goods that Australians want or need to buy. This is the critical problem in this country today. Our mining and primary products are cost efficient, mainly because nature has blessed us with special resources. We should not forget that. We are not as efficient as we could be, even in those great cost effective industries, but we are fortunate. I believe we must look at adding value to those commodities. There is some value added in capital and power intensive industries such as the aluminium industry, but in the main our minerals are treated, refined and exported to be made into finished products overseas. I add that the loonies who put paid to the Wesley Vale pulp mill in Tasmania were from the same Luddite tribe which attempted to stop the construction of the Portland aluminium smelter. I wonder how many people in this chamber remember the chant, `Stop the construction of the smelter, it will export canned electricity'. Yet it was producing a value added product. It was one of the few areas in which we had taken advantage of turning our raw materials into value added products, instead of just exporting the raw materials itself. The difference, of course, was that the coalition Government at the time had the interests of Australia at heart, which enabled construction of that smelter to go ahead. Under this Government I have no doubt that it would have been stopped or at least delayed. When such projects are delayed people lose confidence and in many cases walk away from them.

If it was attractive to process our minerals further, it would be done. I will come to why I believe it is not being done. Everyone must recognise that non-renewable resources are just that, and eventually, because of depth, lower grades or the introduction of substitutes, operations will close. The reasons that we are not doing further processing must be identified and addressed, otherwise generations to come can expect a dismal future. They will look back with contempt at the stupidity of this generation.

I believe that the vast majority of Australians have no sense of urgency because this Government in particular has made sure that they are not aware of the depth of our problems. The attitude is, `Things have been great, we live in a marvellous country and the position will improve next year'. If we look at every Budget Speech made by the Treasurer over the past six years we find that he said, `Don't worry, by the end of next year things will be right, we will have turned the corner'. The real position is that because of our almost total dependence on commodities, a collapse in world commodity prices would be as devastating to Australia as a war. Unless there is a profound change in the economic history of the world, there will be a cyclical downturn in demand for our commodities by other countries.

Investment is not made in the manufacturing sector because people perceive that there are more predictable and better ways of protecting one's savings. We have a real estate mentality in Australia, which is no different from the gold mentality of some South East Asian countries where people move into gold investment when there is political or economic turmoil because their savings are protected and it can be easily traded. In Australia people move into real estate to protect their savings. This investment contributes absolutely nothing to the wealth creation of the economy. They invest in real estate because it is more secure and does not have the hassles or uncertainty associated with investing in business enterprises. The collapse of major organisations such as Ariadne, Rothwells or Bond provides a major disincentive to the ordinary person to invest in wealth creation. Added to this is the complexity of the Government's regulations and charges.

Foreign investment in Australia is geared towards resources and tourism. The question is often asked, `Why don't foreign investors invest in manufacturing?'. The answer is that we would all like to see them do that but one cannot persuade them by force. One must look at why they are not doing it. The answer is that there are other parts of the world whose manufacturing sectors are more attractive for investment. Australia has raw materials, natural wealth, the necessary expertise and our people are educated, yet Australia is not the place in which they wish to invest. If it were attractive, the investments would be made.

There are many reasons for this lack of foreign investment. The major reasons are that we have an inflexible, centralised wage fixing system, terrible work practices, an unenviable record on disputations and hold-ups, and a shocking reputation for unreliability. We are also a long way from major markets and we have a relatively small domestic market. In the June 1989 edition of the Far East Business publication, an article appears on the reforms needed on our waterfront. Being an island continent relying so much on exports, our waterfront is vital to the prosperity of this country. The Far East Business is read by people in the Far East who either wish to invest in this country or wish to purchase goods from this country. It is worth quoting some points from this article. In fact, I was ashamed to read it. As a person who is very proud of my country, I found the facts appalling. The article stated:
Australia's reputation as an unreliable, expensive and inefficient port operator has been a major barrier to international trade.
The article states that a study by the Business Council of Australia found that-and I quote:
. . . Australian ports are half as productive as European ports and only 40 per cent as productive as many Asian ports.

Peter Dexter, president of the Australian Chamber of Shipping, which represents foreign and domestic shipping companies, agrees. ``There is just no comparison with Europe, South America or Asia,'' he says, adding that Australia even lags behind `banana republic' ports of Chile in its efficiency.
I believe I have heard that sort of comment before from our own Treasurer. The article made these other points:
The lost opportunities in exports through this are frightening.
In respect of meat, this comment is made:

The Japanese demand precise delivery dates and the greater reliability of U.S. suppliers tends to swing buyers in its favour. Australian meat producers also fear they will miss out on much of a new 70,000 ton market opening up in Korea . . .

because of these problems. Since that time we have seen the $200 a container surcharge being put on containers in the Port of Sydney. All these problems should be surmountable for people who have the benefits of this country at heart. I do not care what their position is, be they in the trade union movement, the business sector or whatever. For instance, our entrenched problems in respect of work practices and unreliability could be swept away if only there was a little bit of understanding that the work practices destroy productivity, destroy industries, destroy enterprises and destroy jobs.

Where, however, there is a monopoly-whether it be a monopoly organisation or a monopoly union-controlling essential areas such as our ports, the removal of restrictive work practices will open up export vistas which are beyond the reach of much of Australian industry today. I was disappointed with the in-principle agreement on the waterfront. I would have expected the first aim of this in-principle agreement to be the achievement of a standard of efficiency that is better than that in any other port in the world. It is no good for a country as far removed from its markets as we are to have ports equal to ports in other countries. We should aim to be the best in the world. I would have thought that this is the sort of pursuit of excellence that we, as a country, should be looking to today.

This situation is ludicrous, I believe, in that we have a country that stretches from nearly the Equator in the north almost to the Antarctic in the south, from the Pacific Ocean to the Indian Ocean, yet we have a group of people in Melbourne in the Industrial Relations Commission who determine wage rates for the whole country. It does not make any sense. It is like the sort of regulation that I often hear my colleague Senator Sanders talk about in the Civil Aviation Authority. It is a myth. If someone lives in Launceston, Hobart or Bundaberg and is asked to move to Sydney that person will not move without a sufficient increase in wages or salary to pay for those costs. It is a myth. It is ludicrous that under the so-called accord national productivity increases are applied across the board with the productive subsidising the unproductive. This guarantees that the unproductive will survive.

We must look to countries that have been successful: our near neighbours Japan, Taiwan and Korea. Last year in Korea a bipartisan parliamentary delegation of which I was a member met with South Korean trade union representatives. It turned out that just before we arrived one of the major companies had agreed to a 23 per cent wage increase. When asked whether this increase had flowed on to other companies or other industries, the union leaders were taken aback. They pointed out in no uncertain terms that they were interested in nurturing business not destroying it. They said that their aim was for all business to grow so that they could afford the same sorts of increases. In fact, those representatives made the comment that they were not about to destroy business at birth. What a difference in attitude to Australia! If we are to improve our position we must come around to that way of thinking. Until we move to genuine enterprise employment, agreements with wage rates determined at the work place and based on productivity increases at the enterprise level, we will continue to decline to what Julie McIntosh, as I mentioned earlier in my speech, described as a nobody country at the bottom of the world.

In seven years this centralist socialist Government has reduced Australia to a country with a precarious economic position. The coalition has produced a blueprint-an economic plan which provides the recipe for recovery of this great country. It is a great country. It is a country with natural inherent wealth, as I keep saying over and over again. One of the few areas of progress is my own State of Queensland. There are some exciting developments on the horizon in that State: the Cape York Space Agency, a stainless steel plant in Townsville, a steel mill in Gladstone.

TALK.START.PARA: —The election?

—I notice the humorous interjection of Senator McKiernan and I will come to the politics of it in a minute. But this is not politics; this is real. There are companies from both Japan and Taiwan that would like to put a steel mill in Queensland. The only thing that will prevent them from doing so is the uncertainty of our industrial relations-in particular whether they could bring ships, for instance, from the Pilbara to Gladstone without having to use the coastal shipping system as we have it today. Ideally, ships would come from Japan, pick up iron ore in the Pilbara, take it to Gladstone, dump the iron ore off and pick up coal, and take it back to Japan. So there would be a triangular course. Will Senator McKiernan's militant colleagues in the Seamen's Union of Australia, through the Australian Council of Trade Unions, allow that to happen? I mentioned that the Opposition has a recipe for recovery. Basically the summary of it is: tax rates will be cut; interest rates will be lowered; government will be smaller; inflation will be reduced; productivity and real wages will be higher and the growth in foreign debt will be brought under control.

SPEECH.PARA: In a few weeks the people of Queensland will go to the polls. Just a few minutes ago I pointed out what I believe to be exciting developments on the horizon in that State which has been renowned over a long time for some great developments. The people of Queensland cannot allow a Labor government to do to Queensland what this Labor Government has done to Australia. When looking at the destruction of the value added Wesley Vale project in Tasmania and the delay of the Coronation Hill project, which might be its demise, people involved are taking a particular view at the moment. They are talking to me and presumably they are talking to Senator McKiernan. They are saying, `Look, is it worth the hassle? There are other places where we can make investments. To hell with them'. The people of Queensland will see that under a Labor State government the development era in Queensland will be over.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1989-90 and cognate Bills. One of the biggest wastes of money in the Budget is the ongoing study into the Royal Australian Navy move to Jervis Bay. At the moment environmental impact statements (EIS) and a number of other studies are being conducted which are a great waste of money because the Navy should not be moving to Jervis Bay in the first place. In 1987 the Federal Labor Government announced that it proposed to relocate naval facilities from Sydney to Jervis Bay at a cost exceeding $1.2 billion. Engineering consultants, Sinclair, Knight and Partners Pty Ltd (SKP), were commissioned to produce an environmental impact statement for the proposed move. The EIS has been described by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, as probably one of the most complex to be dealt with under Federal environmental law. The EIS contract was initially for $1.5m but in less than three years it has grown to $3.1m. A further $5.3m has so far been spent on planning studies by the Department of Administrative Services and the Department of Defence is spending another $5.5m on the most comprehensive studies of Jervis Bay's marine ecosystem ever done. Yet, most of the results have come too late to be incorporated in the EIS.

SPEECH.PARA: Even before any formal Cabinet decision is made on the future of Jervis Bay about $14m has been committed to the relocation plan. In mid-1989 the preliminary draft EIS for Jervis Bay was deemed inadequate by the Federal Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, causing the public release of the draft EIS to be delayed from April 1989 to early 1990. In particular the justification for and alternatives to the relocation have not been adequately investigated. In September 1989, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who had previously been a strong advocate of the Jervis Bay plan, directed the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) to re-evaluate thoroughly alternative schemes. Regardless of this directive, work on the EIS is continuing with the intention of completing it with a minimum of further delay. The study of alternatives will be separate from the draft EIS.

I will document evidence, uncovered in a survey of the work of Sinclair Knight and Partners, which suggests that SKP lacks the competence and independence to produce an adequate EIS for the Jervis Bay plan. The evidence also reveals that three firms, which have performed key studies for or related to the EIS, have engaged in seriously questionable practices in the course of other work. They are Hill and Knowlton Australia Pty Ltd, which is monitoring public awareness of and reaction to the EIS; Anutech Pty Ltd, which evaluated the impact of defence activities on Jervis Bay's Aboriginal sites; and Kinhill Engineers Pty Ltd, which was commissioned by the Department of Defence to investigate Twofold Bay, New South Wales, as a possible alternative naval port to Jervis Bay.

This evidence renders the Jervis Bay EIS an unreliable document, which cannot be significantly improved by the last minute window-dressing which is now on the way. The EIS should be abandoned. The significance of this goes beyond the Jervis Bay project. It calls into question the entire system of assessing the environmental impact of major projects and underscores the need for substantial reforms in Federal environmental law. First, I shall talk about Sinclair Knight and Partners and its organisational philosophy. A Sinclair Knight and Partners publicity brochure of March 1987 says:
Environmental services: . . . Our specialists know the relevant authorities and can assist in meeting complex requirements so that timely approvals can be acquired.

This statement, which was published in the same month that SKP won the Jervis Bay contract, is an unambiguous admission that it performs environmental studies in order to win approval for construction projects. SKP's approach is hardly surprising. Its publicity brochure lists as key areas of expertise the planning of bridges, buildings, coastal engineering projects, dams, highways, factories, mines, ports, marinas, urban developments and railways.

Revenue from its environmental services accounted for only 8 per cent of all income in the 1987-88 financial year. In short, SKP is an engineering firm whose corporate priority is to ensure that construction projects proceed. Furthermore, environmental impact statements are paid for and supervised by the company or bureaucracy which proposes the project-the Defence Department in the case of Jervis Bay. An EIS consultant which earns a reputation for opposing projects it studies is, of course, unlikely to win further contracts.

I shall now mention some recent SKP environmental studies. In recent times SKP has completed several environmental studies which have drawn damning criticisms from official and independent expert assessors. One of the studies involved an EIS for the controversial Wesley Vale pulp mill. Two were assessments of contamination caused by a toxic waste dump on which homes had been built in the Brisbane suburb of Kingston, and two were EISs for a proposed marina and hotel project at Woolloomooloo in Sydney. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard some of the quotes from the Hansard record and extracts from letters.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
THE WESLEY VALE PULP MILL EIS
(Carried Out by SKP for Noranda and North Broken Hill Holdings, 1988)
Paul Crew (Director, Tasmanian Department of Sea Fisheries), letter to the Tasmanian Department of the Environment, 28 November 1988:
The document is totally inadequate in its consideration of the likely and potential effects of the proposed development on the marine environment . . .
[Its] treatment of the possible effects . . . on the marine environment is a collection of superficial, unsubstantiated, untested and unacceptable claims . . .

Either the consultants, Sinclair Knight and Partners, have a wealth of additional information but have chosen not to reveal it or, alternatively, they have failed in their duty to the Tasmanian public . . .
Senator Graham Richardson, Minister for the Environment, 10 April 1989 (Hansard):

On 7 December [1988] the Commonwealth and the Tasmanian Government, in partnership, sent a joint letter to Noranda and North Broken Hill Holdings Ltd [proponents of the Wesley Vale mill]. In that letter we listed 85 points where the environmental impact statement (EIS) was either inadequate or where points had not been addressed at all.
Extract from that letter (obtained under the Freedom of Information Act):
. . . [The] implications of the development for tourism and the fishing industry are clearly not dealt with adequately . . .
Alternative technologies for producing the grade of pulp required . . . have not been addressed and must be . . .
[The] marine environment in the vicinity of the outfall. . . has not been described adequately . . .
[The] archeological/anthropological significance of sites . . . is not addressed at all . . .
There is little reference to Federal environmental standards.
STUDIES OF THE IMPACT OF A BURIED TOXIC WASTE DUMP IN KINGSTON
(Carried out by SKP for the Queensland Government and Logan City Council, 1987 & 1989)
Institute of Applied Environmental Research (Griffith University) report to the Logan City Council, June 1989:

The . . . dumping of hazardous wastes in the Kingston area has been the subject of two reports by Sinclair Knight and Partners [in 1987 and 1989] which were commissioned by the [Logan City] Council and the [Queensland] Government.
. . . [This review is] an independent assessment of [SKP's] two reports . . .
. . . [It] is the review team's opinion that:
1. The field investigations were poorly conceived and implemented and hence the resulting database is of suspect quality.

2. Sufficient care was not taken to ensure samples were representative of the materials under investigation, whether it be the hazardous substances, soils or waters, and hence the conclusions drawn from the interpretation of the analytical results are unreliable.
3. The unexplained approach to sampling and analysis limits the usefulness of the investigations.
4. The nature of the source of contamination has not been adequately characterised.
5. The extent of contamination of groundwaters has not been established at either of the waste disposal sites.
6. The study has generally concentrated on hazards for public safety and appears to have ignored possible hazards to the environment, i.e. wildlife and aquatic life in the local water courses.
7. There appears to have been no quality control programme in existence to detect and correct the inadequacies of the investigation and sampling programs.

8. It is possible that the waste materials at the site do not represent a significant hazard to public health (other than direct contact), but the investigations undertaken are inadequate to establish this.

9. In view of the findings of this review, little weight should be placed on the results of [SKP's] investigations to define the nature and extent of contamination. Further, more reliable investigations are required.
THE WOOLLOOMOOLOO MARINA EIS's
(Carried out by SKP and Masterplan for Pivot Group, Wardley Australia and Woolloomooloo Marina, 1987; and by SKP for Pivot Group, 1989)
Sydney City Council, Evaluation of the 1987 EIS, 27 October 1987:
[T]he claim that the marina moorings and the land facilities are visually non-intrusive cannot be sustained . . .
[T]he perspectives illustrating the marina concept grossly underestimate the visual impact . . .
[C]laims made in the EIS . . . that development of [a] smaller lease area is financially unacceptable cannot be sustained . . .
The EIS has not considered the environmental and visual benefits of the demolition of the wharf and the restoration of public access to the bay foreshores . . .
Sydney Morning Herald, 28 November 1987:
Mr Dick Smyth, the director of the [NSW] Department of Planning and Environment, said the system of assessing the environmental impact of major projects was fast approaching a crisis of credibility.
. . . [E]nvironmental impact statements . . . were often inadequate, failed to address relevant issues, were misleading and used contradictory and biased information.

They were often lacking substance, or contained superficial analysis. He called part of the [1987] EIS for the Woolloomooloo marina that said `the removal of the Finger Wharf will reinstate the original landscape of the bay', a classic of more recent times.
They also failed to adequately justify projects . . . and sometimes tended to be a justification for a prior decision.
`I can think of the [1987] (Woolloomooloo) marina EIS and Maldon Dumbarton railway as being two classics in that category', he said.
Sydney Morning Herald, 12 May 1989:

[After the Woolloomooloo project was abandoned by the Unsworth Government, then revived in modified form under the Greiner Government-incorporating a 400-room hotel, commercial areas, marina, retail shops, restaurants and car parks-with SKP producing the second EIS, in 1989.]

The $280 million Woolloomooloo Finger Wharf development was dealt a potentially fatal blow last night after the Central Sydney Planning Committee refused approval for a multi-storey hotel on the site . . .
It also considered the [1989] Environmental Impact Statement `inadequate'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The studies cited above were all completed while SKP was working on the Jervis Bay EIS. Two of the projects studied-and approved-by SKP were later rejected by the Federal Government, namely, the Woolloomooloo project, for which the Federal Treasurer (Mr Keating) blocked foreign investment on the grounds that it was `contrary to the national interest', and the Wesley Vale pulp mill.

SPEECH.PARA: Commonwealth approval has not been an issue in the Kingston toxic waste scandal, because the Federal Government has left the matter entirely to the Queensland Government. Residents groups in Kingston strongly believe that SKP's reports understated the hazard, thus assisting the Queensland Government's attempts to minimise political damage and clean-up costs.

It should be stressed that the Jervis Bay EIS will be inadequate if it contains just one of the flaws found in these SKP reports, namely, justification of a prior decision; inadequate consideration of alternatives; poor scientific methods; a lack of substance; superficial analysis; ignorance of the marine environment and of toxic substances; lack of consideration of impacts on archeological and anthropological, that is, Aboriginal, sites, fishing and tourism; and underestimation of the visual impact of maritime structures.

How about the independence of this firm? The successful conduct of environment impact assessments requires more than scientific and analytical competence. The study consultant must also be demonstrably independent of the proponent. Despite official assurances, there is clear evidence that the Jervis Bay EIS does not meet this requirement. Commodore Viv Littlewood, of the Royal Australian Navy, in an article in the Winter 1989 issue of the Naval Ensign, said:
The Jervis Bay EIS process is not a whitewash, as the consultant [Sinclair Knight and Partners] is completely independent of Defence and the Government.
However, the following statement was made in the Australian Financial Review of 23 January 1989:
An Australian-Dutch consortium expects to be awarded a . . . contract this month to [plan] a new [$2 billion] Indian naval base . . .
However, this contract . . . hangs on the imminent trip through [Asia] of the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke.

Mr Bruce Sinclair, director of the consultancy firm Sinclair Knight and Partners, which heads the Australian-Dutch consortium, said: `We are still hanging by our thumbs. Bob Hawke's visit will be very critical in timing'. . . .

. . . [The consortium] is . . . facing a last minute challenge from a rival French group . . . [who are] about to play their trump card . . . with the forthcoming visit to India of President Mitterand.

[He] is expected to lobby the Indian Prime Minister, Mr Gandhi, strongly on behalf of the French group. In status-conscious Asia the endorsement by a head of state of a corporate venture can be decisive. This is why Mr Hawke's visit is crucial.
The following statement appeared in the Pacific Defence Reporter of May 1989:

An important breakthrough into the Indian defence scene marked the recent award to an Australian/Dutch engineering partnership of a key consultancy contract for planning and designing a huge new naval base . . . on India's west coast . . . known as Project Seabird.
The . . . consultancy . . . will be worth about $US5 million. . . .
``A special factor in our success was the support of the Australian Government'', [consultancy team leader Bruce Sinclair] said.

``Defence Minister Beazley met the Indian Navy delegation when it visited Australia and volunteered his support for our partnership. In preparing the bid, we had the support of Australian Construction Services [ACS], the Trade Commissioner Service and other Government agencies.'' . . .

Mr Sinclair also touched on the work of . . . Sinclair Knight and Partners as consultants to the [RAN] and [ACS] on modernizing Garden Island dockyard and on the planning and Environmental Impact Study of the proposed RAN facilities at Jervis Bay.
``. . . [T]he RAN and [ACS] have developed `state of the art' naval support facilities . . .'', he said. ``This was apparent to the Indian Navy assessment group.''.

The fact that the patronage of the Prime Minister and the Minister for Defence was crucial to the success of the bid by SKP's consortium raises grave doubts about SKP's independence in its conduct of the Jervis Bay EIS. Mr Hawke until very recently and Mr Beazley have been the strongest advocates of the relocation plan. In fact, Mr Hawke has said in media interviews said that he `initiated the move'.

SKP's independence is further compromised by its role, as acknowledged by Mr Sinclair, in helping to plan the Jervis Bay facilities in addition to conducting the EIS. According to Mr Beazley, SKP's planning role was to `survey possible sites in the Jervis Bay region for naval facilities'. SKP's wealth of knowledge of the Jervis Bay proposal and of the relevant planning issues in particular puts it in a unique position to win contracts for the further planning and design of proposed facilities. It appears to be in SKP's interests that the project be approved. SKP had a similar conflict of interest in the Wesley Vale pulp mill case. In its 1987-88 annual report, SKP revealed that it had joined forces with Canadian engineering consultants Sandwell Swan Wooster to transfer `specialised pulp and paper technology' to Australia. It listed amongst its clients `North Broken Hill Ltd at Wesley Vale in Tasmania'. With the prospect of further work arising from the proposed new mill, it was perhaps predictable that SKP would produce a favourable EIS.

It could be argued that SKP has already demonstrated its independence of the Federal Government by producing EISs at variance with Government preferences in the Woolloomooloo marina and Wesley Vale cases. However, this is a false conclusion. Neither project was opposed by the Federal Government until after the EISs were completed. In fact, the Prime Minister had initially given strong support to the Wesley Vale project, which he toned down only in response to environment movement pressure following the release of the draft EIS.

This brings us to the firm of Hill and Knowlton. As I have mentioned before in this Parliament, it has been involved in spying on community groups. In 1988, a report of the 4 September 1987 business meeting of the Jervis Bay Protection Committee-a key local environmental organisation opposed to the naval relocation-was leaked from Defence Department files. The activities and some statements of the Committee's leading activists were recorded. Some of this information was clearly directed at identifying ways to discredit those activists. The wording of this report indicates that it was written by someone who had attended the meeting to spy on behalf of the proponents of the relocation of naval facilities to Jervis Bay. The Federal Government denied any knowledge of spying and dismissed the matter as `mickey mouse stuff'. That reference can be found in the Senate Hansard of 7 December 1988. The world's largest public relations firm, the United States based Hill and Knowlton, admitted monitoring the Committee as part of its EIS work but claimed that its role was legitimate. The Canberra Times of 8 December 1988 said:

A spokesman for Hill and Knowlton, a subcontractor for Sinclair Knight and Partners which is carrying out the [Jervis Bay] EIS for the Department of Defence, said that as part of his company's program of monitoring public awareness of and reaction to the EIS, `stringers' or casual employees regularly attended public meetings, including meetings of the [Jervis Bay] Protection Committee. Information was then passed on to Sinclair Knight and Partners.

While it is true that public meetings have been monitored, so too have the Protection Committee's business meetings, such as the 4 September 1987 meeting of which a record was leaked. These business meetings are open only to limited attendance by prospective new members. At no time have the planted observers identified themselves as such, which indicates that their motives were far from honourable.

While watertight proof of Hill and Knowlton's covert monitoring of Protection Committee business committee meetings cannot be obtained, it has a case to answer. It is worth noting that Hill and Knowlton's Australian arm has a history of involvement with espionage. The Age of 24 July 1989 states:
Australian spies worked in South-East Asia under cover provided by the `king' of Australian public relations, Eric White.

The agents were recruited and trained by the Australian Secret Intelligence Service, whereupon they were assigned to Mr White, who sent them to Asian cities as representatives of his firm, Eric White Associates.

This arrangement operated well into the time of the Whitlam Government (1972-1975) . . . In the mid-70s, [Eric White Associates] became part of Hill and Knowlton, the giant American public-relations and publishing group.
Brian Toohey and William Pinwill in Oyster: the story of the Australian Secret Intelligence Service, 1989, stated:

By providing cover for ASIS spies-who routinely engage in deception, misrepresentation, bribery and law-breaking-the Australian PR firm-[a reference to Eric White Associates, which Toohey & Pinwill were forbidden from identifying] breached at least seven of the seventeen articles of th[e] code of ethics [of the Public Relations Institute of Australia].

These revelations were of sufficient concern to the Indonesian Government for it to recently sever its links with Hill and Knowlton's Australian operations. On 31 August 1989 the Australian Financial Review stated:

Jakarta's concern hinges on the fact that . . . Hill and Knowlton, which has owned Eric White [Associates] since the mid-1970s, for more than a decade has been employed by the Indonesian Government as close adviser on the international dissemination of economic promotional material.

As such, Hill and Knowlton PR staffers, many of them in the past drawn from Eric White Associates in Australia, have enjoyed a long-standing position of privileged access to Indonesian ministers and other leaders in an often-secretive government. . . .
Hill and Knowlton is still operating for the Indonesian Government in Jakarta. Eric White, now treated as a separate entity . . . by the Indonesian Government, is not.

As to campaigning against the environment, Hill and Knowlton's Australian operation has shown a willingness to promote projects which could pose serious dangers to the environment. In Western Australia, for example, it is handling public relations for the French-based multinational chemical company Rhone-Poulenc, which is proposing to establish a rare earths separation plant at Pinjarra. The plant would produce large quantities of radioactive waste and other hazardous by-products. In 1988 Western Australia's Environmental Protection Authority rejected the proposal because of doubts that the wastes could be safely disposed of. Rhone-Poulenc has now proposed a controversial new scheme, which includes the disposal of radioactive ammonium nitrate by pumping it underground.

The Australian alliance between Rhone-Poulenc and Hill and Knowlton had its origins in France, where the two firms combined to wage a successful anti-environmental campaign. Their victory is proudly described in an extraordinary memo from Hill and Knowlton to its international branches. It is graphic evidence of a disturbing corporate philosophy. The heading of the memo reads `Getting Results Through Strategy and Action'. The memo states:
Did you know that Hill and Knowlton helped the largest French chemical manufacturer deter the government from imposing a nationwide ban on the use of phosphates in detergents?

The memo goes on in that vein to brag about how this organisation stopped the environmentalists in France from instituting environmental controls. I seek leave of the Senate to incorporate the memo in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The memo read as follows-
Hill and Knowlton
Hill and Knowlton, Inc.
International Public Relations Counsel
420 Lexington Avenue
New York, New York 1017
Getting Results
Through Strategy and Action
Did you know that Hill and Knowlton helped the largest French chemical manufacturer deter the government form imposing a nationwide ban on the use of phosphates in detergents?

The French chemical company Rhone-Poulenc is a major producer of phosphates, which are non-toxic organic compounds commonly used in the manufacture of laundry detergents, among other products. Phosphates in effluents discharged into lakes, streams, and rivers contribute to the oxygen depletion in the affected bodies of water, resulting in algae growth and other ecological disturbances.

In a response to the rising public concern about the deleterious effects of phosphates on the environment, the governments of Italy, Switzerland, and West Germany recently passed sweeping legislation that bans the use or drastically reduces the allowable levels of phosphates in detergents. In France, meanwhile, environmental groups and others were clamouring for the swift enactment of similar legislation.

Rhone-Poulenc feared that such a harsh measure would force the company to close a number of its plants and, consequently, lay off hundreds of workers. The company challenged Hill and Knowlton/Paris to developed and implement a comprehensive campaign that would help thwart the passage of stringent government regulations.

The Paris office suggested that Rhone-Poulenc could counter the arguments for controlling phosphates in detergents by presenting solid evidence that the regulation would have widespread undesired economic effects on the company's plant communities.

Before the phosphate issue was a hot media topic, Hill and Knowlton organized a task force comprising six Rhone-Poulenc researchers, detergent experts, and marketing and environmental specialists who met regularly with H&K representatives to review the campaign strategy and determine further actions to handle troublesome issues as they emerged.

H&K/Paris then began monitoring European media coverage and conducting in-depth research of the phosphate problem. A ``who's who'' list of 1,500 government officials, community leaders, media representatives and environmental experts who could influence the outcome of any decision to regulate phosphate was prepared. Backgrounders, educational booklets, authoritative brochures, and an economic impact study also were developed for the various target audiences. A corporate advertising and mailing campaign designed to point out the distinct product benefits of phosphate detergents was launched as well, with the 7,000 distributors of detergents in France the primary target. In addition, the task force members participated in media training sessions to prepare for potential crisis communications responsibilities and for a major news conference held at Rhone-Poulenc's research centre in Lyons.

To relate the client's viewpoint to government leaders, H&K assisted Rhone-Poulenc in lobbying key decision-makers in the relevant ministries. Another significant component of the government relations program was the presentation of a 15-minute video highlighting the devastating effects of phosphate controls on the economies of U.S. and Swedish plant communities. Two 10-minute videos also were produced for tentative television broadcast.

Finally, H&K arranged for Rhone-Poulenc's active participation in industry symposia and roundtable discussions on pollution-related issues-most notably the World Conference on Detergents, where a company executive delivered a keynote speech-to position the company as taking the initiative to tackle a difficult problem.

H&K's campaign proved invaluable to Rhone-Poulenc: The French government dropped pending legislation against the use of phosphates in detergents. The campaign also deterred consumer interest in a newly introduced non-phosphate detergent. Rhone-Poulenc was so pleased with the program's outcome that it retained H&K to extend the campaign to other countries, including Spain and Belgium.
Congratulations to the Hill and Knowlton/Paris team: Chantal Dreville, Claude Dumond, Jacqueline Gibault, Christophe Lamps, and Daniel Verpeaux.
