TALK.START.PARA: —I will move on to a local firm called ANUTECH Pty Ltd, the Australian National University's consulting agency which has been subcontracted to perform one of the most sensitive studies for the Jervis Bay EIS-as assessment of the impact of Jervis Bay defence activities on Aboriginal sites. Jervis Bay's Aboriginal communities-the Jerringa community from Bundoola's Place on the Beecroft Peninsula on the north side and the Wreck Bay people on the south side-are strongly opposed to the relocation plan, reinforcing the need for the utmost integrity to be shown by ANUTECH. ANUTECH's report from the Jervis Bay EIS is not available, but assessments have been obtained of studies done by it of the impact of two other proposed projects on Aboriginal values-a sand mine at Gerroa in New South Wales and a mining exploration program at El Sherana near Coronation Hill in Kakadu; in the sickness country of the Jawoyn people. In both cases, ANUTECH acted against Aboriginal interests in profoundly unscientific ways. On 16 July 1989 the Sun-Herald stated:

SPEECH.PARA: An archaeologist, who recommended sand mining should not proceed on a site on the NSW South Coast because it contained important Aboriginal artefacts, has discovered her report was later changed without her knowledge.

Dr Sarah Colley, an archaeologist from the Australian National University in Canberra, was contacted last October by the ANU's consulting agency, ANUTECH, to survey a proposed sand mining site near Seven Mile Beach at Gerroa.

She found `rich, archaeological deposits', including 5,000-year-old shell middens and stone tools, indicating a once-thriving Aboriginal population in an area now owned by a local concrete company, Cleary Bros.
But in December, a report was published in her name recommending that sand quarrying should be permitted in some areas.
Mr Allan Lance, ANUTECH's executive archaeologist, admitted to the Sun-Herald last week that he changed the report without Dr Colley's permission after doing a further survey of the site . . .
This report was attached to the Environment Impact Statement performed by two consulting engineering firms, Hardcastle & Richards and Dames & Moore, on behalf of Cleary Bros. . . .
Last week, Dr Colley said she was disgusted at the alteration of her report.
`I'm not doing any more work for them', she said.

I now refer to the misrepresentation of the Jawoyn people. The El Sherana mineral exploration program is a project of BHP Gold Mines Ltd and the Coronation Hill joint venture. In 1988, BHP Gold commissioned ANUTECH to conduct an archaeological survey of the El Sherana site. The study was conducted for ANUTECH by a Canadian PhD student, Paul Tacon. In his report, Tacon not only dealt with archaeological matters but also offered his assessment of the attitude of the Jawoyn elders to mining, and gave advice on the tactics BHP Gold should employ to expedite exploration approval. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a section of a report by Paul Tacon of ANUTECH to BHP Gold and the Coronation Hill joint venture in October 1988 entitled An archaeological survey of the BHP Gold lease at El Sherana.
Leave granted.
The report read as follows-
Survey methods: . . . [Jawoyn traditional elders] Peter Jatbula, Sandy Barraway and Nipper Brown were consulted . . . [but] declined to visit the area and said there was ``nothing there''. . . .

Conclusions and recommendations [No. 3.4]: The more senior [Jawoyn] men did not express much concern about exploration in the El Sh[e]rana lease . . . At a recent meeting of all concerned [Jawoyn], BHP Gold, the Northern Land Council, the Aboriginal Sacred Sites Protection Authority and others at Barunga, it was decided by the [Jawoyn] community that some limited exploration may soon be able to commence . . . Politics and personalities have made cooperation with the Sacred Sites Authority difficult and it is suggested that the best approach is to develop stronger ties with the Northern Land Council and [Jawoyn] elders. It is not advisable to employ an anthropologist to establish the nature of individual [Jawoyn] ties to the Upper South Alligator Valley as this is already being done by the Northern Land Council for the [Jawoyn] land claim. If a rival research study was commissioned at this point there could be much conflict, bad feelings and, eventually, drawn-out court battles. . . . With the air of reconciliation that arose out of the recent Barunga meeting among the Jawoyn it now seems probably [sic] that they wish to make a viable compromise and it is therefore within BHP Gold's interests not to impede this.

TALK.START.PARA: —An Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service archaeologist whose job it was to review Tacon's report generally agreed with his archaeological conclusions. But the comments he gave drew sharp criticism. A minute from I. P. Haskovec of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service (Kakadu) to the Assistant Director N/O, of 3 November 1988, states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I believe that Paul's [Tacon's] interpretation of Jawoyn refusal to accompany him into the lease as a lack of concern is wrong [. A]s I understand it, the senior traditional owners do not want to validate the exploration lease by their cooperation, since they are opposed to . . . mining anywhere within the Upper South Alligator.

. . . Paul's advice to BHP in 3.4 is outside his expertise and as such should not be accepted. Paul is not an anthropologist, and his brief contact with Jawoyn people does not provide sufficient experience for his evaluation of the community's attitude.

Tacon's misinterpretation of the Jawoyn elders' attitude to mineral exploration and his recommendation that BHP Gold should attempt to by-pass the Aboriginal Sacred Sites Protection Authority are extraordinary and disturbing. The elders' opposition to exploration is well established. And the Sacred Sites Authority-now the Areas Protection Authority-is, under Northern Territory law, primarily responsible for documenting and protecting Aboriginal sacred sites under the direction of a committee of Northern Territory Aboriginal people. Tacon's report was a clear attempt to further BHP Gold's interests. It gives little cause for confidence in ANUTECH's sensitivity to Aboriginal concerns or its objectivity in assessing them.

I turn to Kinhill Engineers' report. The ANUTECH study of El Sherana was carried out as part of a public environment report, a PER, on the proposed exploration program. PERs are conducted for projects which the Commonwealth believes warrant an environmental impact assessment, but not a full EIS. BHP Gold and the Coronation Hill joint venture, CHJV, were directed to produce the PER by the Federal Government; it in turn commissioned Kinhill Engineers to carry it out. In the PER, Kinhill repeated the ANUTECH claim that the Jawoyn did not oppose mineral exploration and also claimed that the size of the Jawoyn's people's sickness country had been greatly exaggerated by non-Aboriginal anthropologists and did not in fact encompass El Sherana. Kinhill concluded that the sickness country was not an impediment to mining; under traditional law human activity is greatly restricted in the sickness country. Kinhill's views drew a barrage of criticism. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the comments of the Northern Land Council.
Leave granted.
The comments read as follows-

Not only does the [PER] contain incorrect statements of Jawoyn attitude, but it attempts to discredit the important spiritual association of the area. There is [a] suggestion that the . . . `sickness country' has been deliberately expanded. This suggestion is regarded by the Jawoyn Association to be totally untrue. The PER . . . ignores the traditional principle behind the Jawoyn Association objection to activities in the sickness country.

The Jawoyn Working Party recently visited Canberra to advise the Prime Minister of the Jawoyn's total rejection of any exploration or mining in the sickness country. This position is fully endorsed by the Jawoyn Association . . .

Statements contained in this PER suggesting Jawoyn support for exploration and mining in the sickness country and, in particular, in the El Sherana area are patently without foundation and are considered by the Northern Land Council to be a deliberate distortion of the truth . . .

Within th[e] section [of the PER on `Aboriginal interests'] there are a number of inaccuracies which show a lack of research during the preparation of this PER. However, of greater concern is that they indicate the biases of the consultant company Kinhill and presumably the direction of the client, CHJV. . . .
It would appear that Kinhill has . . . adopted the tactic of discrediting researcher's findings that are contrary to the CHJV ideology. . . .
RECOMMENDATIONS
1. In view of the poorly researched and inaccurate contents of the PER, that the Government reject the findings of the this report.
2. The blatant bias of the report, in particular those sections dealing with Aboriginal interests, justifies a total condemnation of the authors . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —In December 1987, Kinhill Engineers produced an environmental effects statement, EES, for a proposed copper, zinc and silver mine near Benambra, in the north-eastern highlands of Victoria. Environmental effects statements are the equivalent of EISs under Victorian law. The EES was carried out for the proponent, Macquarie Resources Ltd. In the EES, Kinhill claimed that no sites of significant flora or fauna would be affected by the proposed mine. The Conservation Council of Victoria pointed out that two plant species of national significance and a rare frog were potentially affected. Macquarie Resources admitted that this was so, and modified the project in an attempt to rectify the danger. One of the major changes was the selection of a new 45-hectare site for the tailings dam.

SPEECH.PARA: In April 1988, Kinhill produced a second EES for Macquarie Resources' modified project. It offered reassurances about the botanical impact of the project in general and the tailings dam in particular. The Kinhill Engineers' report, Macquarie Resources Ltd: The Benambra Project-Modified Project Description and Environmental Information, of April 1988 states:
. . . [T]he modified project does not directly affect any of the areas identified in the original EES as having conservation significance. . . .

Preliminary [botanical] survey results indicated that the . . . dam sites are covered by mature forest, and relatively undisturbed understorey . . . However, the area directly disturbed is small relative to the total area of forest in the region and the communities represented (montane forest and sclerophyll woodland) are not of limited distribution.

The botanical survey Kinhill was referring to had been carried out by sub-consultants Ecological Horticulture Pty Ltd from 23 to 25 March 1988. This was three weeks before the release of the second EES. In the EES, Kinhill states that final results from the survey would be ready in mid-April 1988 and would be provided on request to interested parties. This would have been well in advance of the closing date for public submissions in response to the EES, 13 May, and the public hearing at which these submissions could be discussed, 13 June, allowing ample time for the survey results to be analysed by conservation groups, local landowners and other interest parties.

However, the final results were received only between 6 and 9 June and then only after repeated requests by several bodies. This was well after the closing date for submissions and only two to five working days before the public hearing. Some organisations did not receive the results at all. Amongst them was the Conservation Council of Victoria, the peak body of Victorian conservation groups, which should have received them automatically. The unacceptable delay indicated that the survey results were embarrassing. This turned out to be the case. A report to Kinhill Engineers in May 1988 from Ecological Horticulture entitled The Benambra Project-Vegetation Data and Assessment of Botanical Significance states:
. . . A total of 10 plant species are significant in a regional or state context; nine (9) were found in the Montane Swamp Complex vegetation . . .
. . . The Montane Swamp Complex vegetation community has high regional and possibly state conservation significance.
. . . The . . . proposed [tailings dam] would eliminate the Montane Swamp Complex . . .

In other words, the tailings dam was to be built on a rare swamp, not a forest as suggested in the second EES. Clearly, the EES should not have been released until the final results of the botanical survey had been incorporated. Kinhill's failure to do so indicates either incompetence or dishonesty on its part. To believe it was incompetence is to accept that the preliminary results of the botanical survey were insufficient to tell a swamp from a forest. At the public hearing, Kinhill was forced to acknowledge that the swamp was unquestionably of State conservation significance. In January 1989, it was provisionally listed as a community under Victoria's Flora and Fauna Guarantee Act.

I now come to the conclusions that can be drawn. Senator Graham Richardson, the Federal Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, was recently reported as saying that it was unlikely that an EIS could be produced for the Jervis Bay relocation which would satisfy the Federal Government. The track record of the consultant and key sub-consultants, as described in this speech, supports this view. It is only fair to note that there are other sub-consultants to the Jervis Bay EIS whose work has not been scrutinised here. However, it cannot be assumed that their work is therefore beyond reproach. For example, consultants Dames and Moore produced two of the environmental studies referred to in the preliminary draft EIS for Jervis Bay. In the Gerroa sandmining matter, ANUTECH claimed that it was directed by Dames and Moore to alter Dr Sarah Colley's report. Dames and Moore also performed two environmental studies for the Rhone-Poulenc rare earths plant previously described, the first of which was rejected by Western Australia's Environmental Protection Authority. Dames and Moore also produced the draft EIS for the controversial Coronation Hill mine which failed to provide a complete or objective analysis of the project's impacts on Aboriginal, that is Jawoyn, interests, according to the then Sacred Sites Authority.

The Jervis Bay EIS is beyond redemption and should be abandoned. In order to prevent a similar misappropriation of public resources in future, it is important to ask why it happened this time. The answer lies in the mindset of the Federal Government and developers that EISs are an afterthought, a cosmetic attempt to address environmental concerns without putting the project in doubt. It has become a recurring theme for the Prime Minister and Cabinet colleagues enthusiastically to embrace major construction plans well before environmental studies have commenced. The Wesley Vale pulp mill, Coronation Hill gold mine, Cape York space port, the very fast train project, the multifunction polis, and the Jervis Bay relocation, are only some of the projects in this category.

The EIS process is heavily weighted in favour of project components. They choose and pay the consultants for the EIS and oversee its conduct. The Federal Environment Department has only a secondary supervisory role, while the general public is allowed detailed input only after the draft EIS has been completed. Much has been said about EISs. They do not perform their functions as an environmental watchdog and they should be scrutinised as a process, overhauled and made to work for the people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a number of points in debate on the Appropriation Bills tonight. In particular, I want to highlight the fact, in response to criticism of the Government, that this set of appropriations, the Budget, does not stand by itself-though it could do that-but it very importantly and very differently is examined if we take it as one of the ongoing Budgets produced by this Labor Government. The Budget is yet another step in the processes instituted by the Labor Government since it came into office to address a multitude of problems left to us by seven years of an uncaring Fraser Government; `uncaring' is the word-uncaring for people who are thrown on to the unemployment heap, people who could not afford to pay, universities and schools that had been wound down without any capital works, the people who could no longer get places in those institutions and the people who could not pay for their health care. The Budget is part of an ongoing series of programs and policies developed by the Government. It is not a random or arbitrary thing that has happened in the Budget; it is part of that program.

SPEECH.PARA: That program has first to take account of all the successful creation of 1.6 million jobs since the Government came to office, a quite extraordinary record unmatched at any time-certainly unmatched by the Opposition which has made our figures that much better because of the enormously low base we had to build on when we came into office. Sixty-five per cent of those jobs are full time and 55 per cent have been taken up by women. Youth unemployment has been nearly halved from its record level of about 28 per cent in early 1983 and women are now in the work force with the highest labour force participation rate in our history. Jobs have been created as part of the Government's policy and they continue to be created because the Government understands that the best way out of poverty is by going into employment, by people being able to have the income security that a job gives them.

Secondly, this Government is committed to supporting people who are looking for work not only by the creation of jobs but also by the creation of educational opportunities. In the 6 1/2 years of Labor Government there has been an extraordinary turnaround in the retention rate in our schools from something like 36 or 37 per cent to over 57 per cent. In fact, in my own State of South Australia that rate is well over 60 per cent. I believe that South Australia is some decimal points behind Queensland in having the highest retention rate of children finishing year 12. It is important to note that, amongst those figures, girls are more highly represented than boys. This Government knows that one does not get on in this world, one does not get a reasonable paying job or even the same opportunities for employment unless one has an adequate education. As a result, this Government's commitment to education is very real and the runs are on the board.

For many people, education to the end of secondary school leads to the opportunity of some sort of tertiary training and, very importantly, university training. While Susan Ryan was the Minister for Education, some 50,000 tertiary places were created. With the introduction of the higher education contribution scheme, another 50,000 places will be created in our universities, colleges and tertiary institutions around this country. Despite the massive increase in tertiary education places, some people still cannot obtain those places. There is still unmet need, much of which cannot be sheeted home to the Government. However, it can be sheeted home to the appalling run-down of commitment to both capital and recurrent expenditure on secondary and tertiary education that occurred in the seven years of the Fraser Government. Despite that, the growth in educational opportunities is matching the growth in jobs. Both of those factors are critical for the development, recovery and ongoing productivity of this country.

Against all of that one needs to remember Medicare, which has often been overlooked in recent years. Medicare provided an insurance policy-a health insurance coverage-for the two million people who were not covered for medical expenses until 1983 when Medicare was introduced. This Government provides for the health of families, the educational opportunities of families and the job opportunities for families. The necessary infrastructure for people to take up those opportunities is very important. I refer now to child-care. This Government is massively committed in its policy and in its funding to the establishment of a huge increase in child-care places. At present there are an extra 30,000 child-care places under construction in this country. That number will be increased to 140,000 public child-care places. Certainly that is not sufficient to meet current demands or needs, and that is why a government that has a commitment to increasing those places and is continuing to fund and establish them must be acknowledged.

The other important point that should be noted is that those child-care places are varied to meet the variety of needs of parents who have the responsibility for their children. Full day-care centres exist for those parents who have a need for full day-care services, particularly if those parents are in full time employment. Occasional care places exist for those many people who need only brief child-care assistance either because they are undertaking voluntary work, making hospital visits or dental visits, or because they are undertaking part time study or part time work. Occasional care meets the needs of those families that have less than a full time requirement for child-care.

Having established child-care facilities for preschool children, the Government recognises that those women who are encouraged to accept employment opportunities do not want to lose those opportunities once their children go to school. As a result, there has been a significant increase in the number of places that are available for after school hours care. The Government recognises that the need for child-care does not stop once children go to school, particularly the children of people who are in full time employment. Often people in part time employment are required to work hours that create a need for child-care either prior to or after school hours. The Government is very concerned that those after school hours care places are established in order to overcome that terrible description of latchkey children.

As well, family day care services provide a variety of flexible options for parents whose children are looked after in smaller groups in private homes. The Government provides assistance, subsidy, fee relief and so on for the users of family day care services. That child-care program is very comprehensive. Not only are child-care places created in various areas of the community, particularly those in greatest need, but also the needs of people in rural or isolated communities are taken into account. Child-care places are not only a metropolitan establishment; they exist across the country and provide a variety of needs to meet the varying needs of working parents, particularly those who have the principal care of children, namely, women. As well, the Government ensures that the provision of child-care and its related costs do not disadvantage people on low incomes. The Government's very comprehensive fee relief subsidies for those in the public child-care sector assist the creation of child-care places and enable people to use them.

The child-care program together with the jobs, the education and the Medicare programs are part of an ongoing commitment that is further reinforced and developed in this Budget. As well, other infrastructure exists for those people who have been out of the work force and who need assistance to get back into it. In particular, that assistance deals with people who are long term unemployed or who are sole parents, particularly women, who may have had a very short time in the work force prior to establishing their families. With its Newstart and jobs, education and training programs, the Government is very concerned to ensure that people do receive assistance to move off pension benefits and into the work force. For many people that task is not easy. The Government is concerned to assist people to take that step rather than to abandon them.

It is particularly shocking that the Opposition's proposal-if one can understand its policy at all-is to dump unemployed people once they have been unemployed for nine months. In a policy that is committed to families there is little understanding from the Opposition of just who are the unemployed people, particularly the older unemployed people, many of whom are family people who have the care of children. Enormous inconsistency exists in the Opposition's policy in that regard.

In 1983 when I first became a member of this place, the Government faced an appalling deficit that was left to it by the Fraser Government. The deficit at that time was $6.5 billion. However, earlier that year it had been estimated to be even higher. This year, the Budget proposes a $9 billion surplus after the actual $6 billion surplus of last year. Nowhere do I hear any cheers or celebrations for that good news. Certainly we cannot overlook the challenges that confront this country, but I find it surprising that, in times past, the bad news was always in terms of the size of the deficit. Somehow the good news of completely reversing that and creating a huge surplus has been lost, particularly amongst members of the Opposition who would not like to confront it at all. That surplus has been another measure of this Budget and past Budgets contributing to an ongoing recovery for this Government. Nothing can be done just in one Budget. No-one would accept that a government's recovery, particularly after what was left to this Government, could be turned around in one Budget.

More than that, the Government was not concerned solely about getting back to some kind of level of neutrality but was concerned to establish policies and programs that would be developed year by year, each time building on the past programs. As a priority, this Government was concerned to help people on the lowest incomes. As I have said before in this place, I well remember a speech by Senator Chaney on appropriations which I believe was delivered last year and during which he criticised the Government for actually assisting families on the lowest income. At that time he said that the Government should have been condemned for that. However, the Labor Government stands up without shame to Senator Chaney and says, `But that was our priority. Do you not know what being a Labor government is about? It is about helping as a priority people on the lowest income'. In fact, if Senator Chaney recognises that the Government has done that, all to the good. Indeed, it has and it should be acknowledged for it. I find it quite surprising that Senator Chaney would want to condemn the Government for it.

At the same time and since, the Government has continued to build on assistance for families-first of all, those at the lowest end of incomes. Then in the April statement and the Budget of this year it moved to increase the range of commitment and assistance to families. This Government has now targeted those families above the lowest income bracket and is tackling the position of the more-middle income earners. The third lot of tax cuts that have just been introduced by this Government take account of that. They are particularly targeted to those on average weekly incomes.

To hear the Opposition speak, one would think that this Government had actually only increased taxes. Somehow the Opposition overlooks the fact that this is the third lot of tax cuts that have been introduced by this Government since it came to office, and not just willy-nilly tax cuts. Those first introduced benefited people at the lowest end of the income scale and are now moving towards those at the middle level of income. At the same time, the Government has been able to reduce the top marginal rate of income tax for a number of reasons, one involving equity considerations and another to encourage people to actually work. In other words, we seek to do away with higher tax levels that may act as a disincentive. Company tax has also been reduced so as to assist producers and companies to get on with the business of producing wealth for this country to address the difficulties of our balance of payments.

The changes for families in terms of family allowance and family allowance supplement cannot be let pass without a particular acknowledgment being given. For the first time ever, those payments are now indexed. More importantly than that, benchmarks have been set for what is considered a reasonable amount of money for children. For children under 13, it is 15 per cent of the married rate of pension, and for children between 13 and 16, it is 20 per cent of the married rate of pension.

This Government has made quite extraordinary contributions on behalf of families and children. First of all, the family allowance has been indexed and increased dramatically. For the first three children, that payment is now $9 a week, and for further children it is $12 a week. That payment is now indexed. Although we in the Government could say that never again will those payments fall below that level, we would have grave concern about what the Opposition means when we have had evidence in this place. Senator Chaney says they are indexed but Mr Peacock says that that is perhaps the case and, anyhow, only for a year.

Having finally got to the stage of being able to afford to index those payments-and what a commitment by government that is-and to afford to index the other payments such as the pensions, the benefits and the family allowance supplement, the Government has a doubt that if the Opposition became the government it would continue that indexation and a fair suspicion that it may well in fact remove it. So the huge amount of work done for six years by this Government to tackle inequity, to tackle poverty, may well be undone by the Opposition, which prefers to target people at a different level of income and to target those people at the expense of those people who are poorest in the community and least able to argue for themselves.

I would like also to pick up on the curious criticism by the Opposition, in particular that of Senator Newman. She was in the chamber a minute ago, but she has just left. Senator Newman, both in an article in Portfolio and in speaking in this place, actually criticised the Government and its commitment to women which she says is nominal. I certainly utterly disagree with Senator Newman. Of late, her arguments have moved away from criticising the Government for creating child-care and urging women into the work force. That argument has gone and it had better stay gone, particularly in the light of the proposed policy by the Opposition.

Her argument now is that economic matters are more important than, for example, allocations to women in sport. I wonder what she would say if she were able to speak to any sporting women's group about the recognition that government is finally giving to women in sport. It is no arbitrary or random, `Why not do that?'. It is part of a coherent program of increasing the contribution to sport and the recognition of the importance of sport in our society, not just for gold medals, although all of us celebrate when the gold medals come home, but in particular to increase the broad-base participation of people in sport and recreation in this country. That increase is dramatic. The Government needs to be congratulated on that.

The Government has a national health policy for women, but that policy is not something that stands alone and has no regard for other things that people do in our society that contribute to their health. The health of women is not an isolated matter and it does not refer only to their genital tract, although sometimes people might want to confine it that way. Certainly, if I am speaking to a woman I want to speak to the whole woman about all the sorts of things and areas of interest that she has. One of the areas of interest for women in this country is their sporting involvement.

For too many years, the achievements of women in sport in this country have gone unrecognised, unacknowledged and certainly massively underfunded. I find it surprising that Senator Newman and the Opposition would criticise the Government for actually committing dollars to improve women's sport and in particular to increase the participation of women across the spectrum of talents not only at the elite level but also, as I said earlier, at the recreational participation level. Those are matters of great celebration. They certainly build on the work that this Government has been doing for a number of years.

I could say that in some ways I had the opportunity to focus on matters of women in sport when I chaired for government an inquiry into women in sport in 1984-85. That was not something that I thought up; that was one of the comprehensive policies for women that were part of the Labor Party's policy statement on women before it came into government in 1983. I am certainly not abandoning it at this stage. I would have thought that Senator Newman should find out what happens when she speaks to the netball players or the hockey players or any other women involved in sport in this country to suggest that they are not really worth dollars. If Senator Newman really understood economic issues she might know that on some recent surveys undertaken by the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories it is estimated that 25 per cent of household income-presumably some households-goes on sport and recreation, for people either to buy the equipment to participate in sport and recreation or to attend sporting and recreational facilities or even games. That is a very large pool of money and it certainly seems to me that even with those figures we should be beginning to regard sport and women's involvement in sport as something that is more of a kind of fillip to women.

It is not. It recognises what opportunities are about. In addition to providing opportunities for our girls and boys, this Government is about providing opportunities for women and men in all fields of endeavour. The Government is not confined, and it will not confine people to a few opportunity areas. Where women want to extend their talents or to try out, to test themselves, to develop fitness and health, this Government acknowledges those efforts and says it will support them.

The Government also recognises that there is a significant economic contribution to be made from the whole field of sport and recreation, and I think that is beginning to be understood more and more, particularly by those people who are beginning to sponsor women's sport with ever increasing numbers of dollars. At a women's cricket meeting at Christmas, one of those sponsors made a comment to me that people have to understand that sponsorship of women's sport is not a soft piece of altruism; it is a hard, economic rational decision.

Women are purchasers. Those women I mentioned earlier who have jobs, who have education, who have increased opportunities under this Government, also have opportunities to participate in sport and recreation like they have not had before. That also means that they can contribute to the economy in a different way from before.

As well as that, of course, women are doing things about their own health. Senator Newman also wanted to argue that dollars allocated for women in sport seemed to be taking dollars away from women's health. I think Senator Richardson has answered questions on this matter on a number of occasions in this place, but I would certainly say that the Government's women in sport program is no irrelevancy. Indeed, it is a comprehensive part of programs that look at women's health, and it fits very well with the national women's health policy established by this Government last year and now to be implemented over however many years it takes. But in particular, it is a $43m package over the next four years to promote the health of Australian women.

That takes account of not only the breast-screening program and the cervical cancer program but also a $33.7m national health program for women that is cost shared with the States and Territories, and it will address a comprehensive list of health issues for women as highlighted in that national health document.

Another area of great interest and concern to people in this community, especially women, has been income security. The creation of jobs is a very important way in which that has been established for women. So too are the changes to superannuation in this Budget. Superannuation membership, particularly for women, will be further encouraged. Indeed, it must be encouraged because it is very low-far too low for those of us concerned about income security for women of all ages. Superannuation membership will be encouraged by permitting contributions to private superannuation schemes for those out of the paid work force for up to two years and by extending the tax deductability of private superannuation contributions for those working as little as 10 hours per week. Both of those changes are particularly advantageous to women.

It is mainly women who drop out of the paid work force to have families. To be able to continue with their contributions to superannuation funds will be a distinct advantage and encouragement to them. They should feel that superannuation is real. It will encourage them to take seriously the prospects of providing for themselves in retirement through superannuation-something that until recently women had not seriously thought was real for them. If they had any access to superannuation it tended to be from their spouses. As women increase their numbers in the work force and have a different attitude about themselves in terms of their income security and their contribution to the productivity of this country, it is important that they look at their superannuation and retirement income differently and take up the options encouraged so much by these changes to superannuation.

As well as that, there is a further inducement for many women in part time work, sometimes working as little as 10 hours a week, to contribute to superannuation and see its benefits. People are more likely to see the benefits of superannuation if they have a realistic opportunity to participate. It is very important that we appreciate those changes to superannuation under this Budget. It is very important that women are reminded of those improvements available to them.

As well, there are changes in the pension rebate. This is beneficial for all pensioners, particularly as many of those pensioners are women who can look forward to an increase in their retirement income through changes to pensions. In the next few years they will be able to earn the full amount allowed under the pension without losing any pension and without having to pay any tax. Again, both of these changes are part of the Government's ongoing comprehensive package of policies in this Budget, which builds on policies that we have put into place in the years before.

Certainly there are challenges ahead for this country; certainly there are matters of serious consideration before us-but this Government has acknowledged that all along. Senator Parer, in his contribution, said that this Government rushes around saying that everything is rosy. I do not know where he was when the Treasurer (Mr Keating) reminded us that we were heading towards a banana republic-a fairly sober message, and certainly not a salutary message about everything being okay. Indeed, it has been this Government that over the years has held out to the Australian people the importance of recognising the real facts about the state of our economy. It has been this Government that has insisted that we face those issues head on and be realistic about them. It is this Government that has put in place the programs that have led to a massive turnaround of a huge deficit to the $9 billion surplus that we will face at the end of this year. That, along with its other policies and programs that deal with needs of individuals in this community, particularly in matters of social justice, of fairness and equity for all, indicates clearly that this Government is not only doing well under this Budget but also is continuing the program that justifies its existence. This Government appreciates the stern concerns that face the country, but it also has the policies and programs in place to continue to address those concerns. It does that because its Budget, year by year, has built on policies. First, it addressed the needs of the poorest in this country and now it is looking to extend its consideration to those people who have over time borne the brunt-those people on middle income levels. This Budget is well worth our serious consideration and celebration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I start my speech I thank my colleague Senator Reid for rising to my defence. It is very much appreciated. I have now participated in a number of appropriation debates. It has begun to strike me as somewhat of a futile exercise. However, one thing that can be said of this Labor Government is that it is consistent, particularly in its management of the economy! It has consistently mismanaged the economy and it has consistently told us that things will get better. In fact, I cannot remember one occasion during the last five years when I have been able to suggest that the year in prospect looks any better than the year in review. This year is certainly no exception. Just as inflation pushes prices ever upward, so too it seems that each year other figures move naturally upwards with nary a hint of apology or explanation from anyone on the Government benches. It seems that we just have to live with higher interest rates, higher inflation, higher current account deficits, higher foreign debt and higher taxes, and with reduced savings, reduced standards of living and reduced international credit ratings-all of this in a nation once termed the lucky country. Where has the lucky country gone? If people such as Sir Arvi Parbo are to be believed it has gone all one way: downwards. In a recent seminar address, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . paradise is under attack . . . Australia has become uncompetitive and lazy.
The Australian Financial Review, in its editorial of last Thursday, 26 October, said that it will get worse before it gets better:
. . . the balance of payments and inflation reinforces the true nature of Australia's economic woes . . . The road ahead is nothing short of a long, hard haul.
As the saying goes, it's going to get a lot worse before it gets better on the balance of payments and foreign debt fronts.

While the commentators seem to realise the seriousness of the situation, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is doggedly sticking to his ill-conceived, inappropriate policies, caring little what effect they are having on the broader economic stage and certainly not giving one minute's thought to how they are affecting the average Australian family. Let us look at the Daily Telegraph of last Friday, 27 October. The headline is `Food, home prices soar'. The article says:
A sharp rise in food prices, housing costs and the July 1 rise in third party car insurance sent Sydney's cost of living rocketing by 2.8 per cent in the September quarter.

These are all areas where the ordinary household is being inflicted with rising costs, and all because this Government has not addressed itself to the proper issues that it will have to address if this country is to get back on the road.

The so-called special meeting convened a month ago by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer to consider the impact of 18 per cent home loan interest rates on Australian families resulted in absolutely nothing being done to improve the lot of an estimated one million families who have taken out home loans since home loan rates were deregulated. Interestingly, the banks argue that if the 800,000 families on the fixed 13.5 per cent loans were also to be deregulated, the banks could lower rates across the board. The conundrum for the Government here is obviously to determine whether there are more Labor voters in the 800,000 families paying 13.5 per cent home loan interest rates or in the one million families with higher interest rates. That is the decision that the Labor Party will have to make at its Caucus meetings in the next little while.

I believe that the Government does not really care a fig for the difficulties of either group. To be honest, it is simply trying to weigh up the political consequences of any change. The political dilemma for the Government was evident when the Treasurer gloatingly announced the other day that a pensioners meeting had pleaded with him to keep interest rates up. Think about that. Treasurer Keating took that as an indication that the Hawke Government's high interest rate policies are popular. I doubt it. I can only suggest that he test that theory at the next Federal election and see how popular he is then.

It is staggering that the Labor Government could have got itself so far removed from the ordinary Australian family and so distant from its traditional support base that it supports economic policies that ensure that the poor in this country remain poor while the rich get richer. They are the simple facts. This nation has turned from being savers to being borrowers. People can no longer afford the luxury of putting a little money aside for a rainy day. The one million families who have suffered 2, 3 and 4 per cent hikes in their home loan repayments have no rainy day accounts left. Those rainy day accounts are long gone. For many others the dream of their own home has long gone. As early as April this year the Australian newspaper was predicting that by the turn of the century-that is, in 11 years time-more than 500,000 Australian families would be sharing their homes with at least two other families. That means 9 per cent of the population will be living in shared accommodation. In commenting on the survey BIS-Shrapnel Pty Ltd director Neil Hayne blamed the staggering survey results on the Federal Government's emphasis on monetary policy. He said that to provide adequate housing for all families now living in shared accommodation the level of residential construction would need to double from the present 120,000 dwellings to 240,000 dwellings a year. What an indictment of a government housing and financial policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not fit.

—Senator McGauran is quite right; they are not fit to govern this country any longer. This Government is turning Australia into the ghetto of the Pacific. Imagine 1.5 million Australians sharing their homes with at least two other families. Gone is the Australian dream and any chance of family life and privacy. Ghetto style living is all that is in prospect for 1.5 million Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: They will be far luckier than the tens of thousands who are presently homeless and who will remain homeless. In the debate on the Appropriation Bill last year I talked about the more than 700,000 Australians living below the poverty line. I spoke of the more than 60,000 people who live on the verge of homelessness and of the 40,000 who sleep in refuges at night and are forced to roam the streets by day. Sadly, the situation has got a lot worse. Many of those who last year were on the verge of homelessness are now out in the streets. Soaring interest rates forcing up rents in capital cities have given them no other option.

Let us not forget the children living in poverty. According to the Prime Minister, we would not have any by next year. Of course, he has now said he might have to apologise for that remark because he was a little bit wrong. But it is anyone's guess where, before the start of next year, he intends to put the estimated 15 per cent of children currently, in late 1989, still living in poverty. We do not have a hope of addressing any of these concerns while this country remains with the same tired, unworkable economic policies this Treasurer has pursued with little success for the past seven years. Take the Labor Government's roads policy, for example.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, you take it.

—Over the past seven years all we have got is increased fuel taxes and decreased road funding. Senator Sheil makes the point that if he could only get some of these Labor Party Ministers to have a look at the roads all around the country areas of Australia they would see, as Senator Sheil would see travelling around his vast State of Queensland, the problems caused by this Government. This Government has failed to understand that 70 per cent of our domestic trade is carried by roads, with road cargo haulage increasing by 25 per cent between 1982 and 1985 and expected to double in the next 10 years. It is expected that the number of cars will increase by over 60 per cent by the turn of the century. Yet the Federal Government has cut funding in real terms by 30 per cent. Only just tonight we have seen on television the carnage on the roads that has been created by some of the semitrailers that are now being forced onto roads that are not adequate for them to travel on at night with all the other traffic. It is not just the National and Liberal parties that are complaining about our roads. The National Roads and Motorists Association says:

SPEECH.PARA: Roads are in an appalling condition and getting worse. Everyone can see that except, for some strange reason, members of the Federal Government; they refuse even to acknowledge there is a problem.

While fuel excise has risen from 6.155c in 1982-83 to an estimated 23.152c per litre in 1989-90, allocations to roads have not similarly increased. We all know at what cost those savings on roads are made. One has only to read the newspapers. I have already alluded to my seeing on television tonight that 20-odd people have been killed in one small area just near this city of Canberra. That is not a record that any government could be proud of.

Yet while the Government is penny-pinching on such vital issues as roads it is offering bribes and handouts to the waterfront. Is that not an area that needs cleaning up? Mr Deputy President, I am quite sure that you would agree that that is an area that really does need a lot of cleaning up. The Government's proposed $290m waterfront reform package is nothing short of a sellout to union pressure. How can the Government possibly justify such a pay-out when it is slashing other essential areas, such as roads, so savagely. Where are this Government's priorities? Are they with card-carrying members of the Labor Party and the various unions of this country? Does this Government only recognise people who live in marginal electorates and belong to blue-collar unions? Certainly the pilots would believe that. While the Prime Minister is giving multi-million dollar handshakes to wharfies he is refusing to talk to the pilots about wage rises-or talk to them at all-to get us out of this horrendous strike that is bringing Australia to its knees.

Hundreds of businesses are going to the wall around the country because the Prime Minister will not put his mind to settling the airlines dispute. Even in affluent Canberra, as Senator Reid would attest from a survey that her office conducted this week, literally hundreds of people have been financially disadvantaged or even destroyed by the strike. If businesses are so savagely hit in Canberra, a city to which most tourists come by bus or car, what hope is there for tourist operators in Tasmania, northern Queensland or the Northern Territory? I heard Senator Tambling earlier tonight, and I know that he is very concerned about the way the strike is affecting people in the Northern Territory.

While the Prime Minister is looking after his mates to the tune of millions of dollars in compensation, what about the little shopkeepers, the one person operators, whose losses may not be as great numerically but are totally devastating? The Prime Minister forgets about them. Even in my home city of Tamworth, people associated with the airline industry or who have connections with the industry are suffering horrendously at the hands of this Government, which will not sit down and talk to try to fix the dispute. Perhaps the commentator Des Keegan best summed up the present situation facing Australia when he wrote:
Labor ran out of direction years ago and the momentum of events is going badly against it; like the Marie Celeste, there's nobody on the bridge.

Fortunately for Australia, there is a choice, unlike the directionless, muddied, failed economic flounderings of the Australian Labor Party, the coalition has put down a set of guidelines more detailed and comprehensive than anything ever produced by any party in Opposition. The policies are clear-cut with direction and detail. More importantly, they will pull Australia out of the economic abyss in which it presently exists under the Hawke Labor Government. We have set out quite clearly our goals and guidelines. Unlike this Government, which cannot say whether inflation will come down by next year and cannot predict where the current account deficit will finish up-and heaven help us in looking at the predictions last year-we have pledged by the end of our first term in government a cut in tax rates, lower interest rates, smaller government, reduced inflation, greater productivity, higher real wages and a foreign debt under control. We do not accept this Government's absurd reliance on high interest rates to cure Australia's economic ills. We reject a high interest rate policy as damaging the very fabric of Australian life.

Let me allude to how that policy affects country people. We are told that the increase in the consumer price index is running at 7.8 per cent, maybe 8 per cent, a year. The input cost increases to people who are running businesses in country areas are between 10 and 15 per cent-that is, increases in the running costs on the same commodities this year compared to last year, because all the people associated with giving services are suffering from high interest rates, the stocks on the shelves have to increase in price for those people even to keep afloat. So it gets passed on down the chain.

The Liberal and National parties believe that it is time for hard working Australians and their families to get a fair go. It is time that those who pay taxes saw some benefits for their efforts and did not have them squandered on handouts for wharfies and protection for wealthy businessmen. When we have a Treasurer who one year describes the balance of payments as Australia's No. 1 economic problem and inflation as the country's No. 1 economic disease and the following year claims that they are the key to securing sustainable lower interest rates, we begin to understand how directionless this country really is under the Hawke Labor Government. The Marie Celeste has nothing on this country. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —This cognate debate on the Appropriation Bills has been a very long one. Judging from the number of speakers who have made impassioned pleas for this Government to change its course, it is time that it took notice of just what is happening in this country today. It is time that we took stock of the situation that exists under this Government. For example, who would want to start a business today? Who would want to get married today and pay the enormous bills that confront young people?
—Who would want to buy a house?
—Yes, who would want to own a house or a car? Who would want to open a mine if they could get permission to prospect?
—Or borrow money from a bank.

—Who would want to borrow money? Interest rates are crippling the country. It is obvious that things are going bad and that the Government is doing nothing about it. It is prepared just to let things drift.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia started under a period of colonial government. At the turn of the century it had a government of cooperative federalism. The Whitlam Government was a government of coercive federalism. Today things are worse. The Australian Labor Party, despite all the rhetoric and talk about being enlightened and progressive, is still lumbered with the socialist objective. It wants to socialise labour, production and the means of exchange. The Government is going ahead willy-nilly and is well on that track. One of the means that it is using is the creation of economic chaos. It is a well known ploy of socialist governments around the world-which have all failed-that the first thing to do to gain control of the country is to destroy its economy. That is what is happening in Australia.

Look at how the country is situated with regard to production. We get our income mainly from the rural and mining industries, with a small but significant contribution from the manufacturing sector. We have to pin our hopes on the mining and agricultural industries. All the incentives for our agricultural industries have been removed by the Labor Government. In fact, life on the land is now a lot more difficult than it was years ago. Similarly, in the mining industry, we have locked up millions and millions of hectares of Australia without even knowing what minerals lie beneath the land-and for no good purpose. I refer, for example, to the decision on Coronation Hill. It is conservatively estimated that the Hill contains minerals which would provide about $500m worth of export earnings for Australia, yet they have just been locked up. In order to pay off our international debt, we would have to discover the equivalent of a Coronation Hill every fortnight for the next year or so and bring them into production so that the country could get itself out of its present mess. That gives us some idea of the extent of the problem caused to this country by this Government.

One would have to say that the mining men are the front row men of the development of any country. They have to find the minerals. The rural industries then usually supply the mines and the miners must move on and explore other areas. This is not easy. We have to provide an enormous infrastructure for people in this industry. Education and hospital facilities are supplied to the mining areas. Nevertheless, it is a risky business which costs a lot of money.

This Government is making it harder and harder for people to explore for minerals. In the pursuit of this socialist objective, if one wanted to have an ideological argument, one could take the word `environment' and substitute it for the word `socialist'. One would then find that the environment is being used as a tool by the Government to destroy the economy. Of course, our Aborigines are mixed up in this mess. They are being used as a tool to thwart the development of this country. This is creating disharmony as well as shattering our economy.

The Government is attacking professional people-the non-union segment of the labour force. I refer to the medical profession-not only ordinary doctors but radiologists and pathologists-the pharmacy industry, the tourist industry and the mining industry. They are all under attack by this Government. Of course, that is another normal socialist ploy. The Government hates independent people. It wants to gain control of them and these are the measures that it is using to gain control of these people.
Government senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I note the derisive laughter by Government senators. They laugh about this sort of thing, but it is part of their plot. I cannot be a party to that. Surely, if they look at the situation in Australia today, they will realise what they are doing to the country and do something about it.
—They are taking us down the road to ruin.

—We are well down the track to ruin. Of course, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) keeps saying that we are on track. We are on his track. He is in a rut. He might be on his track, but he is not on the track to economic prosperity. In fact, socialist governments around the world have proven that they cannot lead to economic prosperity. This one is just adding fuel to the fire.

SPEECH.PARA: I admit that in the last century the bosses used the power of government to make the lot of the working man hard. This led to the rise of the trade union movement. The trade union movement is now so powerful and has been able to achieve such good terms and conditions for its members that it has now priced itself out of the economic market. The prime example is the waterfront in Australia. Featherbedding, double manning and whatever other practices it is engaging in have led us to achieve a deficit of $2 billion a year on the waterfront. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Government say that they have unshackled the financial sector. They have certainly done so, but they cannot do only half of the job. They should unshackle the union sector as well. Of course, they did not do that. By deregulating the financial sector and leaving the union sector to run wild they have added to this country's problems.

Let us look at what happens when one socialises the means of distribution. For example, the Australian National Railways Commission is recording losses. With regard to the airlines, the pilots are on strike. There is no end in sight to the disruption of our air transport industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is being done to solve it?

—The Government is doing nothing to solve it. It is doing things to aid and abet it and make it worse. Every time the parties look like reaching a solution, this Government prevents that from occurring. With regard to another aspect of the transport field, our roads are in a shocking condition. Senator Brownhill is from New South Wales, which probably has the worst roads at the moment and the greatest carnage is occurring on them. It is a tragic circumstance. The state of the roads not only poses a threat to life and limb but also causes damage to vehicles and increases costs. It is all a sorry plight. When one looks at our roads, railways, air transport and the waterfront, one sees that all of those sectors, which provide our means of transport and distribution, are in a form of chaos and are going downhill. The Government is not taking any steps to rectify that situation.
—Except grinding us into the dust with high interest rates.

—The high interest rates are crippling. It is a misdirected policy to use these rates as the sole means of trying to get us out of our economic plight, yet the Government is persisting with it. It is crippling business and preventing new businesses from starting up. It is crippling the housing industry. Housing contributes a great deal to the maintenance of our economy in all fields-from gardening and landscaping to providing work for plumbers and electricians and those in the transport area. The whole basis of our business economy is exemplified by the housing industry. Even taking into account all of those factors, one could not afford to buy a house today because of the crippling cost. People cannot afford to service the present level of interest rates. In most countries, throughout history once interest rates have reached 22 per cent the countries then degenerate into economic chaos. We are getting very close to that situation now. It does not augur well for the future of young people who want to marry, start a family, buy a house and a car and subject themselves to the enormous stress of raising a family and educating children, in the face of the interest rates with which they are now confronted. The deluge of complaints from the Opposition should have woken up the Government to the problems it has created in our economy.
—The carpet snake is asleep.
—Yes, the carpet snake has had a good dinner and it is asleep, but it needs to be woken up.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Death of Professor Gordon Stanley Reid, A.C.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Reynolds) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E. .

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today Senator Button, as Leader of the Government in the Senate, made an announcement about the death of Gordon Reid, the former Governor of Western Australia. It was not a condolence debate and so I did not participate in it then because I did not want to hold up the business of the Senate, although many people confused it with a condolence debate. However I do want to identify with those who mourn the loss of a person whom I regard as a great Australian. I rise now in this adjournment debate to do that. I regard myself as a personal friend of Gordon Reid. I do not pretend that there is anything exclusive about this personal friendship. It is a mark of the man that everyone he touched felt a personal bond of friendship similar to the one that I felt. I think his wife, Ruth, shares this quality: a remarkable capacity to establish rapport with people of all types from all walks of life.

SPEECH.PARA: I had a special interest in Gordon Reid, particularly in his achievement as a Governor. In the early days of the Burke Government when it was looking for someone to take on the difficult task-Labor governments always have greater difficulty in appointing governors after the experience of 1975-I suggested Gordon Reid as a good choice. I do not pretend that I was singly responsible for his appointment but I hope I was one of those who influenced his appointment. I had a great deal of faith in his capacity. I do know that. I also know that this faith was confirmed by consequent events.

Gordon Reid was, indeed, a great Australian, that rare balance between scholar and statesman, dignitary and common man. He brought to the governorship that special capacity to convey the power and importance of his position in a dignified and competent way. Yet he was also-I think this is a rarer achievement-able to identify with and enjoy contact with everyday Australians who would not normally have moved in such circles. As I said, Gordon Reid managed to be everyone's friend, not in any supercilious way but in a genuine way out of an apparently innate interest in people. He was a gentleman in the truest sense of that often loosely used term. Gordon Reid will be greatly missed. He will not easily be replaced as Governor. It will not be easy to emulate the style that he was able to bring to that role. More importantly, he will be missed by the many people from all walks of life who, like I do, count him among their special friends. I convey my sympathy to his wife, Ruth, who has so capably partnered him through his many roles, and to his family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to join with Senator Beahan. He has explained the reasons why I am using the adjournment debate rather than having spoken at the time when other senators did to note the passing of my friend, Gordon Reid. I first met him, not in any role as Governor or other subsequent roles which he played, but when he was appointed as Professor of Politics at the University of Western Australia in 1966. I was a student of his in that year. There were some very distinguished students of politics in that year of whom, I suspect, he thought I was not one. Had he had to choose who was likely to be in the Parliament from that group to speak on this sad occasion, I am sure he would not have picked me as that candidate-and he might have been right.

SPEECH.PARA: He was a very calm and thoughtful man who made a contribution as a teacher because he was interested in ideas. He would never have claimed to have been a great orator or speaker. Students remember some people at university because they were exciting lecturers; they made the subjects sparkle. Gordon was not an exciting speaker. He just loved to talk about the ideas and to advance the discussion of ideas. His background here in the Parliament had given him a great love of democracy, a great commitment to the institution and he wrote and talked and educated people about parliaments and their role and the struggle between the Parliament and the Executive. He will be remembered for that. Other people spoke about it earlier today and I share their views.

But I want to add a different perspective, one that has not been mentioned. I saw Gordon Reid once speaking on a more partisan political occasion. I do not mean party political. It was not a Labor Party occasion; it was a rally about issues. He was usually very concerned not to involve himself in that area. I am not in any way implying what his personal political views might have been. But it was significant that he was talking about his experience in World War II as a pilot. It was a very emotional occasion when he spoke. It clearly affected him substantially and changed the course of his life. It showed me a different side of Gordon Reid, a side which I had not seen before. I guess in a sense that it was Gordon with his guard down and I admired him all the more for that.

I want to tell just one other anecdote about Gordon Reid before concluding. Before he was Governor he was appointed Deputy Vice-Chancellor of the University of Western Australia. I was very surprised, not that he should be chosen because I knew that he would be a good candidate, but that he would accept because I knew that he loved being Professor of Politics. I was still in Western Australia at the time and I saw him and asked him why he had done it. He said, `I have had a great deal from universities. I thought it was time that I gave something back'. I think that explains why he took that position and why he went on to be an excellent Governor. He had a sense of responsibility, of contributing. He was an outstanding Australian.

As well as his wife, Ruth, I knew one of his sons and one of his daughters. They were people who had obviously benefited from Gordon's influence. I regarded them at the time-a long time ago now-as friends and colleagues. I enjoyed working with them. I admired his wife, Ruth. I particularly want to join with those honourable senators today who have spoken about Gordon Reid, to regret that we will not have the benefit of his wise counsel and to hope that others will carry on the excellent work which he did as a teacher, as an administrator at the University, as the Governor and as a great Australian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to associate myself with the remarks of the two previous speakers and with those who spoke earlier today on the very sad occasion of the death of the former Governor of Western Australia, Gordon Reid. Many tributes have been paid to Gordon in this chamber today but I think no finer tribute can be paid than those that appeared in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's television program on Friday night when that station paid a tribute to Gordon. The tributes on that occasion came from the former Governor's staff at Government House in Perth, people who actually worked with Gordon in carrying out his duties on behalf of the State. As Senator Beahan said earlier, both Gordon and his wife, Ruth-it was a combination of both of them-were real people and they associated with real people. His death is a sad occasion not only for people in Western Australia but, indeed, for all Australians.

I understand that it is the policy of the University of Melbourne to pay some portion of royalties received to the inventors and to the Department of the University involved in the invention. The portion of the bionic ear royalties paid to Professor Clark or the Department of Otolaryngology is 25% of total royalty payment for the bionic ear, that is, the University of Melbourne also retains 25%.

(3) Yes. Professor Clark has on a number of occasions approached the Government seeking a re-direction of the Commonwealth's share of bionic ear royalties to his Department. I have recently received agreement from my colleague, the Hon. Peter Walsh, the Minister for Finance, to the Commonwealth foregoing future royalties up to the amount it has received from Cochlear to date and thereafter sharing its royalties on a 50:50 basis with the University of Melbourne. The royalty payments foregone by the Commonwealth will be paid to ABEHI.

(4) The importance that the Government places on ongoing research on the bionic ear is reflected in the Commonwealth's decision to forgo a proportion of its future royalty entitlements in favour of the ABEHI.
